events.text_segment:
I was away below the ferry now. I rose up, and there was Jackson’s Island, about two mile and a half down stream, heavy timbered and standing up out of the middle of the river, big and dark and solid, like a steamboat without any lights. There warn’t any signs of the bar at the head—it was all under water now.
It didn’t take me long to get there. I shot past the head at a ripping rate, the current was so swift, and then I got into the dead water and landed on the side towards the Illinois shore. I run the canoe into a deep dent in the bank that I knowed about; I had to part the willow branches to get in; and when I made fast nobody could a seen the canoe from the outside.
I went up and set down on a log at the head of the island, and looked out on the big river and the black driftwood and away over to the town, three mile away, where there was three or four lights twinkling. A monstrous big lumber-raft was about a mile up stream, coming along down, with a lantern in the middle of it. I watched it come creeping down, and when it was most abreast of where I stood I heard a man say, “Stern oars, there! heave her head to stabboard!” I heard that just as plain as if the man was by my side.
There was a little gray in the sky now; so I stepped into the woods, and laid down for a nap before breakfast.

I was away below the ferry now, drifting slow and easy on the current, feeling the cool night air on my face. The stars were out, bright and clear, and the river was smooth as glass. I could hear the frogs croaking and the occasional splash of a fish jumping. It was peaceful, but I knew I couldn’t let my guard down. 

I kept thinking about Jim and how we’d gotten separated. I hoped he was safe, wherever he was. The raft was gone, and I was alone in the canoe, just me and the river. I reckoned I’d have to find a place to hide come daylight, maybe tie up in some thick willows or behind an island. 

The ferry was long out of sight, but I could still hear the faint sound of voices and laughter drifting over the water. Those folks had no idea I was out here, and that suited me just fine. The less they knew about me, the better. I’d had enough of people and their ways for a while. 

I dipped the paddle into the water now and then to keep the canoe steady, but mostly I let the river carry me. It was a strange feeling, being so free and yet so alone. But I reckoned I’d figure things out sooner or later. The river had a way of taking care of folks, if they let it. 

For now, I just kept floating, listening to the night sounds and watching the stars. The world felt big and wide, and for the first time in a long while, I didn’t mind being a part of it.

events.title: Huck Observes the Search Party and Finds Sustenance
detailed_summary: Huck awakens late in the morning, feeling rested and content in the shade of the trees.
He notices sunlight filtering through the leaves and squirrels chattering nearby.
Feeling lazy, he is about to doze off again when he hears a distant cannon boom.
He realizes a ferry-boat is on the river, with people firing cannons to make his supposed drowned body surface.
Though hungry, Huck decides against starting a fire to avoid detection by the smoke.
He recalls the custom of floating loaves of bread with quicksilver inside to locate drowned bodies.
He moves to the Illinois side of the island and successfully retrieves a loaf of baker's bread from the river using a stick.
After removing the quicksilver, he eats the bread, reflecting that the Widow or Parson's prayers might have led the bread to him, validating their faith but not his own.

events.text_segment:
The sun was up so high when I waked that I judged it was after eight o’clock. I laid there in the grass and the cool shade thinking about things, and feeling rested and ruther comfortable and satisfied. I could see the sun out at one or two holes, but mostly it was big trees all about, and gloomy in there amongst them. There was freckled places on the ground where the light sifted down through the leaves, and the freckled places swapped about a little, showing there was a little breeze up there. A couple of squirrels set on a limb and jabbered at me very friendly.
I was powerful lazy and comfortable—didn’t want to get up and cook breakfast. Well, I was dozing off again when I thinks I hears a deep sound of “boom!” away up the river. I rouses up, and rests on my elbow and listens; pretty soon I hears it again. I hopped up, and went and looked out at a hole in the leaves, and I see a bunch of smoke laying on the water a long ways up—about abreast the ferry. And there was the ferry-boat full of people floating along down. I knowed what was the matter now. “Boom!” I see the white smoke squirt out of the ferry-boat’s side. You see, they was firing cannon over the water, trying to make my carcass come to the top.
I was pretty hungry, but it warn’t going to do for me to start a fire, because they might see the smoke. So I set there and watched the cannon-smoke and listened to the boom. The river was a mile wide there, and it always looks pretty on a summer morning—so I was having a good enough time seeing them hunt for my remainders if I only had a bite to eat. Well, then I happened to think how they always put quicksilver in loaves of bread and float them off, because they always go right to the drownded carcass and stop there. So, says I, I’ll keep a lookout, and if any of them’s floating around after me I’ll give them a show. I changed to the Illinois edge of the island to see what luck I could have, and I warn’t disappointed. A big double loaf come along, and I most got it with a long stick, but my foot slipped and she floated out further. Of course I was where the current set in the closest to the shore—I knowed enough for that. But by-and-by along comes another one, and this time I won. I took out the plug and shook out the little dab of quicksilver, and set my teeth in. It was “baker’s bread”—what the quality eat; none of your low-down corn-pone.
I got a good place amongst the leaves, and set there on a log, munching the bread and watching the ferry-boat, and very well satisfied.

events.title: Huck Establishes Camp and Begins Solitary Island Life
detailed_summary: The search party, however, circles the island and heads up the Missouri side, still occasionally firing the cannon, before finally returning to town.

He sets out a fishing line for the next day's breakfast.
As darkness falls, he smokes by his fire, feeling satisfied, but a sense of loneliness creeps in.
He counters this by sitting on the riverbank, listening to the water, and observing the stars and passing debris before going to bed.
He reflects that this routine helps overcome loneliness.
This pattern continues for three days and nights.
On the fourth day, he decides to explore the island thoroughly, partly to know his domain and partly to pass the time.
During his exploration, he finds an abundance of strawberries, green grapes, green raspberries, and nascent blackberries, anticipating their future usefulness.

I crossed over to that side and watched them. When they got abreast the head of the island they quit shooting and dropped over to the Missouri shore and went home to the town.
I knowed I was all right now. Nobody else would come a-hunting after me. I got my traps out of the canoe and made me a nice camp in the thick woods. I made a kind of a tent out of my blankets to put my things under so the rain couldn’t get at them. I catched a catfish and haggled him open with my saw, and towards sundown I started my camp fire and had supper. Then I set out a line to catch some fish for breakfast.
When it was dark I set by my camp fire smoking, and feeling pretty well satisfied; but by-and-by it got sort of lonesome, and so I went and set on the bank and listened to the current swashing along, and counted the stars and drift logs and rafts that come down, and then went to bed; there ain’t no better way to put in time when you are lonesome; you can’t stay so, you soon get over it.
And so for three days and nights. No difference—just the same thing. But the next day I went exploring around down through the island. I was boss of it; it all belonged to me, so to say, and I wanted to know all about it; but mainly I wanted to put in the time. I found plenty strawberries, ripe and prime; and green summer grapes, and green razberries; and the green blackberries was just beginning to show. They would all come handy by-and-by, I judged.

events.title: Discovery of a Smoldering Campfire and Huck's Fearful Reaction
detailed_summary: While exploring near the foot of the island with his gun for protection, Huck nearly steps on a large snake.
Chasing after the snake, he unexpectedly stumbles upon the still-smoking ashes of a campfire.
His heart races with fear; he immediately unocks his gun and stealthily retreats, his heightened senses making him paranoid.
Reaching his camp feeling unnerved, he quickly packs his belongings back into the canoe, extinguishes his fire, and camouflages the ashes to appear old.
He then climbs a tree and remains there for about two hours, anxiously observing and imagining threats.
Eventually, he descends but stays within the dense woods, remaining vigilant and subsisting on berries and leftover breakfast.
By nightfall, hunger drives him to paddle to the Illinois bank under the cover of darkness to cook supper.
Just as he considers staying there overnight, he hears the sound of horses and people's voices approaching.
He hastily repacks his canoe and creeps through the woods to investigate, overhearing men discussing camping nearby due to tired horses.
Without waiting further, Huck quietly paddles back to his original spot on the island, deciding to sleep in the canoe for safety.

Well, I went fooling along in the deep woods till I judged I warn’t far from the foot of the island. I had my gun along, but I hadn’t shot nothing; it was for protection; thought I would kill some game nigh home. About this time I mighty near stepped on a good-sized snake, and it went sliding off through the grass and flowers, and I after it, trying to get a shot at it. I clipped along, and all of a sudden I bounded right on to the ashes of a camp fire that was still smoking.
My heart jumped up amongst my lungs. I never waited for to look further, but uncocked my gun and went sneaking back on my tiptoes as fast as ever I could. Every now and then I stopped a second amongst the thick leaves and listened, but my breath come so hard I couldn’t hear nothing else. I slunk along another piece further, then listened again; and so on, and so on. If I see a stump, I took it for a man; if I trod on a stick and broke it, it made me feel like a person had cut one of my breaths in two and I only got half, and the short half, too.
When I got to camp I warn’t feeling very brash, there warn’t much sand in my craw; but I says, this ain’t no time to be fooling around. So I got all my traps into my canoe again so as to have them out of sight, and I put out the fire and scattered the ashes around to look like an old last year’s camp, and then clumb a tree.
I reckon I was up in the tree two hours; but I didn’t see nothing, I didn’t hear nothing—I only thought I heard and seen as much as a thousand things. Well, I couldn’t stay up there forever; so at last I got down, but I kept in the thick woods and on the lookout all the time. All I could get to eat was berries and what was left over from breakfast.
By the time it was night I was pretty hungry. So when it was good and dark I slid out from shore before moonrise and paddled over to the Illinois bank—about a quarter of a mile. I went out in the woods and cooked a supper, and I had about made up my mind I would stay there all night when I hear a plunkety-plunk, plunkety-plunk, and says to myself, horses coming; and next I hear people’s voices. I got everything into the canoe as quick as I could, and then went creeping through the woods to see what I could find out. I hadn’t got far when I hear a man say:
“We better camp here if we can find a good place; the horses is about beat out. Let’s look around.”
I didn’t wait, but shoved out and paddled away easy. I tied up in the old place, and reckoned I would sleep in the canoe.

events.title: Huck Decides to Confront the Unknown and Discovers Jim
detailed_summary: Huck endures a restless night, plagued by anxiety and the feeling of being watched.
He resolves that he cannot continue living in such fear and determines to discover the identity of the other person on the island.
Feeling better after making this decision, he takes his paddle and quietly lets his canoe drift along the shadowed edge of the island under the bright moonlight.
After about an hour of silent searching, as a cool breeze signals the approaching dawn, he steers his canoe to shore near the island's foot.
Taking his gun, he slips into the woods and waits, observing the moon set and darkness briefly cover the river.
Soon, a pale streak in the sky announces the coming day.
He cautiously heads towards the area where he previously found the campfire, listening intently.
Although initially unable to locate the spot, he eventually glimpses a fire through the trees.
Approaching with caution, he sees a man lying on the ground, nearly causing him to panic.
The man is covered with a blanket, his head close to the fire.
Huck hides behind bushes, watching intently as daylight grows.
The man stirs, stretches, removes the blanket, and Huck is astonished and relieved to see it is Miss Watson's Jim.
Overjoyed, Huck greets Jim.

“Hello, Jim!” and skipped out.

I didn’t sleep much. The night was long and restless, filled with the creaking of the raft and the distant hoot of an owl. Every little sound made me jump, thinking maybe the duke and the king had caught up with us, or worse—that Pap had somehow found me again. The stars blinked down like cold, unfeeling eyes, and the river whispered secrets I couldn’t quite understand.  

Jim snored softly beside me, his big chest rising and falling steady as the current. I envied him that peace. My mind wouldn’t quit turning over all the things that had happened—the lies we’d told, the scrapes we’d gotten into, and the way them two frauds had near about ruined everything. I kept picturing Mary Jane’s face when she found out the truth, and it made my stomach twist up something awful.  

The moon hung low, casting silver streaks across the water. I reckoned it must’ve been close to dawn, but the sky was still dark as ink. I thought about lighting out for the Territory, just like I’d planned before all this mess. Maybe out there, a fella could breathe free without worrying about who was chasing him or what sin he was supposed to repent for. But then I’d look at Jim, and I knew I couldn’t leave him. Not after all we’d been through.  

A fish jumped somewhere out in the black, making a splash that echoed like a gunshot. I flinched, then cursed myself for being so jumpy. The river was supposed to be our friend, our way to freedom, but tonight it felt like it was watching us, waiting to see what fool thing we’d do next.  

Jim stirred in his sleep, muttering something about his wife and children. My chest got tight hearing it. Here he was, a grown man stolen from his family, and still he looked out for me like I was his own. It made me ashamed of all the times I’d played tricks on him or thought low of him just ‘cause he was black. The world had it all backwards, I decided.  

Finally, the sky started to lighten, pale gray bleeding into the edges of the night. I sat up, rubbing my sore eyes, and watched the sun creep over the trees. Another day, another stretch of river. Maybe today we’d find what we were looking for. Or maybe we’d just keep running. Either way, I reckoned we’d do it together.  

Jim opened his eyes and smiled at me. “Mornin’, Huck.”  

“Mornin’, Jim,” I said, and for the first time all night, I felt like I could breathe.

events.title: Reunion and Initial Explanations
detailed_summary: Jim, startled and terrified, jumps up and then falls to his knees, begging Huck's 'ghost' not to harm him, professing he has always respected the dead.
Huck quickly reassures Jim that he is not dead, expressing his own immense gladness at seeing him and feeling his loneliness dissipate.
He tells Jim he isn't worried about Jim revealing his whereabouts.
Jim remains silent and stares, prompting Huck to suggest making breakfast as daylight has arrived.
Jim questions the utility of a fire for cooking strawberries, but then remembers Huck has a gun, implying they can procure better food.
Huck confirms Jim has been surviving only on berries and similar vegetation.
Jim reveals he arrived on the island the night after Huck was 'killed' and has had nothing else to eat since.
Huck expresses concern for Jim's hunger, and Jim admits he could eat a horse.
Jim, in turn, asks how long Huck has been on the island and what he has eaten, then remembers Huck's gun with satisfaction, urging Huck to hunt while he builds the fire.

He bounced up and stared at me wild. Then he drops down on his knees, and puts his hands together and says:
“Doan’ hurt me—don’t! I hain’t ever done no harm to a ghos’. I alwuz liked dead people, en done all I could for ’em. You go en git in de river agin, whah you b’longs, en doan’ do nuffn to Ole Jim, ’at ’uz awluz yo’ fren’.”
Well, I warn’t long making him understand I warn’t dead. I was ever so glad to see Jim. I warn’t lonesome now. I told him I warn’t afraid of him telling the people where I was. I talked along, but he only set there and looked at me; never said nothing. Then I says:
“It’s good daylight. Le’s get breakfast. Make up your camp fire good.”
“What’s de use er makin’ up de camp fire to cook strawbries en sich truck? But you got a gun, hain’t you? Den we kin git sumfn better den strawbries.”
“Strawberries and such truck,” I says. “Is that what you live on?”
“I couldn’ git nuffn else,” he says.
“Why, how long you been on the island, Jim?”
“I come heah de night arter you’s killed.”
“What, all that time?”
“Yes—indeedy.”
“And ain’t you had nothing but that kind of rubbage to eat?”
“No, sah—nuffn else.”
“Well, you must be most starved, ain’t you?”
“I reck’n I could eat a hoss. I think I could. How long you ben on de islan’?”
“Since the night I got killed.”
“No! W’y, what has you lived on? But you got a gun. Oh, yes, you got a gun. Dat’s good. Now you kill sumfn en I’ll make up de fire.”

He bounced up and stared at me wild. Then he grabbed me by both shoulders and shook me hard, his eyes wide with fear and confusion.  

“Huck Finn!” he gasped. “You—you ain’t dead?”  

I reckon I must’ve looked like a ghost to him, standing there in the moonlight, all pale and ragged. I couldn’t help but grin a little, seeing him so spooked.  

“No, I ain’t dead,” I said. “Though I reckon some folks might wish I was.”

When I finished, he shook his head slow. “That’s mighty risky business, Huck. If they catch you—”  

“They won’t,” I said, though I wasn’t near as sure as I sounded.  

Jim studied me for a long minute, then sighed. “Well, I reckon you ain’t got much choice now. You can’t go back.”  

“Nope,” I agreed. “And neither can you.”  

That’s when it hit me—we was both runaways, him from slavery and me from everything else. And somehow, that made us free in a way neither of us had been before.

events.title: Jim Recounts His Escape from Slavery
detailed_summary: While Jim builds a fire, Huck retrieves provisions from his canoe—meal, bacon, coffee, and cooking utensils—which greatly astonishes Jim, who attributes it to witchcraft.
Huck catches a large catfish, which Jim cleans and fries.
They enjoy a hearty breakfast, with Jim eating voraciously due to his near starvation.
After eating, Jim asks Huck about the 'murder' in the shanty if it wasn't Huck.
Huck explains his elaborate escape plan, which Jim praises as clever, even beyond Tom Sawyer's abilities.
Huck then inquires how Jim came to be on the island.
Jim hesitates, then, after Huck promises not to betray him, confesses he ran off.
Huck, despite societal condemnation of helping a runaway slave, vows to keep Jim's secret.
Jim explains that Miss Watson, despite often treating him roughly, had always said she wouldn't sell him to New Orleans.
However, he grew uneasy seeing a slave trader around and overheard Miss Watson telling the Widow Douglas she was going to sell him for $800, a sum she couldn't resist.
Without waiting to hear more, Jim fled immediately.
He hid in an old cooper-shop, intending to steal a skiff, but people were still about.
The next morning, he heard news of Huck's 'murder' from people going to see the scene.
He remained hidden all day, hungry but not afraid, knowing Miss Watson and the Widow were at a camp-meeting.
At nightfall, he walked up the river road, deciding a raft was his best means of escape as it leaves no tracks.
He swam out to a passing raft, hid on board, and planned to swim ashore on the Illinois side further downriver.

So we went over to where the canoe was, and while he built a fire in a grassy open place amongst the trees, I fetched meal and bacon and coffee, and coffee-pot and frying-pan, and sugar and tin cups, and the nigger was set back considerable, because he reckoned it was all done with witchcraft. I catched a good big catfish, too, and Jim cleaned him with his knife, and fried him.
When breakfast was ready we lolled on the grass and eat it smoking hot. Jim laid it in with all his might, for he was most about starved. Then when we had got pretty well stuffed, we laid off and lazied. By-and-by Jim says:
“But looky here, Huck, who wuz it dat ’uz killed in dat shanty ef it warn’t you?”
Then I told him the whole thing, and he said it was smart. He said Tom Sawyer couldn’t get up no better plan than what I had. Then I says:
“How do you come to be here, Jim, and how’d you get here?”
He looked pretty uneasy, and didn’t say nothing for a minute. Then he says:
“Maybe I better not tell.”
“Why, Jim?”
“Well, dey’s reasons. But you wouldn’ tell on me ef I uz to tell you, would you, Huck?”
“Blamed if I would, Jim.”
“Well, I b’lieve you, Huck. I—I run off.”
“Jim!”
“But mind, you said you wouldn’ tell—you know you said you wouldn’ tell, Huck.”
“Well, I did. I said I wouldn’t, and I’ll stick to it. Honest injun, I will. People would call me a low-down Abolitionist and despise me for keeping mum—but that don’t make no difference. I ain’t a-going to tell, and I ain’t a-going back there, anyways. So, now, le’s know all about it.”
“Well, you see, it ’uz dis way. Ole missus—dat’s Miss Watson—she pecks on me all de time, en treats me pooty rough, but she awluz said she wouldn’ sell me down to Orleans. But I noticed dey wuz a nigger trader roun’ de place considable lately, en I begin to git oneasy. Well, one night I creeps to de do’ pooty late, en de do’ warn’t quite shet, en I hear old missus tell de widder she gwyne to sell me down to Orleans, but she didn’ want to, but she could git eight hund’d dollars for me, en it ’uz sich a big stack o’ money she couldn’ resis’. De widder she try to git her to say she wouldn’ do it, but I never waited to hear de res’. I lit out mighty quick, I tell you.
“I tuck out en shin down de hill, en ’spec to steal a skift ’long de sho’ som’ers ’bove de town, but dey wuz people a-stirring yit, so I hid in de ole tumble-down cooper-shop on de bank to wait for everybody to go ’way. Well, I wuz dah all night. Dey wuz somebody roun’ all de time. ’Long ’bout six in de mawnin’ skifts begin to go by, en ’bout eight er nine every skift dat went ’long wuz talkin’ ’bout how yo’ pap come over to de town en say you’s killed. Dese las’ skifts wuz full o’ ladies en genlmen a-goin’ over for to see de place. Sometimes dey’d pull up at de sho’ en take a res’ b’fo’ dey started acrost, so by de talk I got to know all ’bout de killin’. I ’uz powerful sorry you’s killed, Huck, but I ain’t no mo’ now.
“I laid dah under de shavin’s all day. I ’uz hungry, but I warn’t afeard; bekase I knowed ole missus en de widder wuz goin’ to start to de camp-meet’n’ right arter breakfas’ en be gone all day, en dey knows I goes off wid de cattle ’bout daylight, so dey wouldn’ ’spec to see me roun’ de place, en so dey wouldn’ miss me tell arter dark in de evenin’. De yuther servants wouldn’ miss me, kase dey’d shin out en take holiday soon as de ole folks ’uz out’n de way.
“Well, when it come dark I tuck out up de river road, en went ’bout two mile er more to whah dey warn’t no houses. I’d made up my mine ’bout what I’s agwyne to do. You see, ef I kep’ on tryin’ to git away afoot, de dogs ’ud track me; ef I stole a skift to cross over, dey’d miss dat skift, you see, en dey’d know ’bout whah I’d lan’ on de yuther side, en whah to pick up my track. So I says, a raff is what I’s arter; it doan’ make no track.
“I see a light a-comin’ roun’ de p’int bymeby, so I wade’ in en shove’ a log ahead o’ me en swum more’n half way acrost de river, en got in ’mongst de drift-wood, en kep’ my head down low, en kinder swum agin de current tell de raff come along. Den I swum to de stern uv it en tuck a-holt. It clouded up en ’uz pooty dark for a little while. So I clumb up en laid down on de planks. De men ’uz all ’way yonder in de middle, whah de lantern wuz. De river wuz a-risin’, en dey wuz a good current; so I reck’n’d ’at by fo’ in de mawnin’ I’d be twenty-five mile down de river, en den I’d slip in jis b’fo’ daylight en swim asho’, en take to de woods on de Illinois side.
“But I didn’ have no luck. When we ’uz mos’ down to de head er de islan’ a man begin to come aft wid de lantern, I see it warn’t no use fer to wait, so I slid overboard en struck out fer de islan’. Well, I had a notion I could lan’ mos’ anywhers, but I couldn’t—bank too bluff. I ’uz mos’ to de foot er de islan’ b’fo’ I found’ a good place. I went into de woods en jedged I wouldn’ fool wid raffs no mo’, long as dey move de lantern roun’ so. I had my pipe en a plug er dog-leg, en some matches in my cap, en dey warn’t wet, so I ’uz all right.”

I nodded, feeling the same way. There was something mighty fine about being out on the river, with no rules but the ones we made for ourselves.  

“You reckon we oughta keep movin’ tonight?” I asked.  

Jim thought a minute. “Might be best. Dem men back yonder ain’t gonna give up lookin’ for me easy, an’ de longer we stay in one place, de more chance dey got to find us.”  

So we packed up our things and got back in the canoe, pushing off into the dark water. The moon was high now, casting silver ripples across the river, and the trees along the banks stood like shadows.  

We didn’t talk much, just let the current carry us along. Every now and then, a fish would jump, or an owl would hoot from the woods, but otherwise, it was quiet—the kind of quiet that makes you feel like you’re the only two people left in the world.  

After a while, Jim spoke up, his voice low. “Huck… you ever think ‘bout what’s waitin’ for us downriver?”  

I hadn’t, really. I’d been too busy thinking about getting away to wonder much about where we was going. “Reckon we’ll find out when we get there,” I said.  

Jim didn’t answer right away. Then he said, “I’s hopin’ to get to one of dem free states. Work honest, save up money, maybe buy my family outta slavery someday.”  

Hearing him talk like that made me feel queer. Here I was, just running off for the fun of it, and Jim was running for his life—for his *freedom*. It put things in a different light.  

“We’ll get you there, Jim,” I said, though I didn’t know how.  

He nodded, like he believed me, and we paddled on in silence.  

The night wore on, and the air got cooler. I started to get drowsy, my eyelids heavy, but I didn’t want to stop just yet. Then, up ahead, I saw a light—just a tiny glimmer, like a candle in a window.  

“Jim,” I whispered, pointing. “You see that?”  

He squinted. “Uh-huh. Mighty small, though. Could be a farmhouse.”  

“Or a steamboat,” I said.  

We let the canoe drift closer, keeping to the shadows. As we got nearer, I could make out the shape of a little raft tied up near the shore, and a man sitting beside a fire. He was alone, far as I could tell.  

“What you reckon we oughta do?” Jim asked.  

I thought about it. Could be a fellow traveler, could be trouble. But we was running low on supplies, and if he was friendly, maybe he’d trade.  

“Let’s get a little closer,” I said. “Keep quiet, though.”  

We eased the canoe up to the bank, staying low. The man hadn’t seen us yet—he was busy stirring something in a pot. He was ragged-looking, with a long beard and a hat pulled down low over his eyes.  

Then, all of a sudden, he looked up straight at us.  

“Well,” he said, grinning like he’d been expecting us all along. “If it ain’t a couple of river rats. Y’all look like you could use a hot meal.”  

Jim tensed beside me, but something about the man’s voice didn’t seem threatening. Still, I kept my hand near my knife, just in case.  

“We ain’t lookin’ for trouble,” I said.  

The man chuckled. “Ain’t nobody out here but us chickens. Come on up and set a spell—got stew on the fire.”  

Jim and I exchanged a look. Then, real slow, we climbed out of the canoe.  

Maybe it was a mistake. Maybe it wasn’t. But one thing was sure—our adventure was just getting started.

events.title: Jim Discusses Superstitions and His Financial Misfortunes
detailed_summary: Huck asks Jim why he didn't eat turtles, and Jim explains the difficulty of catching them, especially at night or without revealing himself in daylight.
Jim confirms he heard the cannons being fired for Huck.
Jim points out young birds flying short distances as a sign of impending rain, a belief he extends from chickens.
He dissuades Huck from catching the birds, citing it as a sign of death, recalling an instance involving his father.
Jim shares other superstitions: counting food for dinner or shaking a tablecloth after sundown brings bad luck; bees must be informed of their owner's death to prevent them from dying.
Jim claims bees won't sting idiots, a notion Huck doubts from personal experience.
Huck notes that Jim knows many signs, mostly related to bad luck.
When asked about good luck signs, Jim mentions few, like hairy arms and breast signifying future wealth, which can offer comfort during long periods of poverty.
Jim confirms he has hairy arms and breast and claims to have been rich once (with fourteen dollars) and expects to be rich again.
He recounts his financial speculations: he lost money on a cow that died, only recouping a small amount from the hide.

He then invested his remaining money with a one-legged man named Bradish who started a 'bank,' promising a large return, but the bank 'busted' after Jim had also 'bought' a stolen wood-flat with the anticipated earnings.

His last ten cents were given to a man called 'Balum's Ass' for investment, based on a dream, after Balum heard a preacher say giving to the poor is lending to the Lord with a hundredfold return; the money was given to the poor but never seen again.
Jim concludes by stating that, in a way, he is rich now because he owns himself and is worth eight hundred dollars, wishing he had the cash equivalent.

“And so you ain’t had no meat nor bread to eat all this time? Why didn’t you get mud-turkles?”
“How you gwyne to git ’m? You can’t slip up on um en grab um; en how’s a body gwyne to hit um wid a rock? How could a body do it in de night? En I warn’t gwyne to show mysef on de bank in de daytime.”
“Well, that’s so. You’ve had to keep in the woods all the time, of course. Did you hear ’em shooting the cannon?”
“Oh, yes. I knowed dey was arter you. I see um go by heah—watched um thoo de bushes.”
Some young birds come along, flying a yard or two at a time and lighting. Jim said it was a sign it was going to rain. He said it was a sign when young chickens flew that way, and so he reckoned it was the same way when young birds done it. I was going to catch some of them, but Jim wouldn’t let me. He said it was death. He said his father laid mighty sick once, and some of them catched a bird, and his old granny said his father would die, and he did.
And Jim said you mustn’t count the things you are going to cook for dinner, because that would bring bad luck. The same if you shook the table-cloth after sundown. And he said if a man owned a beehive and that man died, the bees must be told about it before sun-up next morning, or else the bees would all weaken down and quit work and die. Jim said bees wouldn’t sting idiots; but I didn’t believe that, because I had tried them lots of times myself, and they wouldn’t sting me.
I had heard about some of these things before, but not all of them. Jim knowed all kinds of signs. He said he knowed most everything. I said it looked to me like all the signs was about bad luck, and so I asked him if there warn’t any good-luck signs. He says:
“Mighty few—an’ dey ain’t no use to a body. What you want to know when good luck’s a-comin’ for? Want to keep it off?” And he said: “Ef you’s got hairy arms en a hairy breas’, it’s a sign dat you’s agwyne to be rich. Well, dey’s some use in a sign like dat, ’kase it’s so fur ahead. You see, maybe you’s got to be po’ a long time fust, en so you might git discourage’ en kill yo’sef ’f you didn’ know by de sign dat you gwyne to be rich bymeby.”
“Have you got hairy arms and a hairy breast, Jim?”
“What’s de use to ax dat question? Don’t you see I has?”
“Well, are you rich?”
“No, but I ben rich wunst, and gwyne to be rich agin. Wunst I had foteen dollars, but I tuck to specalat’n’, en got busted out.”
“What did you speculate in, Jim?”
“Well, fust I tackled stock.”
“What kind of stock?”
“Why, live stock—cattle, you know. I put ten dollars in a cow. But I ain’ gwyne to resk no mo’ money in stock. De cow up ’n’ died on my han’s.”
“So you lost the ten dollars.”
“No, I didn’t lose it all. I on’y los’ ’bout nine of it. I sole de hide en taller for a dollar en ten cents.”
“You had five dollars and ten cents left. Did you speculate any more?”
“Yes. You know that one-laigged nigger dat b’longs to old Misto Bradish? Well, he sot up a bank, en say anybody dat put in a dollar would git fo’ dollars mo’ at de en’ er de year. Well, all de niggers went in, but dey didn’t have much. I wuz de on’y one dat had much. So I stuck out for mo’ dan fo’ dollars, en I said ’f I didn’ git it I’d start a bank mysef. Well, o’ course dat nigger want’ to keep me out er de business, bekase he says dey warn’t business ’nough for two banks, so he say I could put in my five dollars en he pay me thirty-five at de en’ er de year.
“So I done it. Den I reck’n’d I’d inves’ de thirty-five dollars right off en keep things a-movin’. Dey wuz a nigger name’ Bob, dat had ketched a wood-flat, en his marster didn’ know it; en I bought it off’n him en told him to take de thirty-five dollars when de en’ er de year come; but somebody stole de wood-flat dat night, en nex day de one-laigged nigger say de bank’s busted. So dey didn’ none uv us git no money.”
“What did you do with the ten cents, Jim?”
“Well, I ’uz gwyne to spen’ it, but I had a dream, en de dream tole me to give it to a nigger name’ Balum—Balum’s Ass dey call him for short; he’s one er dem chuckleheads, you know. But he’s lucky, dey say, en I see I warn’t lucky. De dream say let Balum inves’ de ten cents en he’d make a raise for me. Well, Balum he tuck de money, en when he wuz in church he hear de preacher say dat whoever give to de po’ len’ to de Lord, en boun’ to git his money back a hund’d times. So Balum he tuck en give de ten cents to de po’, en laid low to see what wuz gwyne to come of it.”
“Well, what did come of it, Jim?”
“Nuffn never come of it. I couldn’ manage to k’leck dat money no way; en Balum he couldn’. I ain’ gwyne to len’ no mo’ money ’dout I see de security. Boun’ to git yo’ money back a hund’d times, de preacher says! Ef I could git de ten cents back, I’d call it squah, en be glad er de chanst.”
“Well, it’s all right anyway, Jim, long as you’re going to be rich again some time or other.”
“Yes; en I’s rich now, come to look at it. I owns mysef, en I’s wuth eight hund’d dollars. I wisht I had de money, I wouldn’ want no mo’.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“And so you ain’t had no meat nor bread to eat all this time? Why didn’t you get mud-turkles?”  

Huck Finn looked up from where he was sprawled on the raft, squinting against the sun. Jim had been fussing over him like an old hen ever since they’d left Jackson’s Island, and now here he was, scolding him for not eating right.  

“Mud-turkles?” Huck repeated, scratching his head. “What in tarnation are mud-turkles?”  

Jim shook his head, his broad face creased with concern. “Mud-turkles is turtles, Huck. You ain’t never et a turtle?”  

Huck wrinkled his nose. “Can’t say as I have. Ain’t they slimy?”  

Jim chuckled, deep and warm. “Naw, they ain’t slimy if you cook ’em right. Down where I come from, folks catch ’em all the time. Good eatin’, too—better’n possum, if you ask me.”  

Huck sat up, suddenly interested. “How d’you catch ’em?”  

“Easy as pie,” Jim said, settling himself on the edge of the raft. “You find ’em sunnin’ on logs or rocks near the riverbank. Sneak up quiet-like, grab ’em by the tail, and flip ’em over. Once they’re on their backs, they can’t do nothin’ but wave them little legs in the air.”  

Huck grinned. “Sounds like fun. Reckon we could try it?”  

Jim nodded. “We sure could. But first, we got to find us a good spot where they’s likely to be.”  

The raft drifted lazily downstream, the Mississippi carrying them along like an old friend. Huck leaned over the side, peering into the murky water, half-expecting to see a mud-turkle staring back at him.  

“Jim,” he said after a while, “you ever eat anything else strange like that?”  

Jim thought for a moment. “Well, there’s frogs’ legs. Some folks say they taste like chicken.”  

Huck made a face. “Frogs’ legs? That’s plumb crazy!”  

Jim laughed. “Ain’t no crazier than eatin’ squirrel or rabbit. When you hungry enough, you’ll eat near ’bout anything.”  

Huck reckoned that was true. He’d eaten some mighty odd things himself when times were lean. Still, the idea of chomping down on a frog’s leg made him shudder.  

“What about snakes?” he asked, mostly to see what Jim would say.  

Jim’s expression turned serious. “Now, Huck, you don’t want to mess with snakes. Some of ’em is poison, and even the ones that ain’t—well, it just ain’t right.”  

Huck nodded. He’d had his fill of snakes after that dead one he’d put in Jim’s bedroll as a joke. Jim had near about jumped clean out of his skin when he found it.  

The sun dipped lower in the sky, painting the river in shades of gold and red. Jim stood and stretched. “Reckon we ought to start lookin’ for a place to tie up for the night. Then maybe we can see ’bout catchin’ us some supper.”  

Huck scrambled to his feet, eager for the hunt. “You think we’ll find any mud-turkles?”  

Jim smiled. “If the good Lord’s willin’ and the creek don’t rise.”  

And with that, they poled the raft toward the shore, ready for whatever adventure—and supper—the river had in store for them.

events.title: Discovery and Assessment of the Cavern
detailed_summary: Huck decided to show Jim a specific location he had previously discovered in the central part of the island.
The island itself was relatively small, making the journey to the spot quick.
The place was a moderately long and steep hill, about forty feet high, presenting a challenging climb due to its steepness and dense bushes.
After thorough exploration, they located a large cavern in the rock, positioned near the summit on the side facing Illinois.
The cavern was spacious, comparable to two or three combined rooms, allowing Jim to stand upright comfortably, and it offered a cool interior.
Jim immediately suggested moving their supplies into the cavern, but Huck expressed reservations about the inconvenience of constantly climbing to and from it.

Jim was for putting our traps in there right away, but I said we didn’t want to be climbing up and down there all the time.

Huck described the dramatic visual effects: the landscape appearing blue-black in the intense darkness, the thick rain obscuring distant trees into dim, web-like shapes, and powerful gusts of wind bending trees and revealing the pale undersides of their leaves.

He noted the branches thrashing wildly, followed by sudden, brilliant flashes of lightning that briefly illuminated treetops far off in the storm, then immediate, profound darkness again, and the awesome sound of thunder rolling across the sky.
Huck expressed his deep contentment to Jim, stating he desired to be nowhere else but their current refuge, and asked for more fish and cornbread.

Jim responded by reminding Huck that his present comfort and safety from being drenched in the woods were due to Jim's foresight and understanding of natural signs, like the behavior of chickens and birds before rain.

events.title: Navigating the Flooded Island and Finding a Raft
detailed_summary: The river continued to rise for approximately ten to twelve days, eventually overflowing its banks.
Water covered the low-lying areas of the island and the Illinois bottomlands to a depth of three or four feet.
On the Illinois side, the floodwaters spread out for many miles, while the Missouri side, with its high bluffs, maintained its usual half-mile width.
During the daytime, Huck and Jim used their canoe to navigate the flooded island.
They found the deep woods to be remarkably cool and shady, despite the blazing sun elsewhere.
Their explorations involved winding through the trees, sometimes having to retreat and find alternative paths due to thick vine growth.
They observed numerous rabbits, snakes, and other creatures on every old, fallen tree.

After a day or two of the island being submerged, these animals became quite tame from hunger, allowing Huck and Jim to approach and even touch them, though snakes and turtles would retreat into the water.
The ridge where their cavern was located was teeming with such wildlife.
One night, they managed to secure a small section of a lumber raft composed of good pine planks.
This raft section was about twelve feet wide and fifteen or sixteen feet long, with its top surface six or seven inches above the water, providing a solid, level platform.
They sometimes observed saw-logs floating by during the day but let them pass, as they were careful not to reveal their presence in daylight.

events.title: Exploring a Floating House and Discovering a Dead Man
detailed_summary: On another occasion, while they were at the northern end of the island near dawn, a two-story frame house came floating down the river on its west side, tilted significantly.
They paddled out to the house and climbed aboard through an upstairs window.
It was still too dark to see clearly, so they secured their canoe to the house and waited inside for daylight.
Light began to appear before they reached the southern end of the island.
Looking through the window, they could distinguish a bed, a table, two old chairs, various items scattered on the floor, and clothes hanging on the wall.
In a far corner, something lay on the floor that resembled a man.
Jim called out to the figure, but there was no response.
After Huck also shouted, Jim concluded that the man was not asleep but dead, and he went to investigate.
Jim bent down, looked closely, and confirmed it was a dead man, naked, who had been shot in the back and appeared to have been deceased for two or three days.
He advised Huck not to look at the man's face, describing it as too gruesome.
Huck chose not to look at the body at all; Jim covered it with some old rags, though Huck felt it unnecessary as he had no intention of looking.
The room contained scattered old, greasy playing cards, old whiskey bottles, and a pair of masks made from black cloth.
The walls were covered with crude words and pictures drawn with charcoal.
They found two old, dirty calico dresses, a sun-bonnet, women's undergarments, and some men's clothing hanging on the wall, all of which they took for the canoe, thinking it might be useful.
Huck also took an old, speckled straw hat belonging to a boy that was on the floor.
There was a broken milk bottle with a rag stopper, presumably for a baby.
A dilapidated old chest and an old hair trunk with broken hinges stood open, containing nothing of value, suggesting the occupants had left in a hurry without taking most of their possessions.

They salvaged an old tin lantern, a butcher knife missing its handle, a brand-new Barlow knife, numerous tallow candles, a tin candlestick, a gourd, a tin cup, a worn-out old bedquilt, a reticule filled with needles, pins, beeswax, buttons, and thread, a hatchet, some nails, a thick fishline with very large hooks, a roll of buckskin, a leather dog-collar, and a horseshoe.
They also found some vials of medicine without labels.
As they were about to leave, Huck found a reasonably good curry-comb, and Jim discovered an old, shabby fiddle-bow and a wooden leg.
The straps on the wooden leg were broken, but otherwise, it was serviceable, though it didn't fit either of them, and they couldn't find its match despite searching.

We paddled out and got aboard—clumb in at an upstairs window. But it was too dark to see yet, so we made the canoe fast and set in her to wait for daylight.
The light begun to come before we got to the foot of the island. Then we looked in at the window. We could make out a bed, and a table, and two old chairs, and lots of things around about on the floor, and there was clothes hanging against the wall. There was something laying on the floor in the far corner that looked like a man. So Jim says:
“Hello, you!”
But it didn’t budge. So I hollered again, and then Jim says:
“De man ain’t asleep—he’s dead. You hold still—I’ll go en see.”
He went, and bent down and looked, and says:
“It’s a dead man. Yes, indeedy; naked, too. He’s ben shot in de back. I reck’n he’s ben dead two er three days. Come in, Huck, but doan’ look at his face—it’s too gashly.”
I didn’t look at him at all. Jim throwed some old rags over him, but he needn’t done it; I didn’t want to see him. There was heaps of old greasy cards scattered around over the floor, and old whisky bottles, and a couple of masks made out of black cloth; and all over the walls was the ignorantest kind of words and pictures made with charcoal. There was two old dirty calico dresses, and a sun-bonnet, and some women’s underclothes hanging against the wall, and some men’s clothing, too. We put the lot into the canoe—it might come good. There was a boy’s old speckled straw hat on the floor; I took that, too. And there was a bottle that had had milk in it, and it had a rag stopper for a baby to suck. We would a took the bottle, but it was broke. There was a seedy old chest, and an old hair trunk with the hinges broke. They stood open, but there warn’t nothing left in them that was any account. The way things was scattered about we reckoned the people left in a hurry, and warn’t fixed so as to carry off most of their stuff.
We got an old tin lantern, and a butcher-knife without any handle, and a bran-new Barlow knife worth two bits in any store, and a lot of tallow candles, and a tin candlestick, and a gourd, and a tin cup, and a ratty old bedquilt off the bed, and a reticule with needles and pins and beeswax and buttons and thread and all such truck in it, and a hatchet and some nails, and a fishline as thick as my little finger with some monstrous hooks on it, and a roll of buckskin, and a leather dog-collar, and a horseshoe, and some vials of medicine that didn’t have no label on them; and just as we was leaving I found a tolerable good curry-comb, and Jim he found a ratty old fiddle-bow, and a wooden leg. The straps was broke off of it, but, barring that, it was a good enough leg, though it was too long for me and not long enough for Jim, and we couldn’t find the other one, though we hunted all around.

Another night when we was up at the head of the island, just before daylight, here comes a frame-house down, on the west side. It was a sight to see—that big old house a-floating along like some kind of ghost ship, all dark and silent. The river had been high for days, and I reckon it must’ve tore loose from somewheres upcountry. Me and Jim just stood there, watching it drift closer, the moonlight glinting off the wet boards.

“You reckon there’s anybody in there?” Jim whispered, his voice low and uneasy.

I squinted at it. “Dunno. Might be. Or might be empty. River’s been mean lately—could’ve washed it clean out.”

Jim shook his head. “Ain’t right to leave folks drownin’ if they is in there.”

I knew he was right, but the thought of poking around in that creaky old wreck sent a shiver down my spine. Still, we couldn’t just let it pass by without looking. So we poled the raft over slow, keeping quiet like we was sneaking up on a sleeping bear.

When we got close enough, I grabbed hold of a broken window frame and pulled myself up. The wood groaned under my weight, and for a second I thought the whole thing might tip over and swallow me up. But it held, and I climbed inside, Jim right behind me.

The place was a mess—furniture overturned, water sloshing over the floor, and the smell of damp and rot thick in the air. I struck a match, and the little flame showed us a parlor with pictures still hanging crooked on the walls. Then we heard it—a sound like scratching, coming from one of the back rooms.

Jim’s eyes got wide. “Huck, you hear that?”

I nodded, my heart pounding. Could be a rat, I told myself. Or worse. But we crept forward anyway, the floorboards creaking underfoot. The noise got louder as we neared a closed door. I reached out, turned the knob, and pushed it open slow.

There, in the corner, was a man—or what was left of one. He was dead, no doubt about it, his face pale and his clothes soaked through. But the scratching wasn’t coming from him. It was from a crate beside him, something moving inside.

Jim crossed the room quick and pried the lid off. Out jumped the sorriest, scrawniest little dog you ever saw, shivering and whining like it hadn’t eaten in a week. Jim scooped it up right away, murmuring to it soft.

“Poor thing,” he said. “Must’ve been trapped in here since the house got took by the river.”

I looked at the dead man again, wondering who he was and how he’d come to be here. There wasn’t nothing we could do for him now, but at least we’d saved the dog. 

We took what little food we could find—some moldy bread and a jar of preserves—and got out of there fast. The sun was just starting to rise as we pushed off, the frame-house drifting on downstream, bound for only the river knew where. 

Jim held that dog close all day, feeding it bits of fish and talking to it like it was a long-lost friend. And I reckon that was the first time I truly understood what kind of heart Jim had—big enough to care for even the smallest, most helpless creatures the river brought our way.

He said it would fetch bad luck; and besides, he said, he might come and ha’nt us; he said a man that warn’t buried was more likely to go a-ha’nting around than one that was planted and comfortable. That sounded pretty reasonable, so I didn’t say no more; but I couldn’t keep from studying over it and wishing I knowed who shot the man, and what they done it for.
We rummaged the clothes we’d got, and found eight dollars in silver sewed up in the lining of an old blanket overcoat. Jim said he reckoned the people in that house stole the coat, because if they’d a knowed the money was there they wouldn’t a left it. I said I reckoned they killed him, too; but Jim didn’t want to talk about that. I says:
“Now you think it’s bad luck; but what did you say when I fetched in the snake-skin that I found on the top of the ridge day before yesterday? You said it was the worst bad luck in the world to touch a snake-skin with my hands. Well, here’s your bad luck! We’ve raked in all this truck and eight dollars besides. I wish we could have some bad luck like this every day, Jim.”

events.title: Huck's Prank and Jim's Snakebite
detailed_summary: Jim's premonition of bad luck materializes shortly thereafter.
Huck, intending a harmless prank, kills a rattlesnake he finds in their cave and places its coiled body at the foot of Jim's blanket.
Later that night, Huck having forgotten his prank, Jim throws himself onto the blanket, and the dead snake's mate, which had joined it, bites Jim on the heel.
Jim cries out in pain, and Huck quickly dispatches the second snake with a stick.
To treat the bite, Jim immediately begins to drink whiskey from a jug.
Following Jim's instructions for folk remedies, Huck decapitates the snake, skins its body to roast a piece for Jim to consume, and makes Jim wear the rattles on his wrist.
Overcome with guilt, Huck secretly disposes of both snakes to prevent Jim from discovering his culpability in the incident.

It did come, too. It was a Tuesday that we had that talk. Well, after dinner Friday we was laying around in the grass at the upper end of the ridge, and got out of tobacco. I went to the cavern to get some, and found a rattlesnake in there. I killed him, and curled him up on the foot of Jim’s blanket, ever so natural, thinking there’d be some fun when Jim found him there. Well, by night I forgot all about the snake, and when Jim flung himself down on the blanket while I struck a light the snake’s mate was there, and bit him.
He jumped up yelling, and the first thing the light showed was the varmint curled up and ready for another spring. I laid him out in a second with a stick, and Jim grabbed pap’s whisky-jug and begun to pour it down.
He was barefooted, and the snake bit him right on the heel. That all comes of my being such a fool as to not remember that wherever you leave a dead snake its mate always comes there and curls around it. Jim told me to chop off the snake’s head and throw it away, and then skin the body and roast a piece of it. I done it, and he eat it and said it would help cure him. He made me take off the rattles and tie them around his wrist, too. He said that that would help. Then I slid out quiet and throwed the snakes clear away amongst the bushes; for I warn’t going to let Jim find out it was all my fault, not if I could help it.

events.title: Huck's Plan for Reconnaissance in Disguise
detailed_summary: Feeling restless and bored, Huck proposes to cross the river to gather information about current events.
Jim approves of the idea, cautioning Huck to travel at night and remain vigilant.
Jim then offers a creative suggestion: Huck should disguise himself as a girl using some of the clothing they had found earlier.
They collaborate to adjust a calico gown to fit Huck, who completes the ensemble with a sun-bonnet tied under his chin, effectively obscuring his face.
Jim expresses confidence that the disguise would be convincing, even in daylight.
Huck dedicates the day to practicing feminine mannerisms, receiving guidance from Jim on how to improve his walk and to avoid instinctively reaching for his pants pocket through the dress.

detailed_summary: Under the cover of darkness, Huck paddles the canoe to the Illinois shore.
He lands the canoe a little below the ferry landing and makes his way along the riverbank towards the town.
He observes a light emanating from a small shanty that had been unoccupied for a considerable time, piquing his curiosity about its new inhabitant.
Peering through the window, Huck sees an unfamiliar woman, approximately forty years old, engaged in knitting by candlelight.
He feels a sense of relief that she is a stranger, as this lessens the chance of his voice being recognized and his true identity being compromised.
Confident that a newcomer would be well-informed about local happenings, Huck resolves to knock on the door, reminding himself to maintain his assumed persona as a girl.

events.text_segment:
I started up the Illinois shore in the canoe just after dark.
I started across to the town from a little below the ferry-landing, and the drift of the current fetched me in at the bottom of the town. I tied up and started along the bank. There was a light burning in a little shanty that hadn’t been lived in for a long time, and I wondered who had took up quarters there. I slipped up and peeped in at the window. There was a woman about forty year old in there knitting by a candle that was on a pine table. I didn’t know her face; she was a stranger, for you couldn’t start a face in that town that I didn’t know. Now this was lucky, because I was weakening; I was getting afraid I had come; people might know my voice and find me out. But if this woman had been in such a little town two days she could tell me all I wanted to know; so I knocked at the door, and made up my mind I wouldn’t forget I was a girl.

events.title: Huck's Initial Deception at the Woman's House
detailed_summary: Huck, dressed as a girl, is welcomed into a woman's home and invited to sit.
He introduces himself as Sarah Williams from Hookerville, claiming to have walked seven miles.
He states he has already eaten and is not hungry, attributing his lateness to stopping at a farm.

Huck fabricates a story about his mother being sick and destitute, and his journey to inform his Uncle Abner Moore, who supposedly lives in the town, which Huck claims to be visiting for the first time.
The woman, Judith Loftus, mentions she has only lived in the town for about two weeks and does not know Abner Moore.
She suggests Huck stay the night due to the late hour and the distance to the upper part of town, offering for him to remove his bonnet.
Huck declines, saying he will rest for a while then continue, expressing no fear of the dark.
Mrs. Loftus insists he shouldn't go alone and says her husband will accompany him, expecting him back in about an hour and a half.
She then launches into a lengthy discourse about her husband, her relatives both up and down the river, their former better circumstances, and their potential regret in moving to the current town.
Huck begins to worry that he chose the wrong person to ask for information, until her conversation shifts towards his father, Pap, and the recent murder.

events.title: Unraveling the Town's Theories on Huck's Murder
detailed_summary: After observing Huck, Mrs. Loftus asks for his name, to which he replies "Sarah Williams."
She inquires about his residence, and he claims to live in Hookerville, seven miles away, explaining his fatigue from the long walk.

When she offers food, Huck states he already ate at a farm, which made him late, and reiterates his story about his sick mother and seeking his Uncle Abner Moore at the upper end of town, a place he's never been.
Mrs. Loftus, a newcomer to the town of under two weeks, doesn't know Abner Moore and suggests "Sarah" stay the night due to the distance, but Huck prefers to rest and continue, unafraid of the dark.
She proposes her husband, expected soon, could accompany him, then digresses into her family history and dissatisfaction with their move, making Huck anxious he picked the wrong informant.
Eventually, her conversation turns to Pap Finn and the murder, piquing Huck's interest.

Mrs. Loftus recounts the tale of Huck and Tom Sawyer finding money (inflating the amount to ten thousand dollars), Pap's bad character, and Huck's own perceived roughness, before discussing Huck's supposed murder.
Huck, in character, asks who is suspected of killing Huck Finn.
Mrs. Loftus explains that Pap Finn was initially the prime suspect and was nearly lynched by the townspeople.
However, opinion shifted when a runaway slave named Jim disappeared on the very night of the murder.
She informs Huck that there's a $300 reward for Jim and a $200 reward for Pap.
She details Pap's suspicious return the morning after the murder, his participation in the ferry search, and his subsequent quick departure, which led to a desire to lynch him before he vanished.
The discovery of Jim's absence the next day then pointed suspicion towards him.
Pap later reappeared, tearfully convincing Judge Thatcher to give him money to hunt for Jim, but then got drunk with strangers and left again, not having returned since.

The prevailing belief now, she says, is that Pap killed Huck to secure his money, staged it as a robbery, and plans to return in about a year when things cool down to claim the inheritance without legal trouble, as people believe him capable of such a deed.
Huck feigns agreement and inquires if everyone has ceased to suspect Jim.

"Which side of a tree does the moss grow on?"  

"North side."  

"If fifteen cows is browsing on a hillside, how many of them eats with their heads pointed the same direction?"  

"The whole fifteen, mum."  

"Well, I reckon you have lived in the country. I thought maybe you was trying to hocus me again. What's your real name, now?"  

"George Peters, mum."  

"Well, try to remember it, George. Don't forget and tell me it's Elexander before you go, and then get out by saying it's George Elexander when I catch you. And don't go about women in that old calico. You do a girl tolerable poor, but you might fool men, maybe. Bless you, child, when you set out to thread a needle don't hold the thread still and fetch the needle up to it; hold the needle still and poke the thread at it; that's the way a woman most always does, but a man always does t'other way. And when you throw at a rat or anything, hitch yourself up a tiptoe and fetch your hand up over your head as awkward as you can, and miss your rat about six or seven foot. Throw stiff-armed from the shoulder, like there was a pivot there for it to turn on, like a girl; not from the wrist and elbow, with your arm out to one side, like a boy. And, mind you, when a girl tries to catch anything in her lap she throws her knees apart; she don't clap them together, the way you did when you catched the lump of lead. Why, I spotted you for a boy when you was threading the needle; and I contrived the other things just to make certain. Now trot along to your uncle, Sarah Mary Williams George Elexander Peters, and if you get into trouble you send word to Mrs. Judith Loftus, which is me, and I'll do what I can to get you out of it. Keep the river road all the way, and next time you tramp take shoes and socks with you. The river road's a rocky one, and your feet'll be in a condition when you get to Goshen, I reckon."  

I went up the bank about fifty yards, and then I doubled on my tracks and slipped back to where my canoe was, a good piece below the house. I jumped in, and was off in a hurry. I went up-stream far enough to make the head of the island, and then started across. I took off the sun-bonnet, for I didn't want no blinders on then. When I was about the middle I heard the clock begin to strike, so I stops and listens; the sound come faint over the water but clear—eleven. When I struck the head of the island I never waited to blow, though I was most winded, but I shoved right into the timber where my old camp used to be, and started a good fire there on a high and dry spot.  

Then I jumped in the canoe and dug out for our place, a mile and a half below, as hard as I could go. I landed, and slopped through the timber and up the ridge and into the cavern. There Jim laid, sound asleep on the ground. I roused him out and says:  

"Git up and hump yourself, Jim! There ain't a minute to lose. They're after us!"  

Jim never asked no questions, he never said a word; but the way he worked for the next half an hour showed about how he was scared. By that time everything we had in the world was on our raft, and she was ready to be shoved out from the willow cove where she was hid. We put out the camp fire at the cavern the first thing, and didn't show a candle outside after that.  

I took the canoe out from the shore a little piece, and took a look; but if there was a boat around I couldn't see it, for stars and shadows ain't good to see by. Then we got out the raft and slipped along down in the shade, past the foot of the island dead still—never saying a word.

events.title: Cracks in the Disguise: Huck's Nervous Errors and Name Slip-up
detailed_summary: The news of the impending search for Jim makes Huck extremely anxious, unable to sit still.
To occupy his trembling hands, he picks up a needle and attempts to thread it, performing the task poorly.
When Mrs. Loftus pauses, Huck looks up to see her observing him with a curious smile.
He puts the needle down and, feigning interest (though genuinely concerned), asks if her husband is going to the island that night.
Mrs. Loftus confirms they will go after midnight.
Huck questions whether waiting for daylight would offer better visibility for the search.
She counters that the darkness is advantageous, as Jim would likely be asleep, making it easier for them to locate his campfire if he has one.
Huck admits he hadn't considered that possibility.
Mrs. Loftus continues to scrutinize him, making Huck increasingly uncomfortable.
She then asks him to repeat his name.
Flustered, Huck stammers, "M—Mary Williams."
It immediately strikes him that he previously stated his name was Sarah, and he feels cornered, fearing his anxiety is evident.
Mrs. Loftus points out his earlier use of the name Sarah.
Huck quickly improvises, claiming his full name is Sarah Mary Williams and that people use either Sarah or Mary.
Mrs. Loftus seemingly accepts this explanation.
Huck feels a momentary sense of relief but still wishes to be elsewhere and is unable to meet her gaze.

events.text_segment:
I had got so uneasy I couldn’t set still. I had to do something with my hands; so I took up a needle off of the table and went to threading it. My hands shook, and I was making a bad job of it. When the woman stopped talking I looked up, and she was looking at me pretty curious and smiling a little. I put down the needle and thread, and let on to be interested—and I was, too—and says:
“Three hundred dollars is a power of money. I wish my mother could get it. Is your husband going over there to-night?”
“Oh, yes. He went up-town with the man I was telling you of, to get a boat and see if they could borrow another gun. They’ll go over after midnight.”
“Couldn’t they see better if they was to wait till daytime?”
“Yes. And couldn’t the nigger see better, too? After midnight he’ll likely be asleep, and they can slip around through the woods and hunt up his camp fire all the better for the dark, if he’s got one.”
“I didn’t think of that.”
The woman kept looking at me pretty curious, and I didn’t feel a bit comfortable. Pretty soon she says,
“What did you say your name was, honey?”
“M—Mary Williams.”
Somehow it didn’t seem to me that I said it was Mary before, so I didn’t look up—seemed to me I said it was Sarah; so I felt sort of cornered, and was afeared maybe I was looking it, too. I wished the woman would say something more; the longer she set still the uneasier I was. But now she says:
“Honey, I thought you said it was Sarah when you first come in?”
“Oh, yes’m, I did. Sarah Mary Williams. Sarah’s my first name. Some calls me Sarah, some calls me Mary.”
“Oh, that’s the way of it?”
“Yes’m.”
I was feeling better then, but I wished I was out of there, anyway. I couldn’t look up yet.

I had got so uneasy I couldn’t set still. My conscience was gnawing at me like a hungry rat in a corncrib. Here I was, helping Jim run away from Miss Watson, and all the while, folks would say I was no better than a thief. The more I thought on it, the worse I felt. Wasn’t I raised to know better? Weren’t the Widow Douglas and old Miss Watson always preaching about right and wrong?  

I tried telling myself Jim was a good man, that he didn’t deserve to be sold down the river, separated from his family. But then the law came whispering in my ear, saying I was breaking it, that I ought to turn Jim in. The weight of it pressed down on me till I could hardly breathe.  

One night, I made up my mind. I’d write a letter to Miss Watson, telling her where Jim was. It’d ease my soul, I reckoned. So I took out a scrap of paper and a pencil, and my hand shook like a leaf in a storm as I wrote:  

*Miss Watson, your runaway n***** Jim is down here two mile below Pikesville, and Mr. Phelps has got him and he will give him up for the reward if you send.*  

I felt better right off. Clean, almost. But then I got to thinking about Jim—how he called me his only friend, how he’d stood watch over me when I was sick, how he’d laughed and talked about buying his wife and children out of slavery someday. My heart started aching something fierce.  

I held that letter in my hand, trembling. Then I tore it up.  

“All right, then, I’ll *go* to hell,” I said.  

And I reckoned I meant it. If helping Jim meant I was wicked, then wicked I’d be. I’d stick by him, no matter what. And with that, the uneasiness left me, and I felt lighter than I had in days. Sometimes, doing the wrong thing feels right—and that’s the hardest lesson of all.

Well, the woman fell to talking about how hard times was, and how poor they had to live, and how the rats was as free as if they owned the place, and so forth and so on, and then I got easy again. She was right about the rats. You’d see one stick his nose out of a hole in the corner every little while. She said she had to have things handy to throw at them when she was alone, or they wouldn’t give her no peace. She showed me a bar of lead twisted up into a knot, and said she was a good shot with it generly, but she’d wrenched her arm a day or two ago, and didn’t know whether she could throw true now. But she watched for a chance, and directly banged away at a rat; but she missed him wide, and said “Ouch!” it hurt her arm so. Then she told me to try for the next one. I wanted to be getting away before the old man got back, but of course I didn’t let on. I got the thing, and the first rat that showed his nose I let drive, and if he’d a stayed where he was he’d a been a tolerable sick rat. She said that was first-rate, and she reckoned I would hive the next one. She went and got the lump of lead and fetched it back, and brought along a hank of yarn which she wanted me to help her with. I held up my two hands and she put the hank over them, and went on talking about her and her husband’s matters. But she broke off to say:
“Keep your eye on the rats. You better have the lead in your lap, handy.”
So she dropped the lump into my lap just at that moment, and I clapped my legs together on it and she went on talking. But only about a minute. Then she took off the hank and looked me straight in the face, and very pleasant, and says:
“Come, now, what’s your real name?”
“Wh—what, mum?”
“What’s your real name? Is it Bill, or Tom, or Bob?—or what is it?”
I reckon I shook like a leaf, and I didn’t know hardly what to do. But I says:
“Please to don’t poke fun at a poor girl like me, mum. If I’m in the way here, I’ll—”
“No, you won’t. Set down and stay where you are. I ain’t going to hurt you, and I ain’t going to tell on you, nuther. You just tell me your secret, and trust me. I’ll keep it; and, what’s more, I’ll help you. So’ll my old man if you want him to. You see, you’re a runaway ’prentice, that’s all. It ain’t anything. There ain’t no harm in it. You’ve been treated bad, and you made up your mind to cut. Bless you, child, I wouldn’t tell on you. Tell me all about it now, that’s a good boy.”

events.title: A New Fabrication: Huck's Tale of a Runaway Apprentice and Geographical Misstep
detailed_summary: Realizing his disguise is completely compromised, Huck decides to confess, but first makes Mrs. Loftus promise not to betray him.
He then invents a new story: he claims his parents are deceased and that he was legally indentured to a harsh farmer living thirty miles from the river.
He explains that the farmer's mistreatment became unbearable, so he seized an opportunity to escape when the farmer was away for a couple of days.
According to this new tale, he stole some of the farmer's daughter's old clothes for a disguise and has spent three nights traveling the thirty miles, hiding and sleeping during the daytime.
He adds that he brought a bag of bread and meat from home, which sustained him throughout the journey.
He states his intention was to reach the town of Goshen, where he believed his uncle, Abner Moore, would provide for him.
Mrs. Loftus then informs him that he is not in Goshen, but in St. Petersburg, and Goshen is actually ten miles further up the river.
She speculates that the man who gave him directions must have been drunk, as he directed him incorrectly at a fork in the road.
Huck concedes the man did seem intoxicated but says it no longer matters and that he must press on to reach Goshen before daylight.
Mrs. Loftus detains him for a moment, offering to prepare a snack for him to take on his journey.

“Well, he did act like he was drunk, but it ain’t no matter now. I got to be moving along. I’ll fetch Goshen before daylight.”

events.title: Urgent Escape: Huck Warns Jim and They Flee Jackson's Island
detailed_summary: After leaving Mrs. Loftus's house, Huck walks about fifty yards up the riverbank before stealthily retracing his steps to his hidden canoe, located some distance below the house.
He jumps into the canoe and paddles away quickly, heading upstream far enough to reach the head of Jackson's Island before starting to cross the river.
He removes his sun-bonnet, no longer needing it to obscure his vision.
While in the middle of the river, he hears a clock faintly striking eleven.
Upon reaching the head of the island, despite being winded, he doesn't rest but immediately pushes into the timber towards his old campsite.
There, on a high and dry spot, he starts a substantial fire, likely intended as a decoy.
He then jumps back into his canoe and paddles as hard as he can for a mile and a half down to their current hiding place.
He lands and makes his way through the woods and up the ridge to the cavern where Jim is sound asleep on the ground.
Huck urgently rouses Jim, telling him there isn't a moment to lose because they are being pursued.
Jim, without asking any questions or uttering a word, immediately begins to work with a fervor that demonstrates his profound fear.
Within the next half hour, they manage to load all their worldly possessions onto their raft, which is then ready to be pushed out from its concealed spot in a willow cove.
Their first act is to extinguish their campfire at the cavern, and they maintain complete darkness outside afterwards.
Huck takes the canoe a short distance from the shore to scout for any pursuing boats, but the darkness from stars and shadows makes visibility poor.
Finally, they maneuver the raft out and silently drift downstream in the shadows, passing the foot of the island without speaking a word.

events.title: Securing a Hiding Spot and Reflecting on Pursuit
detailed_summary: At first light, Huck and Jim concealed their raft by covering it with cottonwood branches on a tow-head (a sandbar with trees) along the Illinois shore, making it appear like a natural bank collapse.
They felt secure due to their location, with mountains on the Missouri side, dense woods on the Illinois side, and the main river channel running along the Missouri shore.
They spent the entire day hidden, observing the river traffic, including rafts and steamboats.
Huck recounted his conversation with Mrs. Judith Loftus to Jim.
Jim remarked on Mrs. Loftus's cleverness, suggesting she would be smart enough to use a dog to track them rather than just watch a campfire.
Huck then questioned why she hadn't advised her husband to get a dog immediately.
Jim surmised that she likely thought of it later, and the delay caused by the men needing to go to town for a dog gave Huck and Jim the time needed to escape much farther downriver.
Huck concluded that the specific reasons for their successful evasion were less important than the fact that they had, indeed, escaped capture.

events.title: Improving the Raft for the Journey
detailed_summary: As evening approached, Huck and Jim checked their surroundings from their hiding spot and saw no one.
Jim then constructed a cozy shelter, or wigwam, on the raft using some of its top planks, designed to offer protection from sun and rain and to keep their supplies dry.
He elevated the wigwam's floor about a foot above the raft's deck to safeguard their blankets and other items from waves created by steamboats.
Inside the wigwam, they created a fire pit using a layer of dirt held by a frame, enabling them to have a concealed fire during inclement or cold weather.
They also crafted a spare steering oar, anticipating that one of their existing oars might break.

Additionally, they prepared a forked stick to hang their lantern, which was essential for signaling downstream steamboats to prevent collisions, though it wasn't always necessary for upstream boats unless they were at a river crossing, because the high water levels allowed upstream vessels to navigate outside the main channel.

events.title: Peaceful Nights on the River and Passing St. Louis
detailed_summary: On their second night after leaving the tow-head, they traveled for seven to eight hours, propelled by a current moving over four miles an hour.
Their journey was filled with activities like fishing, conversation, and occasional swims to ward off drowsiness.
Drifting down the vast, silent river while gazing at the stars evoked a solemn mood, leading them to speak softly and laugh infrequently, usually with only a quiet chuckle.
They generally experienced favorable weather and encountered no significant problems for several consecutive nights.
Each night they passed towns, which appeared as distant clusters of lights on dark hillsides, with no individual houses discernible.
On their fifth night, they passed St. Louis, which seemed like an entire world illuminated.

Huck, who had previously doubted St. Petersburg claims about St. Louis's population of twenty to thirty thousand, found himself believing it upon seeing the magnificent expanse of lights at two in the morning.
The city was completely silent, its inhabitants seemingly all asleep.

events.text_segment:
This second night we run between seven and eight hours, with a current that was making over four mile an hour. We catched fish and talked, and we took a swim now and then to keep off sleepiness. It was kind of solemn, drifting down the big, still river, laying on our backs looking up at the stars, and we didn’t ever feel like talking loud, and it warn’t often that we laughed—only a little kind of a low chuckle. We had mighty good weather as a general thing, and nothing ever happened to us at all—that night, nor the next, nor the next.
Every night we passed towns, some of them away up on black hillsides, nothing but just a shiny bed of lights; not a house could you see. The fifth night we passed St. Louis, and it was like the whole world lit up. In St. Petersburg they used to say there was twenty or thirty thousand people in St. Louis, but I never believed it till I see that wonderful spread of lights at two o’clock that still night. There warn’t a sound there; everybody was asleep.
