I went off down to the river, studying over this thing, and pretty soon I noticed that my nigger was following along behind. When we was out of sight of the house he looked back and around a second, and then comes a-running, and says:
“Mars Jawge, if you’ll come down into de swamp I’ll show you a whole stack o’ water-moccasins.”
Thinks I, that’s mighty curious; he said that yesterday. He oughter know a body don’t love water-moccasins enough to go around hunting for them. What is he up to, anyway? So I says:
“All right; trot ahead.”
I followed a half a mile; then he struck out over the swamp, and waded ankle deep as much as another half-mile. We come to a little flat piece of land which was dry and very thick with trees and bushes and vines, and he says:
“You shove right in dah jist a few steps, Mars Jawge; dah’s whah dey is. I’s seed ’m befo’; I don’t k’yer to see ’em no mo’.”
Then he slopped right along and went away, and pretty soon the trees hid him. I poked into the place a-ways and come to a little open patch as big as a bedroom all hung around with vines, and found a man laying there asleep—and, by jings, it was my old Jim!
I waked him up, and I reckoned it was going to be a grand surprise to him to see me again, but it warn’t. He nearly cried he was so glad, but he warn’t surprised. Said he swum along behind me that night, and heard me yell every time, but dasn’t answer, because he didn’t want nobody to pick him up and take him into slavery again. Says he:
“I got hurt a little, en couldn’t swim fas’, so I wuz a considable ways behine you towards de las’; when you landed I reck’ned I could ketch up wid you on de lan’ ’dout havin’ to shout at you, but when I see dat house I begin to go slow. I ’uz off too fur to hear what dey say to you—I wuz ’fraid o’ de dogs; but when it ’uz all quiet agin, I knowed you’s in de house, so I struck out for de woods to wait for day. Early in de mawnin’ some er de niggers come along, gwyne to de fields, en dey tuk me en showed me dis place, whah de dogs can’t track me on accounts o’ de water, en dey brings me truck to eat every night, en tells me how you’s a-gitt’n along.”
“Why didn’t you tell my Jack to fetch me here sooner, Jim?”
“Well, ’twarn’t no use to ’sturb you, Huck, tell we could do sumfn—but we’s all right now. I ben a-buyin’ pots en pans en vittles, as I got a chanst, en a-patchin’ up de raf’ nights when—”
“What raft, Jim?”
“Our ole raf’.”
“You mean to say our old raft warn’t smashed all to flinders?”
“No, she warn’t. She was tore up a good deal—one en’ of her was; but dey warn’t no great harm done, on’y our traps was mos’ all los’. Ef we hadn’ dive’ so deep en swum so fur under water, en de night hadn’ ben so dark, en we warn’t so sk’yerd, en ben sich punkin-heads, as de sayin’ is, we’d a seed de raf’. But it’s jis’ as well we didn’t, ’kase now she’s all fixed up agin mos’ as good as new, en we’s got a new lot o’ stuff, in de place o’ what ’uz los’.”
“Why, how did you get hold of the raft again, Jim—did you catch her?”
“How I gwyne to ketch her en I out in de woods? No; some er de niggers foun’ her ketched on a snag along heah in de ben’, en dey hid her in a crick ’mongst de willows, en dey wuz so much jawin’ ’bout which un ’um she b’long to de mos’ dat I come to heah ’bout it pooty soon, so I ups en settles de trouble by tellin’ ’um she don’t b’long to none uv um, but to you en me; en I ast ’m if dey gwyne to grab a young white genlman’s propaty, en git a hid’n for it? Den I gin ’m ten cents apiece, en dey ’uz mighty well satisfied, en wisht some mo’ raf’s ’ud come along en make ’m rich agin. Dey’s mighty good to me, dese niggers is, en whatever I wants ’m to do fur me, I doan’ have to ast ’m twice, honey. Dat Jack’s a good nigger, en pooty smart.”
“Yes, he is. He ain’t ever told me you was here; told me to come, and he’d show me a lot of water-moccasins. If anything happens he ain’t mixed up in it. He can say he never seen us together, and it’ll be the truth.”

I went off down to the river, studying over this thing, and pretty soon I noticed that my nigger was following along behind. I didn’t pay him no mind at first, figuring he’d turn back when he saw I wasn’t in no mood for company. But Jim—that was his name—he just kept on coming, slow and steady, like he had something on his mind but wasn’t quite sure how to say it.  

The river was high and muddy, rolling along like it had a mind of its own, same as always. I picked up a flat stone and skipped it across the water, watching it bounce three times before sinking. Jim stopped a few feet behind me, shifting from one foot to the other.  

"You got somethin’ to say, Jim?" I asked, not looking at him.  

He scratched his head and looked down at his feet. "Well, Marse Huck, I reckon I do."  

I sighed. "Out with it, then."  

Jim took a deep breath. "I been thinkin’... ’bout what you said back there. ’Bout runnin’ off."  

That got my attention. I turned around sharp. "You ain’t told nobody, have you?"  

"No, sir," Jim said quick. "I ain’t told a soul. But Marse Huck, if you fixin’ to light out, I... I reckon I might go with you."  

I stared at him. Jim was a big man, strong as an ox, but right then he looked like a boy caught stealing sugar. His eyes were wide and worried, like he expected me to laugh or holler at him.  

"You?" I said. "Why in blazes would you want to run off with me?"  

Jim looked out at the river, his face all serious. "Ain’t no life for me here, Marse Huck. You know that. And if you go, who’s gonna look after you?"  

I snorted. "I can look after myself."  

Jim didn’t say nothing to that, just kept staring at the water. After a minute, I started feeling foolish. Maybe I could look after myself, but Jim had been doing it for years—keeping me out of trouble, patching me up when I got hurt, even covering for me when I played hooky from school.  

I kicked at the dirt. "You really mean it? You’d run off?"  

Jim nodded. "I mean it."  

I thought about it. Running off alone was one thing, but having Jim along... well, that changed things. He knew the river better than anybody, and he was strong enough to handle whatever trouble came our way. Plus, he was about the only person I knew who wouldn’t try to civilize me or tell me what to do.  

"All right," I said at last. "But we got to be careful. If anybody finds out, they’ll skin us both."  

Jim’s face broke into a grin. "Yes, sir. We’ll be careful as cats."  

And just like that, it was settled. We stood there a while longer, watching the river roll by, both of us knowing that once we stepped onto that raft, there’d be no turning back.  

But somehow, that didn’t scare me near as much as staying put.

events.title: Miss Sophia's Elopement Ignites a Deadly Feud Battle
detailed_summary: Huck prefaces the account of the next day with reluctance. He wakes at dawn to an unusual stillness and discovers Buck is gone.
Downstairs, the house is deserted. Outside, Huck encounters Jack, who informs him that Miss Sophia has eloped during the night, presumably with Harney Shepherdson.

The Grangerford family found out about half an hour earlier, leading to a frantic rush for guns and horses. The women went to rally relatives, while Colonel Saul Grangerford and the boys rode upriver to catch and kill Harney before he could cross with Sophia.
Jack explains that Buck also went, determined to bring back a Shepherdson, and that Huck was deliberately not awakened or involved.
Huck rushes up the river road and soon hears gunfire. He climbs a cottonwood tree near the steamboat landing for a better view.
He witnesses four or five mounted men (Shepherdsons) attacking two young individuals hidden behind a wood-rank. Each time a Shepherdson exposes himself, he is shot at.

The two defenders, squatting back-to-back, watch both directions. Eventually, the attackers seem to retreat towards a store, but one of the defenders takes careful aim and shoots one of them from his saddle.
As the remaining Shepherdsons dismount to help their fallen comrade, the two defenders make a run for it, reaching a woodpile near Huck's tree before the pursuing men can catch them.
Huck recognizes one of the boys as Buck and the other as a slim young man of about nineteen, Buck's cousin Joe.

After the attackers temporarily ride off, Huck calls out to Buck, startling him. Buck, distraught and crying, tells Huck his father and two brothers have been killed in an ambush by the Shepherdsons, along with two or three of the enemy. He laments they didn't wait for reinforcements as the Shepherdsons were too strong.
Buck confirms that Harney and Miss Sophia made it safely across the river, which relieves Huck. However, Buck is intensely regretful for not having killed Harney when he had the chance earlier.
Suddenly, three or four gunshots ring out as the Shepherdson men, having dismounted and circled through the woods, attack from behind.
Buck and Joe, both injured, jump into the river. As they swim with the current, the men run along the bank, shooting at them and shouting, "Kill them, kill them!"

The sight makes Huck so sick he nearly falls from the tree. He states he will not recount all the details, as it would make him sick again, and expresses regret for ever coming ashore to witness such horrors, which he knows will haunt his dreams.

events.text_segment:
I don’t want to talk much about the next day. I reckon I’ll cut it pretty short. I waked up about dawn, and was a-going to turn over and go to sleep again, when I noticed how still it was—didn’t seem to be anybody stirring. That warn’t usual. Next I noticed that Buck was up and gone. Well, I gets up, a-wondering, and goes down stairs—nobody around; everything as still as a mouse. Just the same outside. Thinks I, what does it mean? Down by the wood-pile I comes across my Jack, and says:
“What’s it all about?”
Says he:
“Don’t you know, Mars Jawge?”
“No,” says I, “I don’t.”
“Well, den, Miss Sophia’s run off! ’deed she has. She run off in de night some time—nobody don’t know jis’ when; run off to get married to dat young Harney Shepherdson, you know—leastways, so dey ’spec. De fambly foun’ it out ’bout half an hour ago—maybe a little mo’—en’ I tell you dey warn’t no time los’. Sich another hurryin’ up guns en hosses you never see! De women folks has gone for to stir up de relations, en ole Mars Saul en de boys tuck dey guns en rode up de river road for to try to ketch dat young man en kill him ’fo’ he kin git acrost de river wid Miss Sophia. I reck’n dey’s gwyne to be mighty rough times.”
“Buck went off ’thout waking me up.”
“Well, I reck’n he did! Dey warn’t gwyne to mix you up in it. Mars Buck he loaded up his gun en ’lowed he’s gwyne to fetch home a Shepherdson or bust. Well, dey’ll be plenty un ’m dah, I reck’n, en you bet you he’ll fetch one ef he gits a chanst.”
I took up the river road as hard as I could put. By-and-by I begin to hear guns a good ways off. When I come in sight of the log store and the woodpile where the steamboats lands, I worked along under the trees and brush till I got to a good place, and then I clumb up into the forks of a cottonwood that was out of reach, and watched. There was a wood-rank four foot high a little ways in front of the tree, and first I was going to hide behind that; but maybe it was luckier I didn’t.
There was four or five men cavorting around on their horses in the open place before the log store, cussing and yelling, and trying to get at a couple of young chaps that was behind the wood-rank alongside of the steamboat landing; but they couldn’t come it. Every time one of them showed himself on the river side of the woodpile he got shot at. The two boys was squatting back to back behind the pile, so they could watch both ways.
By-and-by the men stopped cavorting around and yelling. They started riding towards the store; then up gets one of the boys, draws a steady bead over the wood-rank, and drops one of them out of his saddle. All the men jumped off of their horses and grabbed the hurt one and started to carry him to the store; and that minute the two boys started on the run. They got half way to the tree I was in before the men noticed. Then the men see them, and jumped on their horses and took out after them. They gained on the boys, but it didn’t do no good, the boys had too good a start; they got to the woodpile that was in front of my tree, and slipped in behind it, and so they had the bulge on the men again. One of the boys was Buck, and the other was a slim young chap about nineteen years old.
The men ripped around awhile, and then rode away. As soon as they was out of sight I sung out to Buck and told him. He didn’t know what to make of my voice coming out of the tree at first. He was awful surprised. He told me to watch out sharp and let him know when the men come in sight again; said they was up to some devilment or other—wouldn’t be gone long. I wished I was out of that tree, but I dasn’t come down. Buck begun to cry and rip, and ’lowed that him and his cousin Joe (that was the other young chap) would make up for this day yet. He said his father and his two brothers was killed, and two or three of the enemy. Said the Shepherdsons laid for them in ambush. Buck said his father and brothers ought to waited for their relations—the Shepherdsons was too strong for them. I asked him what was become of young Harney and Miss Sophia. He said they’d got across the river and was safe. I was glad of that; but the way Buck did take on because he didn’t manage to kill Harney that day he shot at him—I hain’t ever heard anything like it.
All of a sudden, bang! bang! bang! goes three or four guns—the men had slipped around through the woods and come in from behind without their horses! The boys jumped for the river—both of them hurt—and as they swum down the current the men run along the bank shooting at them and singing out, “Kill them, kill them!” It made me so sick I most fell out of the tree. I ain’t a-going to tell all that happened—it would make me sick again if I was to do that. I wished I hadn’t ever come ashore that night to see such things. I ain’t ever going to get shut of them—lots of times I dream about them.

The river was calm that morning, smooth as glass, like it was holding its breath. That’s the thing about the Mississippi—she’s got moods. One day she’s roaring and wild, the next she’s quiet as a church mouse, like she’s plotting something. I didn’t trust it.

I’d whistle now and then, trying to act like just another boy out fishing, but my heart wasn’t in it. Every shout from shore, every creak of a boat in the distance, set my nerves jumping.

I gave a little wave, trying to look harmless, but they didn’t wave back. Jim didn’t move a muscle, just let the current carry us on past.  

“You reckon they was slave catchers?” I whispered once we were out of earshot.  

Jim shook his head slow. “Don’t know, Huck. But we best keep moving.”  

That was the worst of it—not knowing. Not knowing who was friend, who was foe, who might take one look at Jim and see dollar signs instead of a man. It wore on a person, that kind of watching and waiting.  

By evening, the sky turned the color of a fresh bruise, purple and yellow at the edges. A storm was brewing, and we knew we’d have to find shelter soon. We steered the raft toward a little island, one with enough trees to hide us if need be. The first drops of rain were starting to fall when we dragged the raft up onto the bank.  

Jim got a fire going, small enough not to draw attention but enough to dry us out some. We ate cold cornbread and some fish we’d caught earlier, not saying much. The thunder rolled in, low and mean, and the wind picked up, shaking the leaves like they owed it money.  

I reckon I must’ve dozed off, because the next thing I knew, Jim was shaking me awake, his face tight with worry. “Huck,” he whispered, “listen.”  

And then I heard it—voices, men’s voices, not far off. Laughter, rough and loud, and the sound of boots crunching through the underbrush.

events.title: Huck's Traumatic Escape and Joyful Reunion with Jim on the Raft
detailed_summary: Huck remains hidden in the tree until dusk, too scared to descend, as he continues to hear sporadic gunfire and see armed men, indicating the feud is still active.

He feels deeply downhearted and blames himself for the tragic events, believing that if he had revealed Miss Sophia's note and her suspicious behavior to her father, she might have been locked up, preventing the elopement and the ensuing bloodshed.

After climbing down, Huck creeps along the riverbank and finds two bodies at the water's edge. He pulls them ashore and covers their faces; he cries while covering Buck's face, remembering Buck's kindness to him.
It is now dark. Huck avoids the Grangerford house, instead heading through the woods towards the swamp to find Jim.
Jim is not on his usual island hiding spot, so Huck hurries to the creek where the raft was supposedly hidden, only to find the raft gone, which terrifies him momentarily.
Huck yells out, and to his immense relief, Jim's voice answers from nearby. Jim is overjoyed to see Huck, hugging him tightly.

Jim explains that Jack had come and reported that Huck was likely shot because he hadn't returned home. Consequently, Jim was just starting to move the raft down the creek to be ready to leave as soon as Jack confirmed Huck's death.

Huck reassures Jim and explains that his disappearance will lead the Grangerfords to believe he was killed and floated downriver, a belief that will be aided by 'something up there' (likely the bodies he covered). He urges Jim to shove off into the main river immediately.
Huck only feels truly at ease once the raft is two miles downstream and in the middle of the Mississippi River. They light their signal lantern, feeling free and safe once more.
Having not eaten since the previous day, Huck enjoys a meal of corn-dodgers, buttermilk, pork, cabbage, and greens prepared by Jim. While eating, they talk and enjoy their reunion.

Huck expresses his profound gladness to be away from the feuds, and Jim is equally glad to be away from the swamp. They both agree that there is no home like a raft, where one feels free, easy, and comfortable, unlike the cramped and smothery nature of other places.

I stayed in the tree till it begun to get dark, afraid to come down. Sometimes I heard guns away off in the woods; and twice I seen little gangs of men gallop past the log store with guns; so I reckoned the trouble was still a-going on. I was mighty downhearted; so I made up my mind I wouldn’t ever go anear that house again, because I reckoned I was to blame, somehow. I judged that that piece of paper meant that Miss Sophia was to meet Harney somewheres at half-past two and run off; and I judged I ought to told her father about that paper and the curious way she acted, and then maybe he would a locked her up, and this awful mess wouldn’t ever happened.
When I got down out of the tree, I crept along down the river bank a piece, and found the two bodies laying in the edge of the water, and tugged at them till I got them ashore; then I covered up their faces, and got away as quick as I could. I cried a little when I was covering up Buck’s face, for he was mighty good to me.
It was just dark now. I never went near the house, but struck through the woods and made for the swamp. Jim warn’t on his island, so I tramped off in a hurry for the crick, and crowded through the willows, red-hot to jump aboard and get out of that awful country. The raft was gone! My souls, but I was scared! I couldn’t get my breath for most a minute. Then I raised a yell. A voice not twenty-five foot from me says:
“Good lan’! is dat you, honey? Doan’ make no noise.”
It was Jim’s voice—nothing ever sounded so good before. I run along the bank a piece and got aboard, and Jim he grabbed me and hugged me, he was so glad to see me. He says:
“Laws bless you, chile, I ’uz right down sho’ you’s dead agin. Jack’s been heah; he say he reck’n you’s ben shot, kase you didn’ come home no mo’; so I’s jes’ dis minute a startin’ de raf’ down towards de mouf er de crick, so’s to be all ready for to shove out en leave soon as Jack comes agin en tells me for certain you is dead. Lawsy, I’s mighty glad to git you back agin, honey.”
I says:
“All right—that’s mighty good; they won’t find me, and they’ll think I’ve been killed, and floated down the river—there’s something up there that’ll help them think so—so don’t you lose no time, Jim, but just shove off for the big water as fast as ever you can.”
I never felt easy till the raft was two mile below there and out in the middle of the Mississippi. Then we hung up our signal lantern, and judged that we was free and safe once more. I hadn’t had a bite to eat since yesterday, so Jim he got out some corn-dodgers and buttermilk, and pork and cabbage and greens—there ain’t nothing in the world so good when it’s cooked right—and whilst I eat my supper we talked, and had a good time. I was powerful glad to get away from the feuds, and so was Jim to get away from the swamp. We said there warn’t no home like a raft, after all. Other places do seem so cramped up and smothery, but a raft don’t. You feel mighty free and easy and comfortable on a raft.

I stayed in the tree till it begun to get dark, afraid to come down. The woods were quiet, too quiet, like they was holding their breath. I could hear the leaves rustling now and then, but it weren’t no wind—just some critter moving about, maybe a possum or a coon. My stomach growled something fierce, but I didn’t dare move. Pap was out there somewhere, and I knew he was madder than a wet hen after what I’d done.

I reckoned he’d be looking for me by now, his voice rough as a sawblade, hollering my name like he owned it. The thought sent a shiver down my spine. I’d seen him in a temper before, and it weren’t nothing to trifle with. Last time, he’d near about took a strap to me for just looking at him wrong. This time, though, I’d gone and done worse—I’d run off, and worse still, I’d taken some of his whiskey money. 

The sun dipped lower, painting the sky red like a fresh wound. I figured I couldn’t stay up there forever, so I started easing my way down, branch by branch, trying not to make a sound. My feet hit the ground soft as I could manage, and I crouched there a minute, listening. Nothing but the crickets starting up their evening song. 

I took off running then, keeping low, darting between trees like a rabbit with a hound on its tail. I didn’t know where I was headed, only that it had to be away—away from Pap, away from the Widow Douglas and her civilizing ways, away from everything that wanted to tie me down or tell me what to do. 

The river was my best bet. I’d always had a fondness for the Mississippi. It was wild and free, just like I aimed to be. If I could get to the water, I could follow it south, maybe catch a ride on a raft. Nobody asked questions on the river. A body could disappear there, and nobody’d be the wiser. 

Twilight settled in proper now, the shadows stretching long and thin. I kept moving, my breath coming quick and my heart pounding like a drum. Then I heard it—a sound that near about stopped it altogether. A twig snapped somewhere behind me, too loud to be no animal. 

I froze, my blood turning to ice. There was somebody there, sure as shooting. I didn’t turn around, didn’t even breathe. Then a voice cut through the dark, low and mean. 

“Huck.” 

It was Pap. 

I didn’t wait to hear no more. I lit out like the devil himself was after me, crashing through the underbrush, branches whipping at my arms and face. I could hear him behind me, cussing and stumbling, but I didn’t look back. The river was close—I could smell the damp in the air, hear the water lapping at the bank. 

Then I broke through the trees and there it was, wide and dark and beautiful. Without thinking, I plunged in, the cold water closing over my head like a blessing. I swam hard, letting the current take me, putting as much distance between me and Pap as I could. 

When I finally came up for air, gasping and sputtering, I looked back. Pap stood on the shore, his shape black against the fading light, shaking his fist and yelling things I was glad I couldn’t hear. 

I turned away and let the river carry me off, feeling lighter than I had in a long while. I was free. At least for now. 

But I knew one thing for certain—I weren’t never going back.

events.title: Idyllic Life and Dawn on the Mississippi
detailed_summary: Several days and nights passed with remarkable tranquility and smoothness for Huck and Jim on the raft.
They established a routine: traveling by night and concealing the raft with freshly cut cottonwoods and willows during daylight hours.
Upon mooring, typically in still water near a tow-head, their first task was to set out fishing lines.
Following this, they would swim in the river to cool off and refresh themselves.
They then sat in the knee-deep sandy shallows, observing the arrival of dawn.
The surroundings were utterly silent, save for the occasional croaking of bullfrogs, creating a sense that the entire world was asleep.
The first visual sign of morning was a faint line of woods on the opposite bank, followed by a growing paleness in the sky.
The river's surface would then soften from black to gray, revealing distant trading scows and rafts as small dark shapes or long streaks.
In the profound stillness, faint sounds like a creaking oar or muffled voices could travel great distances.
They learned to identify snags in swift currents by the streaks they made on the water.
Mist would rise from the river, the eastern sky would redden, and features like log cabins on the far bank, likely woodyards, would become discernible.
A pleasant breeze often carried the scent of woods and flowers, though sometimes it was tainted by the smell of decaying fish.
The arrival of full daylight brought sunshine and the cheerful sound of songbirds.
Once daylight was established and a little smoke wouldn't be easily noticed, they would cook freshly caught fish for a hot breakfast.
After their meal, they would relax, observe the river's vast solitude, and eventually drift off to sleep.

Two or three days and nights went by; I reckon I might say they swum by, they slid along so quiet and smooth and lovely. Here is the way we put in the time. It was a monstrous big river down there—sometimes a mile and a half wide; we run nights, and laid up and hid daytimes; soon as night was most gone we stopped navigating and tied up—nearly always in the dead water under a tow-head; and then cut young cottonwoods and willows, and hid the raft with them. Then we set out the lines. Next we slid into the river and had a swim, so as to freshen up and cool off; then we set down on the sandy bottom where the water was about knee deep, and watched the daylight come. Not a sound anywheres—perfectly still—just like the whole world was asleep, only sometimes the bullfrogs a-cluttering, maybe. The first thing to see, looking away over the water, was a kind of dull line—that was the woods on t’other side; you couldn’t make nothing else out; then a pale place in the sky; then more paleness spreading around; then the river softened up away off, and warn’t black any more, but gray; you could see little dark spots drifting along ever so far away—trading scows, and such things; and long black streaks—rafts; sometimes you could hear a sweep screaking; or jumbled up voices, it was so still, and sounds come so far; and by-and-by you could see a streak on the water which you know by the look of the streak that there’s a snag there in a swift current which breaks on it and makes that streak look that way; and you see the mist curl up off of the water, and the east reddens up, and the river, and you make out a log-cabin in the edge of the woods, away on the bank on t’other side of the river, being a woodyard, likely, and piled by them cheats so you can throw a dog through it anywheres; then the nice breeze springs up, and comes fanning you from over there, so cool and fresh and sweet to smell on account of the woods and the flowers; but sometimes not that way, because they’ve left dead fish laying around, gars and such, and they do get pretty rank; and next you’ve got the full day, and everything smiling in the sun, and the song-birds just going it!
A little smoke couldn’t be noticed now, so we would take some fish off of the lines and cook up a hot breakfast. And afterwards we would watch the lonesomeness of the river, and kind of lazy along, and by-and-by lazy off to sleep.

Two or three days and nights went by; I reckon I might say they swum by, they slid along so quiet and smooth and lovely. There warn’t nothing to do but float down the river, watching the trees slip past and listening to the water lap against the raft. The days was warm and lazy, and the nights was cool and full of stars. Jim and me took turns keeping watch, though there warn’t much to watch for ‘cept the river and the sky.  

We’d fish when we got hungry, and sometimes we’d pull up to the bank to gather berries or shoot a rabbit if we was lucky. Jim knew all sorts of things about the river—where the deep parts was, where the currents ran swift, and how to steer clear of snags. He’d hum low to himself sometimes, a kind of mournful tune that made me feel lonesome in a way I didn’t mind.  

One evening, just as the sun was dipping below the trees, we seen a little island ahead, no bigger than a house, with a clump of willows growing thick in the middle. Jim said we ought to stop there for the night, seeing as how the sky was turning red and purple, which he said meant rain before morning. So we tied up the raft and made a little fire on the sand, just big enough to cook some catfish we’d caught earlier.  

The firelight flickered on Jim’s face, and for the first time in a long while, I got to studying him proper. He was a mighty good man, Jim was, always thinking of me before himself. It made me feel queer, knowing how some folks would say he warn’t nothing but a runaway n*****, when he was ten times the person most of ‘em was.  

After supper, we laid back on the sand, listening to the frogs and the night birds calling across the water. Jim pointed up at the stars and told me how some folks believed they was holes in the floor of heaven, letting the light shine through. I reckoned that was as good an explanation as any.  

The rain come just like Jim said it would, soft at first, then coming down steady. We scrambled under the willows, pulling our blankets over us, and listened to the drops patter on the leaves. The river kept on moving, same as always, carrying us along whether we was ready or not.  

And so the days went, slow and easy, like the river itself. For the first time in my life, I felt free—not just from Pap or the Widow Douglas, but from everything that ever tried to tell me how to live. Out there on the water, with Jim for company, I didn’t have to be nothing but myself.  

It was a mighty fine feeling.

events.title: Daytime Observations, Fog, and Evening Contemplations on the Raft
detailed_summary: Upon waking during the day, they might spot a distant steamboat, distinguishable only by its type (stern-wheel or side-wheel), followed by periods of profound quiet and isolation.
They observed other rafts passing in the distance, noting the perceptible delay between seeing an axe fall and hearing its impact due to the distance sound traveled over water.
Their days were spent lazily, immersed in the river's stillness.
On one occasion, a dense fog enveloped them, and passing rafts and other vessels would beat tin pans as a warning to steamboats to prevent collisions.
During this fog, they heard men on a nearby, unseen raft talking, cursing, and laughing, which created an eerie, crawly sensation, as if spirits were present.
Jim expressed his belief that these unseen voices belonged to spirits.
Huck, however, pragmatically countered Jim's superstition, reasoning that spirits wouldn't use earthly curses like “Dern the dern fog.”
As night approached, they would push the raft into the river's current, allowing it to float freely.
They would then light their pipes, dangle their legs in the water, and engage in conversations on various topics.
Huck mentions their preference for being naked day and night, weather permitting, as the new clothes from Buck's family were too fine for comfort and he generally wasn't fond of clothing.
They often experienced the sensation of having the entire vast river to themselves for extended periods.
They would observe distant sparks of light, identifying them as candles in cabin windows or lights on other rafts or scows.
Occasionally, the faint sound of a fiddle or a song would drift across the water from these other crafts.
Huck reflects on the loveliness of living on a raft.
They would lie on their backs, gazing at the star-speckled sky, and debate whether the stars were created or simply came into existence on their own.
Jim believed the stars were made, while Huck, considering their vast number, thought they just happened.
Jim proposed that the moon could have laid the stars, an idea Huck found somewhat reasonable by comparing it to a frog laying numerous eggs.
They also watched falling stars, which Jim believed were spoiled stars ejected from their celestial nest.
At night, they would sometimes see steamboats gliding by, emitting showers of sparks from their chimneys that looked beautiful as they fell into the river.
After a steamboat passed and disappeared around a bend, its waves would eventually reach and joggle the raft, followed by a prolonged silence, broken only by natural sounds like frogs.

After midnight, lights from shore cabins would extinguish, indicating that people had gone to bed; these lights served as their clock, and the first reappearance of a light signaled approaching morning, prompting them to quickly find a hiding place.

events.text_segment:
Wake up by-and-by, and look to see what done it, and maybe see a steamboat coughing along up-stream, so far off towards the other side you couldn’t tell nothing about her only whether she was a stern-wheel or side-wheel; then for about an hour there wouldn’t be nothing to hear nor nothing to see—just solid lonesomeness. Next you’d see a raft sliding by, away off yonder, and maybe a galoot on it chopping, because they’re most always doing it on a raft; you’d see the axe flash and come down—you don’t hear nothing; you see that axe go up again, and by the time it’s above the man’s head then you hear the k’chunk!—it had took all that time to come over the water. So we would put in the day, lazying around, listening to the stillness. Once there was a thick fog, and the rafts and things that went by was beating tin pans so the steamboats wouldn’t run over them. A scow or a raft went by so close we could hear them talking and cussing and laughing—heard them plain; but we couldn’t see no sign of them; it made you feel crawly; it was like spirits carrying on that way in the air. Jim said he believed it was spirits; but I says:
“No; spirits wouldn’t say, ‘Dern the dern fog.’”
Soon as it was night out we shoved; when we got her out to about the middle we let her alone, and let her float wherever the current wanted her to; then we lit the pipes, and dangled our legs in the water, and talked about all kinds of things—we was always naked, day and night, whenever the mosquitoes would let us—the new clothes Buck’s folks made for me was too good to be comfortable, and besides I didn’t go much on clothes, nohow.
Sometimes we’d have that whole river all to ourselves for the longest time. Yonder was the banks and the islands, across the water; and maybe a spark—which was a candle in a cabin window; and sometimes on the water you could see a spark or two—on a raft or a scow, you know; and maybe you could hear a fiddle or a song coming over from one of them crafts. It’s lovely to live on a raft. We had the sky up there, all speckled with stars, and we used to lay on our backs and look up at them, and discuss about whether they was made or only just happened. Jim he allowed they was made, but I allowed they happened; I judged it would have took too long to make so many. Jim said the moon could a laid them; well, that looked kind of reasonable, so I didn’t say nothing against it, because I’ve seen a frog lay most as many, so of course it could be done. We used to watch the stars that fell, too, and see them streak down. Jim allowed they’d got spoiled and was hove out of the nest.
Once or twice of a night we would see a steamboat slipping along in the dark, and now and then she would belch a whole world of sparks up out of her chimbleys, and they would rain down in the river and look awful pretty; then she would turn a corner and her lights would wink out and her powwow shut off and leave the river still again; and by-and-by her waves would get to us, a long time after she was gone, and joggle the raft a bit, and after that you wouldn’t hear nothing for you couldn’t tell how long, except maybe frogs or something.
After midnight the people on shore went to bed, and then for two or three hours the shores was black—no more sparks in the cabin windows. These sparks was our clock—the first one that showed again meant morning was coming, so we hunted a place to hide and tie up right away.

**The Lonesome River**  

There ain’t nothing quite like the lonesomeness of the river at night. You’d be laying there, half-asleep, when suddenly some far-off sound would stir you—maybe the low groan of a steamboat’s whistle, so faint it might’ve been a dream. You’d sit up, rubbing your eyes, and squint across the water, trying to make out the shape of her. Sometimes you could just barely see the white puff of her smoke, curling up against the stars, or catch the glint of her lanterns, bobbing like fireflies on the black water.  

If she was close enough, you could tell whether she was a stern-wheeler or a side-wheeler by the way she moved—side-wheelers churned up the water something fierce, while stern-wheelers left a smoother wake behind ’em. But most times, she was so far off you couldn’t tell nothing at all, just a dark shape creeping along the far shore, coughing out smoke like an old man with a bad chest.  

Then, just as quick as she came, she’d be gone, swallowed up by the night. And after that, there wouldn’t be nothing—no sound but the soft lap of the river against the raft, no sight but the endless stretch of black water and the stars hanging low over it. That’s when the lonesomeness settled in thick, like a fog you couldn’t shake.  

It’s a queer thing, that lonesomeness. It ain’t like being alone in the woods, where there’s always some critter rustling in the brush or an owl calling from the trees. On the river, especially at night, it’s like the whole world’s emptied out, and you’re the last soul left in it. The water stretches on forever, and the sky presses down so close you feel like you could reach up and touch it.  

Sometimes I’d lay there, staring up at them stars, and wonder if anybody else was looking at ’em too—maybe Jim, if he was awake, or some feller on a steamboat miles away. But most times, it felt like I was the only one, like them stars was put there just for me to see. And that’s when the thoughts would come creeping in—thoughts about Pap, and Miss Watson, and all the things I’d run off from.  

The funny thing is, even though the river was lonesome, I didn’t mind it much. There was something peaceful about it, like the whole world had slowed down and was just breathing easy for once. No one telling you what to do, no one fussing at you—just you and the water and the sky.  

But then, just when you was getting used to the quiet, something would stir again—maybe a fish jumping, or a log bumping against the raft. And you’d remember you wasn’t completely alone after all. The river was alive in its own way, always moving, always whispering secrets to whoever was listening.  

And that’s how it went, night after night—the steamboats passing like ghosts, the lonesomeness settling in, and then, just when you thought you couldn’t stand it no more, the river would remind you it was still there, carrying you along to wherever you was meant to go.

events.title: Huck Encounters and Rescues Two Fugitives
detailed_summary: Around daybreak one morning, Huck located a canoe and ventured to the main shore, paddling about a mile up a creek through cypress woods in search of berries.
As he passed a spot where a cowpath intersected the creek, two men suddenly appeared, running down the path in great haste.
Huck's immediate thought was that he or Jim was being pursued, as he always assumed trouble was directed at them.
He was about to make a quick escape, but the men, now very close, called out and implored him to save their lives.
They claimed they had done nothing wrong but were being chased by men and dogs.
They wanted to jump directly into Huck's canoe.
Huck, however, advised them against it, noting he couldn't yet hear dogs or horses, meaning they had time.
He instructed them to push through the brush further up the creek, then enter the water and wade down to him, a tactic designed to throw the pursuing dogs off their scent.
The men followed his directions, and once they were aboard the canoe, Huck sped towards their raft's hiding place at the tow-head.
Within five to ten minutes, they heard the distant shouts of dogs and men.
The pursuers seemed to approach the creek and linger there for a while, though Huck and the escapees couldn't see them.
As Huck paddled further away, the sounds of pursuit grew fainter and eventually ceased altogether.

By the time they had put a mile of woods between them and the creek and reached the main river, all was quiet, and they successfully paddled to the tow-head, concealed themselves in the cottonwoods, and were safe.

One morning about daybreak I found a canoe and crossed over a chute to the main shore—it was only two hundred yards—and paddled about a mile up a crick amongst the cypress woods, to see if I couldn’t get some berries. Just as I was passing a place where a kind of a cowpath crossed the crick, here comes a couple of men tearing up the path as tight as they could foot it. I thought I was a goner, for whenever anybody was after anybody I judged it was me—or maybe Jim. I was about to dig out from there in a hurry, but they was pretty close to me then, and sung out and begged me to save their lives—said they hadn’t been doing nothing, and was being chased for it—said there was men and dogs a-coming. They wanted to jump right in, but I says:
“Don’t you do it. I don’t hear the dogs and horses yet; you’ve got time to crowd through the brush and get up the crick a little ways; then you take to the water and wade down to me and get in—that’ll throw the dogs off the scent.”
They done it, and soon as they was aboard I lit out for our tow-head, and in about five or ten minutes we heard the dogs and the men away off, shouting. We heard them come along towards the crick, but couldn’t see them; they seemed to stop and fool around a while; then, as we got further and further away all the time, we couldn’t hardly hear them at all; by the time we had left a mile of woods behind us and struck the river, everything was quiet, and we paddled over to the tow-head and hid in the cottonwoods and was safe.

Just as I was rounding a bend in the crick, I spotted a thick patch of blackberry bushes heavy with ripe fruit. My mouth watered at the sight, and I steered the canoe toward the bank, tying it to a low-hanging cypress limb. The morning air was cool and damp, and the woods were alive with the chatter of birds and the occasional splash of a turtle slipping into the water.  

I hadn’t been picking berries long when I heard a rustling in the underbrush. My heart jumped into my throat, thinking it might be a wild hog or worse—somebody who’d take me for a runaway. But then I saw a pair of dark eyes peering through the leaves, and a small, ragged boy stepped out. He couldn’t have been more than ten, barefoot and skinny as a rail, with a shock of tangled hair.  

“You stealin’ them berries?” he asked, squinting at me.  

“Ain’t stealin’ if they’re wild,” I said, keeping my voice low. “You want some?”  

He hesitated, then nodded, and I tossed him a handful. He caught them quick and stuffed them into his mouth like he hadn’t eaten in days.  

“You live round here?” I asked.  

He shook his head. “Just passin’ through.”  

Something about the way he said it made me think he was running from something too. Maybe we weren’t so different after all.  

I handed him my hat full of berries. “Take ’em,” I said. “I can get more.”  

He gave me a quick, grateful look before vanishing back into the woods, quiet as a shadow. I stood there a minute, listening to the crick water ripple past, wondering how many folks in this world were just trying to get by unseen. Then I untied the canoe and paddled on, leaving the berries—and the boy—behind.

events.title: The Fugitives Introduce Themselves and Their Troubles
detailed_summary: Huck provides a description of the two men he rescued.

One was elderly, around seventy or older, with a bald head and very gray whiskers. He wore an old, battered slouch hat, a greasy blue woolen shirt, ragged old blue jeans tucked into his boot-tops, and only one home-knit suspender. He also carried an old long-tailed blue jeans coat with brass buttons over his arm.
The other man was about thirty years old and dressed in a similarly shabby manner.
Both men carried large, dilapidated-looking carpet-bags.
After breakfast, as they all relaxed and talked, it became clear that the two fugitives did not know each other prior to their meeting on the path.
The older man inquired of the younger one about the cause of his trouble.

The younger man explained that he had been selling a tartar-removing product for teeth, which unfortunately also tended to remove tooth enamel. He had lingered in a town one night too long and was making his escape when he encountered the older man on the trail, who warned him of approaching pursuers and asked for help.
The younger man, expecting trouble himself, agreed to flee with the older one.

The older man then shared his own predicament: he had been conducting a successful temperance revival for about a week and was very popular, especially with the women, earning five or six dollars a night.
However, a rumor began circulating the previous night that he secretly indulged in alcohol from a private jug.

A Black person alerted him that morning that a mob was quietly gathering with dogs and horses, intending to give him a brief head start before hunting him down to tar and feather him and ride him on a rail. Consequently, he fled immediately, without waiting for breakfast.

events.title: The Younger Con Man Claims Dukedom and Receives Royal Treatment
detailed_summary: The younger fugitive proposed to the older one that they should team up, an idea the older man was amenable to.
They then discussed their respective 'lines' of work, or rather, their various scams and professions.

The younger man listed his skills as a journeyman printer, dabbling in patent medicines, performing as a tragedy actor, practicing mesmerism and phrenology when opportunities arose, occasionally teaching 'singing-geography' school, and sometimes delivering lectures – essentially, anything that was not conventional work.

The older man mentioned his experience in 'doctoring,' particularly laying on of hands for ailments like cancer and paralysis, fortune-telling (especially when someone else could gather the necessary information for him), preaching, working at camp-meetings, and general missionary work.
Following a pause in conversation, the younger man sighed dramatically and began to lament his current circumstances, expressing sorrow at leading such a life and being 'degraded' into such company.
When the older man questioned his lament, the younger man delivered a self-pitying speech, claiming he had brought his downfall upon himself and deserved his current low state.
He then dramatically revealed what he termed 'the secret of my birth,' proclaiming himself to be, by rights, a duke.
Jim's eyes widened in astonishment, and Huck presumed his own did as well.

The younger man elaborated on his claim, stating he was the rightful Duke of Bridgewater, a lineal descendant of the eldest son of a Duke of Bridgewater who had fled to America. He asserted that the titles and estates had been unjustly seized by a second son, while the infant true duke (his ancestor) was ignored.
He portrayed himself as forlorn, hunted, despised, ragged, heartbroken, and degraded by his association with felons on a raft.
Both Jim and Huck felt immense pity for him. The 'Duke' suggested that acknowledging his rank would comfort him more than anything else.

They agreed to do so, and he instructed them to bow when addressing him, use titles such as 'Your Grace,' 'My Lord,' or 'Your Lordship,' and mentioned he wouldn't mind being called 'Bridgewater.' He also requested that one of them wait on him at dinner and perform any small tasks he desired.

Huck and Jim found these requests easy to fulfill. Throughout dinner, Jim attended to the 'Duke,' asking, 'Will yo’ Grace have some o’ dis or some o’ dat?', which clearly pleased the 'Duke' immensely.

“Old man,” said the young one, “I reckon we might double-team it together; what do you think?”
“I ain’t undisposed. What’s your line—mainly?”
“Jour printer by trade; do a little in patent medicines; theater-actor—tragedy, you know; take a turn to mesmerism and phrenology when there’s a chance; teach singing-geography school for a change; sling a lecture sometimes—oh, I do lots of things—most anything that comes handy, so it ain’t work. What’s your lay?”
“I’ve done considerble in the doctoring way in my time. Layin’ on o’ hands is my best holt—for cancer and paralysis, and sich things; and I k’n tell a fortune pretty good when I’ve got somebody along to find out the facts for me. Preachin’s my line, too, and workin’ camp-meetin’s, and missionaryin’ around.”
Nobody never said anything for a while; then the young man hove a sigh and says:
“Alas!”
“What ’re you alassin’ about?” says the baldhead.
“To think I should have lived to be leading such a life, and be degraded down into such company.” And he begun to wipe the corner of his eye with a rag.
“Dern your skin, ain’t the company good enough for you?” says the baldhead, pretty pert and uppish.
“Yes, it is good enough for me; it’s as good as I deserve; for who fetched me so low when I was so high? I did myself. I don’t blame you, gentlemen—far from it; I don’t blame anybody. I deserve it all. Let the cold world do its worst; one thing I know—there’s a grave somewhere for me. The world may go on just as it’s always done, and take everything from me—loved ones, property, everything; but it can’t take that. Some day I’ll lie down in it and forget it all, and my poor broken heart will be at rest.” He went on a-wiping.
“Drot your pore broken heart,” says the baldhead; “what are you heaving your pore broken heart at us f’r? We hain’t done nothing.”
“No, I know you haven’t. I ain’t blaming you, gentlemen. I brought myself down—yes, I did it myself. It’s right I should suffer—perfectly right—I don’t make any moan.”
“Brought you down from whar? Whar was you brought down from?”
“Ah, you would not believe me; the world never believes—let it pass—’tis no matter. The secret of my birth—”
“The secret of your birth! Do you mean to say—”
“Gentlemen,” says the young man, very solemn, “I will reveal it to you, for I feel I may have confidence in you. By rights I am a duke!”
Jim’s eyes bugged out when he heard that; and I reckon mine did, too. Then the baldhead says: “No! you can’t mean it?”
“Yes. My great-grandfather, eldest son of the Duke of Bridgewater, fled to this country about the end of the last century, to breathe the pure air of freedom; married here, and died, leaving a son, his own father dying about the same time. The second son of the late duke seized the titles and estates—the infant real duke was ignored. I am the lineal descendant of that infant—I am the rightful Duke of Bridgewater; and here am I, forlorn, torn from my high estate, hunted of men, despised by the cold world, ragged, worn, heart-broken, and degraded to the companionship of felons on a raft!”
Jim pitied him ever so much, and so did I. We tried to comfort him, but he said it warn’t much use, he couldn’t be much comforted; said if we was a mind to acknowledge him, that would do him more good than most anything else; so we said we would, if he would tell us how. He said we ought to bow when we spoke to him, and say “Your Grace,” or “My Lord,” or “Your Lordship”—and he wouldn’t mind it if we called him plain “Bridgewater,” which, he said, was a title anyway, and not a name; and one of us ought to wait on him at dinner, and do any little thing for him he wanted done.
Well, that was all easy, so we done it. All through dinner Jim stood around and waited on him, and says, “Will yo’ Grace have some o’ dis or some o’ dat?” and so on, and a body could see it was mighty pleasing to him.

I am the lineal descendant of that infant—I am the rightful Duke of Bridgewater; and here am I, forlorn, torn from my high estate, hunted of men, despised by the cold world, ragged, worn, heart-broken, and degraded to the companionship of felons on a raft!”

We tried to comfort him, but he said it warn’t much use, he couldn’t be much comforted; said if we was a mind to acknowledge him, that would do him more good than most anything else; so we said we would, if he would tell us how. The young man nodded eagerly and bounded off toward the shed, his boots kicking up little puffs of dust. The old man watched him go, shaking his head. “Youth,” he muttered to himself. “All fire and no sense.” But there was a fondness in his voice, the kind that comes from remembering his own younger days, when the world seemed full of possibilities and every problem had an easy solution.

Headin’ out to see what’s beyond them hills?”

The old man didn’t look up. “Nope.”

The young man frowned, his brush hovering mid-stroke. “But there’s a whole world out there. Rivers and cities and—and adventures! Don’t you ever wanna see it?”

The old man paused, his gaze drifting toward the horizon, where the hills rolled away into the distance. For a moment, something flickered in his eyes—a shadow of longing, maybe, or regret. But then he shook his head. “Adventures is for fools and young’uns. Me, I’m content right where I’m at.”

events.title: The Older Con Man Claims to Be the Lost King of France
detailed_summary: The older man grew noticeably quiet and appeared uncomfortable witnessing the deferential treatment the 'Duke' was receiving.
He seemed to be contemplating something, and later in the afternoon, he addressed the 'Duke' (calling him 'Bilgewater'), stating that the 'Duke' wasn't the only one who had experienced such troubles.
He asserted that the 'Duke' was not unique in being wrongfully brought down from a high position or in having a secret of his birth, and then the older man himself began to cry.

When pressed, the older man, after securing a promise of trust from the 'Duke,' dramatically revealed his own secret: he declared himself to be the 'late Dauphin,' Louis XVII, son of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette, the rightful King of France.
This revelation caused Huck and Jim to stare in amazement. The 'Duke' expressed skepticism, particularly regarding the older man's age in relation to the historical Dauphin.

The older man attributed his aged appearance, gray hairs, and premature baldness to 'trouble,' presenting himself as the wandering, exiled, trampled-on, and suffering King of France, clad in blue jeans and misery.
Moved by his sorrowful display, Huck and Jim felt both pity and a sense of pride at having such an eminent personage with them. They began to comfort him as they had the 'Duke.'

The 'King' claimed that only death could truly relieve his suffering, but he admitted that being treated according to his royal rights often made him feel better. He requested that people kneel when speaking to him, always call him 'Your Majesty,' serve him first at meals, and not sit in his presence until invited.
Huck and Jim readily complied, bestowing royal honors upon him, which significantly cheered him up.

However, the 'Duke' became somewhat resentful of the new hierarchy and the attention the 'King' was receiving. Despite this, the 'King' acted very friendly towards the 'Duke,' mentioning that his (the King's) father had held the Duke's ancestors in high regard.

After the 'Duke' remained disgruntled for some time, the 'King' philosophically reasoned with him. He pointed out that they would likely be together on the raft for a long time, so being sour would only create discomfort. He emphasized that it wasn't his fault he wasn't born a duke, nor the 'Duke's' fault he wasn't born a king, so there was no use in worrying. He advocated for making the best of their situation and offered his hand in friendship.
The 'Duke' accepted this gesture, and Huck and Jim were greatly pleased, as it dispelled the tension and restored harmony on the raft, which they valued highly for peaceful coexistence.

It ain’t my fault I warn’t born a duke, it ain’t your fault you warn’t born a king—so what’s the use to worry? Make the best o’ things the way you find ’em, says I—that’s my motto. It took away all the uncomfortableness and we felt mighty good over it, because it would a been a miserable business to have any unfriendliness on the raft; for what you want, above all things, on a raft, is for everybody to be satisfied, and feel right and kind towards the others.

But the old man got pretty silent by-and-by—didn’t have much to say, and didn’t look pretty comfortable over all that petting that was going on around that duke. He sat there in the corner, chewing his tobacco slow and thoughtful-like, his eyes darting from one face to another, sizing up the situation. I could see plain enough he was getting riled, though he kept it bottled up inside.  

The duke, on the other hand, was lapping up all the attention like a cat with cream. He had them all fooled—the townsfolk hanging on his every word, treating him like royalty, bringing him presents and such. It was enough to make a body sick, the way they carried on. And the king—well, he wasn’t used to playing second fiddle, and it was eating at him something fierce.  

I kept my mouth shut and watched, knowing full well this wasn’t going to end pretty. Those two rascals had been partners in crime long enough, but jealousy’s a poison that works quick, especially when there’s money or fame involved. And right now, the duke was hogging both.  

That night, after the crowd had finally cleared out and we were left alone in the little room above the tavern, the king let loose.  

“You’re mighty high and mighty all of a sudden,” he growled, his voice low and dangerous. “Struttin’ around like you own the place, lettin’ them fools bow and scrape.”  

The duke just smiled, cool as you please. “A man’s got to play the part he’s given,” he said, smoothing out his fancy coat. “If they want to treat me like nobility, who am I to refuse?”  

The king’s face turned red as a beet. “We’re partners, or have you forgot? Fifty-fifty, that was the deal. But here you are, hoggin’ the spotlight and likely the profits too.”  

I edged toward the door, not wanting to be caught in the middle of what was coming. But the duke just leaned back in his chair, looking like he hadn’t a care in the world. “Now, now,” he said, “no need to get testy. There’s plenty to go around.”  

“Like hell there is!” the king snapped, slamming his fist on the table. “I know your kind—slick talkers who’ll cut a man’s throat soon as look at him. Well, I ain’t about to be cheated, not by you or anybody!”  

For a minute, I thought they might come to blows right then and there. The air was thick with anger, and even Jim, who’d been keeping quiet in the corner, looked uneasy. But then the duke did something unexpected—he laughed.  

“You’re right,” he said, holding up his hands like he was surrendering. “I got carried away. No sense in us quarreling when there’s money to be made. How about we split the next take even, no tricks?”  

The king eyed him suspiciously, but the fight seemed to go out of him some. “All right,” he muttered. “But I’m watchin’ you.”  

Things settled down after that, at least on the surface. But I knew better. That kind of resentment don’t just disappear—it simmers, waiting for the right moment to boil over. And with those two, it was only a matter of time.  

The next morning, the duke made a big show of letting the king take the lead in their next scheme, some nonsense about a lost inheritance. The townsfolk ate it up, same as always, but I could see the king wasn’t fooled. He played along, but his smiles didn’t reach his eyes.  

Jim pulled me aside later. “Huck,” he whispered, “dem two is fixin’ to turn on each other. We best be ready to light out when it happens.”  

I nodded. He didn’t have to tell me twice. I’d seen enough of their kind to know that when thieves fall out, innocent folks had a way of getting caught in the crossfire. And I aimed to make sure Jim and I weren’t around when the shooting started.  

So we kept our eyes open and our bags packed, waiting for the storm to break. Because one thing was certain—wherever those two went, trouble wasn’t far behind.

events.title: Huck's Astute Realization and Pragmatic Decision for Peace
detailed_summary: Huck quickly discerned that the two newcomers were not genuine royalty but were, in fact, common swindlers and deceivers.
Despite this realization, he decided not to reveal his knowledge or challenge their claims.
He concluded that maintaining silence and feigning belief was the most effective strategy to prevent arguments and avoid trouble.
He was willing to address them as kings and dukes if it helped maintain peace within their group, which he thought of as 'the family.'
Furthermore, he saw no benefit in informing Jim of his suspicions, so he kept this insight to himself.

Huck reflected on a lesson learned from his father, Pap: the most practical way to deal with people like the two con men was to allow them to have their own way, thus ensuring a smoother and less confrontational coexistence.

events.title: Huck's Elaborate Lie and the Duke's Plan for Daytime Travel
detailed_summary: The duke and king questioned Huck about why the raft was covered and why they only traveled at night, asking if Jim was a runaway.
Huck deflected the question about Jim running south, which they agreed a runaway wouldn't do.
Huck then fabricated a lengthy story about his family from Pike County, Missouri, explaining that only he, his pa, and his brother Ike survived initially.
He continued the tale, claiming his pa intended to move them to his Uncle Ben's place near Orleans but was poor.
According to Huck's story, after finding a piece of raft, a steamboat accident killed his pa and young Ike, leaving only him and Jim.

“’Tis my fate to be always ground into the mire under the iron heel of oppression. Misfortune has broken my once haughty spirit; I yield, I submit; ’tis my fate. I am alone in the world—let me suffer; I can bear it.”

We got away as soon as it was good and dark. The king told us to stand well out towards the middle of the river, and not show a light till we got a long ways below the town. We come in sight of the little bunch of lights by-and-by—that was the town, you know—and slid by, about a half a mile out, all right. When we was three-quarters of a mile below we hoisted up our signal lantern; and about ten o’clock it come on to rain and blow and thunder and lighten like everything; so the king told us to both stay on watch till the weather got better; then him and the duke crawled into the wigwam and turned in for the night. It was my watch below till twelve, but I wouldn’t a turned in anyway if I’d had a bed, because a body don’t see such a storm as that every day in the week, not by a long sight. My souls, how the wind did scream along! And every second or two there’d come a glare that lit up the white-caps for a half a mile around, and you’d see the islands looking dusty through the rain, and the trees thrashing around in the wind; then comes a h-whack!—bum! bum! bumble-umble-um-bum-bum-bum-bum—and the thunder would go rumbling and grumbling away, and quit—and then rip comes another flash and another sockdolager. The waves most washed me off the raft sometimes, but I hadn’t any clothes on, and didn’t mind. We didn’t have no trouble about snags; the lightning was glaring and flittering around so constant that we could see them plenty soon enough to throw her head this way or that and miss them.
I had the middle watch, you know, but I was pretty sleepy by that time, so Jim he said he would stand the first half of it for me; he was always mighty good that way, Jim was. I crawled into the wigwam, but the king and the duke had their legs sprawled around so there warn’t no show for me; so I laid outside—I didn’t mind the rain, because it was warm, and the waves warn’t running so high now. About two they come up again, though, and Jim was going to call me; but he changed his mind, because he reckoned they warn’t high enough yet to do any harm; but he was mistaken about that, for pretty soon all of a sudden along comes a regular ripper and washed me overboard. It most killed Jim a-laughing. He was the easiest nigger to laugh that ever was, anyway.
I took the watch, and Jim he laid down and snored away; and by-and-by the storm let up for good and all; and the first cabin-light that showed, I rousted him out and we slid the raft into hiding quarters for the day.

The king got out an old ratty deck of cards after breakfast, and him and the duke played seven-up a while, five cents a game. Then they got tired of it, and allowed they would “lay out a campaign,” as they called it. The duke went down into his carpet-bag, and fetched up a lot of little printed bills and read them out loud. One bill said, “The celebrated Dr. Armand de Montalban, of Paris,” would “lecture on the Science of Phrenology” at such and such a place, on the blank day of blank, at ten cents admission, and “furnish charts of character at twenty-five cents apiece.” The duke said that was him. In another bill he was the “world-renowned Shakespearian tragedian, Garrick the Younger, of Drury Lane, London.” In other bills he had a lot of other names and done other wonderful things, like finding water and gold with a “divining-rod,” “dissipating witch spells,” and so on. By-and-by he says:
“But the histrionic muse is the darling. Have you ever trod the boards, Royalty?”
“No,” says the king.
“You shall, then, before you’re three days older, Fallen Grandeur,” says the duke. “The first good town we come to we’ll hire a hall and do the sword fight in Richard III. and the balcony scene in Romeo and Juliet. How does that strike you?”
“I’m in, up to the hub, for anything that will pay, Bilgewater; but, you see, I don’t know nothing about play-actin’, and hain’t ever seen much of it. I was too small when pap used to have ’em at the palace. Do you reckon you can learn me?”
“Easy!”
“All right. I’m jist a-freezn’ for something fresh, anyway. Le’s commence right away.”
So the duke he told him all about who Romeo was and who Juliet was, and said he was used to being Romeo, so the king could be Juliet.
“But if Juliet’s such a young gal, duke, my peeled head and my white whiskers is goin’ to look oncommon odd on her, maybe.”
“No, don’t you worry; these country jakes won’t ever think of that. Besides, you know, you’ll be in costume, and that makes all the difference in the world; Juliet’s in a balcony, enjoying the moonlight before she goes to bed, and she’s got on her night-gown and her ruffled nightcap. Here are the costumes for the parts.”
He got out two or three curtain-calico suits, which he said was meedyevil armor for Richard III. and t’other chap, and a long white cotton nightshirt and a ruffled nightcap to match. The king was satisfied; so the duke got out his book and read the parts over in the most splendid spread-eagle way, prancing around and acting at the same time, to show how it had got to be done; then he give the book to the king and told him to get his part by heart.

The king got out an old ratty deck of cards after breakfast, and him and the duke played seven-up a while, five cents a game. The way them two cheated each other was a sight to behold—neither one of ’em honest enough to fill a thimble, yet both acting like they was saints. The king would squint at his cards like he was studyin’ the Good Book, then slip an ace from his sleeve when the duke wasn’t lookin’. The duke, though, he was just as slick, palmin’ cards like he was born with ’em in his hand.  

I sat off to the side, whittlin’ a stick and pretendin’ not to notice, but it was hard not to laugh. Every now and then, one of ’em would catch the other in some low-down trick, and then there’d be a mighty ruckus—accusations flyin’, tempers flarin’, till one of ’em remembered they was supposed to be gentlemen and smoothed it over with a oily grin.  

“Why, your grace,” the king’d say, all honey-sweet, “I do believe you misremember the play. That there was my queen o’ diamonds.”  

“Was it now?” the duke’d drawl, his eyes narrow as a snake’s. “Funny, ’cause I coulda swore I seen that very card in the last hand.”  

Then they’d both chuckle, like it was all in good fun, but you could see the meanness behind their smiles. They’d start up again, dealin’ fresh hands, and the whole dance would repeat.  

After a time, the duke got tired of losin’—or maybe just tired of the king’s cheatin’—and suggested they try a new game. “How ’bout a round of poker?” he said, shufflin’ the deck with a fancy flourish.  

The king’s eyes lit up like he’d struck gold. “Why, that’s a capital idea, my noble friend! Nothin’ like a friendly game to pass the time.”  

Friendly, my foot. Poker just gave ’em more ways to swindle each other. Now they was bluffin’ and raisin’ stakes like high-toned gamblers, though neither had two nickels to rub together. The pot was mostly buttons and a rusty fishhook by the third hand.  

I reckon they woulda kept at it all day if Jim hadn’t cleared his throat real loud from where he was mendin’ a shirt. “Reckon we best be movin’ along,” he muttered, not lookin’ up. “Daylight’s burnin’.”  

That snapped ’em out of it. The king stuffed the cards back in his coat, grumblin’ about how a man oughta be allowed his pleasures, and the duke stretched like he was doin’ us a favor by quittin’.  

“Right you are, good fellow,” the duke said, smooth as ever. “We’ve dallied long enough. Adventure awaits!”  

I just shook my head. If adventure meant more of their two-bit schemes and cheatin’ at cards, I’d as soon take a nap. But there warn’t no choice in the matter—off we went, floatin’ down the river, with them two rogues plottin’ their next move.

The king got the directions, and allowed he’d go and work that camp-meeting for all it was worth, and I might go, too.
The duke said what he was after was a printing-office. We found it; a little bit of a concern, up over a carpenter shop—carpenters and printers all gone to the meeting, and no doors locked. It was a dirty, littered-up place, and had ink marks, and handbills with pictures of horses and runaway niggers on them, all over the walls. The duke shed his coat and said he was all right now. So me and the king lit out for the camp-meeting.

events.text_segment:
We got there in about a half an hour fairly dripping, for it was a most awful hot day. There was as much as a thousand people there from twenty mile around. The woods was full of teams and wagons, hitched everywheres, feeding out of the wagon-troughs and stomping to keep off the flies. There was sheds made out of poles and roofed over with branches, where they had lemonade and gingerbread to sell, and piles of watermelons and green corn and such-like truck.
The preaching was going on under the same kinds of sheds, only they was bigger and held crowds of people. The benches was made out of outside slabs of logs, with holes bored in the round side to drive sticks into for legs. They didn’t have no backs. The preachers had high platforms to stand on at one end of the sheds. The women had on sun-bonnets; and some had linsey-woolsey frocks, some gingham ones, and a few of the young ones had on calico. Some of the young men was barefooted, and some of the children didn’t have on any clothes but just a tow-linen shirt. Some of the old women was knitting, and some of the young folks was courting on the sly.
The first shed we come to the preacher was lining out a hymn. He lined out two lines, everybody sung it, and it was kind of grand to hear it, there was so many of them and they done it in such a rousing way; then he lined out two more for them to sing—and so on. The people woke up more and more, and sung louder and louder; and towards the end some begun to groan, and some begun to shout. Then the preacher begun to preach, and begun in earnest, too; and went weaving first to one side of the platform and then the other, and then a-leaning down over the front of it, with his arms and his body going all the time, and shouting his words out with all his might; and every now and then he would hold up his Bible and spread it open, and kind of pass it around this way and that, shouting, “It’s the brazen serpent in the wilderness! Look upon it and live!” And people would shout out, “Glory!—A-a-men!” And so he went on, and the people groaning and crying and saying amen:
“Oh, come to the mourners’ bench! come, black with sin! (amen!) come, sick and sore! (amen!) come, lame and halt and blind! (amen!) come, pore and needy, sunk in shame! (a-a-men!) come, all that’s worn and soiled and suffering!—come with a broken spirit! come with a contrite heart! come in your rags and sin and dirt! the waters that cleanse is free, the door of heaven stands open—oh, enter in and be at rest!” (a-a-men! glory, glory hallelujah!)
And so on. You couldn’t make out what the preacher said any more, on account of the shouting and crying. Folks got up everywheres in the crowd, and worked their way just by main strength to the mourners’ bench, with the tears running down their faces; and when all the mourners had got up there to the front benches in a crowd, they sung and shouted and flung themselves down on the straw, just crazy and wild.

Well, the first I knowed the king got a-going, and you could hear him over everybody; and next he went a-charging up on to the platform, and the preacher he begged him to speak to the people, and he done it. He told them he was a pirate—been a pirate for thirty years out in the Indian Ocean—and his crew was thinned out considerable last spring in a fight, and he was home now to take out some fresh men, and thanks to goodness he’d been robbed last night and put ashore off of a steamboat without a cent, and he was glad of it; it was the blessedest thing that ever happened to him, because he was a changed man now, and happy for the first time in his life; and, poor as he was, he was going to start right off and work his way back to the Indian Ocean, and put in the rest of his life trying to turn the pirates into the true path; for he could do it better than anybody else, being acquainted with all pirate crews in that ocean; and though it would take him a long time to get there without money, he would get there anyway, and every time he convinced a pirate he would say to him, “Don’t you thank me, don’t you give me no credit; it all belongs to them dear people in Pokeville camp-meeting, natural brothers and benefactors of the race, and that dear preacher there, the truest friend a pirate ever had!”
And then he busted into tears, and so did everybody. Then somebody sings out, “Take up a collection for him, take up a collection!” Well, a half a dozen made a jump to do it, but somebody sings out, “Let him pass the hat around!” Then everybody said it, the preacher too.
So the king went all through the crowd with his hat swabbing his eyes, and blessing the people and praising them and thanking them for being so good to the poor pirates away off there; and every little while the prettiest kind of girls, with the tears running down their cheeks, would up and ask him would he let them kiss him for to remember him by; and he always done it; and some of them he hugged and kissed as many as five or six times—and he was invited to stay a week; and everybody wanted him to live in their houses, and said they’d think it was an honor; but he said as this was the last day of the camp-meeting he couldn’t do no good, and besides he was in a sweat to get to the Indian Ocean right off and go to work on the pirates.
When we got back to the raft and he come to count up he found he had collected eighty-seven dollars and seventy-five cents. And then he had fetched away a three-gallon jug of whisky, too, that he found under a wagon when he was starting home through the woods. The king said, take it all around, it laid over any day he’d ever put in in the missionarying line. He said it warn’t no use talking, heathens don’t amount to shucks alongside of pirates to work a camp-meeting with.

events.title: Theatrical Rehearsals and Mishaps on the Raft

The Duke and King then rehearsed together, with the Duke meticulously instructing the King on the proper delivery for each of Romeo's speeches.

The Duke stressed that Romeo's words should be spoken softly and with a sense of longing and illness, fitting for addressing Juliet, whom he described as a sweet young girl, not to be addressed with a booming voice.
Subsequently, they practiced a sword fight using long swords fashioned by the Duke from oak laths, with the Duke portraying Richard III, creating an impressive spectacle as they moved about the raft.
The practice session was interrupted when the King stumbled and fell into the river.
After this incident, they ceased their rehearsal, rested, and engaged in conversation about various adventures they had experienced on the river in the past.
