The king and the duke turned out by-and-by looking pretty rusty; but after they’d jumped overboard and took a swim it chippered them up a good deal. After breakfast the king he took a seat on the corner of the raft, and pulled off his boots and rolled up his britches, and let his legs dangle in the water, so as to be comfortable, and lit his pipe, and went to getting his Romeo and Juliet by heart. When he had got it pretty good, him and the duke begun to practice it together. The duke had to learn him over and over again how to say every speech; and he made him sigh, and put his hand on his heart, and after a while he said he done it pretty well; “only,” he says, “you mustn’t bellow out Romeo! that way, like a bull—you must say it soft and sick and languishy, so—R-o-o-meo! that is the idea; for Juliet’s a dear sweet mere child of a girl, you know, and she doesn’t bray like a jackass.”
Well, next they got out a couple of long swords that the duke made out of oak laths, and begun to practice the sword fight—the duke called himself Richard III.; and the way they laid on and pranced around the raft was grand to see. But by-and-by the king tripped and fell overboard, and after that they took a rest, and had a talk about all kinds of adventures they’d had in other times along the river.

After dinner the duke says:
“Well, Capet, we’ll want to make this a first-class show, you know, so I guess we’ll add a little more to it. We want a little something to answer encores with, anyway.”
“What’s onkores, Bilgewater?”
The duke told him, and then says:
“I’ll answer by doing the Highland fling or the sailor’s hornpipe; and you—well, let me see—oh, I’ve got it—you can do Hamlet’s soliloquy.”
“Hamlet’s which?”
“Hamlet’s soliloquy, you know; the most celebrated thing in Shakespeare. Ah, it’s sublime, sublime! Always fetches the house. I haven’t got it in the book—I’ve only got one volume—but I reckon I can piece it out from memory. I’ll just walk up and down a minute, and see if I can call it back from recollection’s vaults.”
So he went to marching up and down, thinking, and frowning horrible every now and then; then he would hoist up his eyebrows; next he would squeeze his hand on his forehead and stagger back and kind of moan; next he would sigh, and next he’d let on to drop a tear. It was beautiful to see him. By-and-by he got it. He told us to give attention. Then he strikes a most noble attitude, with one leg shoved forwards, and his arms stretched away up, and his head tilted back, looking up at the sky; and then he begins to rip and rave and grit his teeth; and after that, all through his speech, he howled, and spread around, and swelled up his chest, and just knocked the spots out of any acting ever I see before. This is the speech—I learned it, easy enough, while he was learning it to the king:
To be, or not to be; that is the bare bodkin
That makes calamity of so long life;
For who would fardels bear, till Birnam Wood do come to Dunsinane,
But that the fear of something after death
Murders the innocent sleep,
Great nature’s second course,
And makes us rather sling the arrows of outrageous fortune
Than fly to others that we know not of.
There’s the respect must give us pause:
Wake Duncan with thy knocking! I would thou couldst;
For who would bear the whips and scorns of time,
The oppressor’s wrong, the proud man’s contumely,
The law’s delay, and the quietus which his pangs might take.
In the dead waste and middle of the night, when churchyards yawn
In customary suits of solemn black,
But that the undiscovered country from whose bourne no traveler returns,
Breathes forth contagion on the world,
And thus the native hue of resolution, like the poor cat i’ the adage,
Is sicklied o’er with care.
And all the clouds that lowered o’er our housetops,
With this regard their currents turn awry,
And lose the name of action.
’Tis a consummation devoutly to be wished.
But soft you, the fair Ophelia:
Ope not thy ponderous and marble jaws.
But get thee to a nunnery—go!
Well, the old man he liked that speech, and he mighty soon got it so he could do it first rate. It seemed like he was just born for it; and when he had his hand in and was excited, it was perfectly lovely the way he would rip and tear and rair up behind when he was getting it off.

events.title: Scouting and Advertising the Show in an Arkansas Town
detailed_summary: At their earliest convenience, the Duke arranged for the printing of show bills.
For the subsequent two or three days, as they drifted downriver, the raft was exceptionally animated with continuous sword-fighting and theatrical rehearsals.
While navigating through Arkansas, they came upon a small, unremarkable town located in a prominent bend of the river.

They secured their raft approximately three-quarters of a mile upstream, concealed within a cypress-bordered creek, and everyone except Jim disembarked in a canoe to explore the town's prospects for their performance.
They discovered that a circus was scheduled for that afternoon, with rural attendees already arriving, but its departure by nightfall would create an opportunity for their show.
The Duke successfully rented the local courthouse as their venue, and the group then proceeded to distribute their promotional posters throughout the town.

The show bills ambitiously proclaimed a "Shaksperean Revival!!!" as a "Wonderful Attraction! For One Night Only!" featuring the "world renowned tragedians, David Garrick the younger" (the Duke) and "Edmund Kean the elder" (the King), from prestigious London theatres, performing "The Balcony Scene" from Romeo and Juliet, a "thrilling, masterly, and blood-curdling Broad-sword conflict In Richard III.!!!", and, by special request, "Hamlet’s Immortal Soliloquy!!" by Kean, allegedly performed for 300 consecutive nights in Paris, all due to "imperative European engagements." Admission was priced at 25 cents, with a reduced rate of 10 cents for children and servants.

Jim and I would sit back and watch, trying not to laugh outright. They’d argue over who had the finer performance, each one trying to outdo the other with more ridiculous antics.  

Then they’d get to quarreling over who got top billing on them show bills the duke had printed up. The duke insisted his name ought to be bigger, seeing as how he was the real talent, while the dauphin swore he was the main attraction on account of his royal blood. It was a sight to behold, two grown men carrying on like children over such foolishness.  

All the while, the raft kept drifting downriver, and Jim and I just shook our heads, knowing full well these two rascals wouldn’t amount to nothing but trouble. But for now, we let ‘em have their fun—leastways, it kept ‘em from scheming up worse mischief.

events.title: Huck's Observations of a Dilapidated Arkansas Town and its Idle Inhabitants
characters: Loafers (Bill, Buck, Hank, Joe, Andy, Lafe Buckner)
detailed_summary: The group then wandered through the town, taking in its general state of disrepair.

Huck noted that the stores and houses were predominantly old, unpainted wooden structures, elevated on stilts to protect against river flooding. Their gardens appeared neglected, primarily cultivating weeds, sunflowers, and accumulating debris like ash-piles and old discarded items.

The fences were haphazardly constructed from various types of boards added at different times, leaning in multiple directions, and often equipped with only a single leather hinge for a gate. Some bore faint remnants of whitewash, which the Duke humorously suggested dated back to Columbus's era.
Hogs were a common sight in gardens, with residents frequently attempting to shoo them away.
All the town's stores were situated along a single street, featuring white fabric awnings in front, where country visitors would tie their horses.

Under these awnings, idle men, referred to as loafers, spent their days perched on empty dry-goods boxes, whittling wood with Barlow knives, chewing tobacco, and exhibiting general lethargy through yawning and stretching—a rather uncouth assembly.

These men typically wore wide-brimmed yellow straw hats but no coats or waistcoats, addressed each other by familiar names like Bill, Buck, Hank, Joe, and Andy, spoke in a slow, lazy drawl, and used a considerable amount of profanity.
Nearly every awning-post had a loafer leaning against it, usually with hands in pockets, except when retrieving tobacco or scratching.
Huck described their conversations, highlighting the frequent requests to borrow chewing tobacco, often accompanied by false claims about having just given away their last piece.
He detailed the ritual of sharing tobacco, where a borrower would gnaw off a piece from a plug, sometimes to the feigned dismay of the owner.
The town's streets and alleys were entirely composed of mud, deep and black in places, and universally present.

Hogs were ubiquitous, lounging and grunting throughout the town. A common sight was a muddy sow with her piglets leisurely occupying a walkway, forcing people to detour, while she appeared contentedly nursing her young.

This tranquility would often be broken by a loafer inciting a dog to chase the sow, leading to a chaotic pursuit that amused the onlookers, who would then resettle until the next diversion, such as a dog fight.
The narrator observed that nothing animated the loafers as much as a dog fight, unless it was a cruel prank like setting fire to a stray dog or tying a tin pan to its tail.
Some houses along the riverfront were precariously situated, leaning and appearing ready to collapse into the water due to erosion, though some were still inhabited despite the danger.
The town was in a constant state of retreat as the river relentlessly eroded its banks.

Then we went loafing around the town. The stores and houses was most all old shackly dried-up frame concerns that hadn’t ever been painted; they was set up three or four foot above ground on stilts, so as to be out of reach of the water when the river was overflowed. The houses had little gardens around them, but they didn’t seem to raise hardly anything in them but jimpson weeds, and sunflowers, and ash-piles, and old curled-up boots and shoes, and pieces of bottles, and rags, and played-out tin-ware. The fences was made of different kinds of boards, nailed on at different times; and they leaned every which-way, and had gates that didn’t generly have but one hinge—a leather one. Some of the fences had been whitewashed, some time or another, but the duke said it was in Clumbus’s time, like enough. There was generly hogs in the garden, and people driving them out.
All the stores was along one street. They had white domestic awnings in front, and the country people hitched their horses to the awning-posts. There was empty drygoods boxes under the awnings, and loafers roosting on them all day long, whittling them with their Barlow knives; and chawing tobacco, and gaping and yawning and stretching—a mighty ornery lot. They generly had on yellow straw hats most as wide as an umbrella, but didn’t wear no coats nor waistcoats, they called one another Bill, and Buck, and Hank, and Joe, and Andy, and talked lazy and drawly, and used considerable many cuss words. There was as many as one loafer leaning up against every awning-post, and he most always had his hands in his britches-pockets, except when he fetched them out to lend a chaw of tobacco or scratch. What a body was hearing amongst them all the time was:
“Gimme a chaw ’v tobacker, Hank.”
“Cain’t; I hain’t got but one chaw left. Ask Bill.”
Maybe Bill he gives him a chaw; maybe he lies and says he ain’t got none. Some of them kinds of loafers never has a cent in the world, nor a chaw of tobacco of their own. They get all their chawing by borrowing; they say to a fellow, “I wisht you’d len’ me a chaw, Jack, I jist this minute give Ben Thompson the last chaw I had”—which is a lie pretty much everytime; it don’t fool nobody but a stranger; but Jack ain’t no stranger, so he says:
“You give him a chaw, did you? So did your sister’s cat’s grandmother. You pay me back the chaws you’ve awready borry’d off’n me, Lafe Buckner, then I’ll loan you one or two ton of it, and won’t charge you no back intrust, nuther.”
“Well, I did pay you back some of it wunst.”
“Yes, you did—’bout six chaws. You borry’d store tobacker and paid back nigger-head.”
Store tobacco is flat black plug, but these fellows mostly chaws the natural leaf twisted. When they borrow a chaw they don’t generly cut it off with a knife, but set the plug in between their teeth, and gnaw with their teeth and tug at the plug with their hands till they get it in two; then sometimes the one that owns the tobacco looks mournful at it when it’s handed back, and says, sarcastic:
“Here, gimme the chaw, and you take the plug.”
All the streets and lanes was just mud; they warn’t nothing else but mud—mud as black as tar and nigh about a foot deep in some places, and two or three inches deep in all the places. The hogs loafed and grunted around everywheres. You’d see a muddy sow and a litter of pigs come lazying along the street and whollop herself right down in the way, where folks had to walk around her, and she’d stretch out and shut her eyes and wave her ears whilst the pigs was milking her, and look as happy as if she was on salary. And pretty soon you’d hear a loafer sing out, “Hi! so boy! sick him, Tige!” and away the sow would go, squealing most horrible, with a dog or two swinging to each ear, and three or four dozen more a-coming; and then you would see all the loafers get up and watch the thing out of sight, and laugh at the fun and look grateful for the noise. Then they’d settle back again till there was a dog fight. There couldn’t anything wake them up all over, and make them happy all over, like a dog fight—unless it might be putting turpentine on a stray dog and setting fire to him, or tying a tin pan to his tail and see him run himself to death.
On the river front some of the houses was sticking out over the bank, and they was bowed and bent, and about ready to tumble in. The people had moved out of them. The bank was caved away under one corner of some others, and that corner was hanging over. People lived in them yet, but it was dangersome, because sometimes a strip of land as wide as a house caves in at a time. Sometimes a belt of land a quarter of a mile deep will start in and cave along and cave along till it all caves into the river in one summer. Such a town as that has to be always moving back, and back, and back, because the river’s always gnawing at it.

The streets were dusty, and the sun beat down something fierce, but we didn’t mind none. Huck had a way of making even the dullest places seem like an adventure, and I reckon I was happy just to be alongside him, free as the river we’d left behind.

We passed by the general store first, where old man Higgins sat whittling on a stick, his eyes squinted up against the sun. He gave us a nod, and Huck tipped his hat like he was some fine gentleman instead of a boy with holes in his britches. The smell of pickles and tobacco hung thick in the air, and my stomach growled something awful, but Huck just grinned and said, "Ain’t no use thinkin’ on an empty belly, Tom. Let’s move along."

Down by the blacksmith’s, the clang of hammer on iron rang out like a church bell. Jim the blacksmith was shoeing a mule, sweat pouring off him like he was standing in a rainstorm. The mule didn’t take too kindly to the business and kicked up a fuss, but Jim just cussed under his breath and kept at it. Huck nudged me and whispered, "Reckon that mule’s got more sense than most folks in this town," and I had to stifle a laugh.

We wandered past the schoolhouse next, where the young’uns were reciting their lessons in that singsong way kids do. The windows were open, and the teacher’s voice carried out sharp and clear, drilling arithmetic into their heads like he was hammering nails. Huck made a face. "Glad I ain’t cooped up in there no more," he said. "Numbers never did me no good anyhow." I couldn’t argue with that. Huck had a head for figuring things out, but not the kind you find in books.

The town square was livelier, with folks milling about, swapping gossip and trading goods. A couple of old women in bonnets were haggling over a basket of eggs, their voices rising higher and higher till you’d think the sky was about to fall. A group of boys our age were playing mumblety-peg in the shade of the big oak, and one of ’em waved us over. Huck shook his head. "Nah, we got business elsewhere," he lied smooth as butter, and we kept walking.

Down by the riverbank, the air was cooler, and the smell of fish and wet earth filled my nose. A couple of fishermen were hauling in their nets, their faces brown and wrinkled from years of squinting into the sun. One of ’em nodded at Huck. "You boys best stay clear of the water today," he said. "River’s restless." Huck just shrugged and kicked a pebble into the shallows. "Ain’t nothin’ the river can do to me it ain’t already tried," he said, and I knew he meant it.

We found a spot under a willow tree and sat awhile, watching the water roll by. Huck chewed on a blade of grass, his eyes far off like he was seeing clear to the other side of the world. "You ever think about just keepin’ on goin’, Tom?" he asked sudden-like. "Just walkin’ and walkin’ till you find a place where nobody knows your name?" I thought about it. There was something mighty tempting in the idea, but then I reckoned Aunt Polly would skin me alive if I lit out for good. "Maybe someday," I said, and Huck just nodded, like he understood.

The sun was starting to dip low when we headed back into town, casting long shadows ahead of us. The lamplighter was making his rounds, and the first fireflies were blinking on like tiny stars. We passed by the jailhouse, where old Sheriff Turner was leaning against the porch rail, picking his teeth with a splinter of wood. He gave us a long look, but Huck met his gaze steady, and after a minute the sheriff just chuckled and shook his head. "You boys stay outta trouble now, hear?" he called after us, and Huck waved a hand like he was making no promises.

By the time we got to the edge of town, the stars were out proper, and the air had that soft, quiet feel that comes just before full dark. Huck stopped at the fork in the road where we’d have to part ways. "Reckon I’ll see you tomorrow?" he asked, though we both knew he would. "Reckon so," I said, and with that, he tipped his hat again and disappeared into the gathering night, just another shadow among shadows.

I stood there a minute longer, listening to the crickets and the distant murmur of the town settling down. Then I turned for home, feeling the weight of the day in my bones but lighter somehow, like Huck had carried half of it for me without my even noticing. That was just his way.

events.title: The Arrival of Drunken Boggs and His Threats Against Colonel Sherburn
detailed_summary: As midday approached, the town's streets became increasingly congested with wagons and horses, with a continuous influx of people.
Families arriving from the countryside ate their meals in their wagons, while considerable whisky consumption and at least three fights were observed by Huck.
Suddenly, someone announced the arrival of "old Boggs" from the country for his regular monthly drunken spree.

The loafers appeared pleased, evidently accustomed to deriving entertainment from Boggs's behavior. One remarked on Boggs's history of unfulfilled threats, while another joked that being threatened by Boggs was a guarantee of a long life.
Boggs then came riding wildly on his horse, shouting like a Native American and proclaiming that he was on the warpath and the price of coffins was about to rise.

He was clearly intoxicated, swaying in his saddle, over fifty years old, with a notably red face. The crowd shouted at him, laughed, and taunted him, and he responded in kind, stating he would deal with them later but first had to kill Colonel Sherburn, adhering to his motto of "Meat first, and spoon vittles to top off on."
Boggs noticed Huck, rode up to him, and asked if he was prepared to die, before continuing on his way.

Huck was frightened by the encounter, but a bystander reassured him that Boggs meant no harm, describing him as a habitually boisterous but ultimately harmless drunkard, the most good-natured old fool in Arkansas, who never injured anyone, whether drunk or sober.

“Wonder who he’s a-gwyne to chaw up this time. If he’d a-chawed up all the men he’s ben a-gwyne to chaw up in the last twenty year he’d have considerable ruputation now.”
Another one says, “I wisht old Boggs ’d threaten me, ’cuz then I’d know I warn’t gwyne to die for a thousan’ year.”
Boggs comes a-tearing along on his horse, whooping and yelling like an Injun, and singing out:
“Cler the track, thar. I’m on the waw-path, and the price uv coffins is a-gwyne to raise.”
He was drunk, and weaving about in his saddle; he was over fifty year old, and had a very red face. Everybody yelled at him and laughed at him and sassed him, and he sassed back, and said he’d attend to them and lay them out in their regular turns, but he couldn’t wait now because he’d come to town to kill old Colonel Sherburn, and his motto was, “Meat first, and spoon vittles to top off on.”
He see me, and rode up and says:
“Whar’d you come f’m, boy? You prepared to die?”
Then he rode on. I was scared, but a man says:
“He don’t mean nothing; he’s always a-carryin’ on like that when he’s drunk. He’s the best naturedest old fool in Arkansaw—never hurt nobody, drunk nor sober.”

events.title: Colonel Sherburn's Ultimatum and Boggs's Continued Defiance
detailed_summary: Boggs positioned himself in front of the town's most prominent store and, peering under the awning, loudly called for Sherburn to come out and face him, accusing Sherburn of swindling him and declaring his intent to get him.
He continued to hurl every insult he could think of at Sherburn, while the street filled with people who listened, laughed, and commented on the spectacle.
After some time, a distinguished-looking man of about fifty-five, who was also the best-dressed individual in town, stepped out of the store. The crowd instinctively fell back to allow him passage.

This man, Colonel Sherburn, addressed Boggs in a very calm and deliberate manner, stating that he was tired of Boggs's behavior but would tolerate it until one o'clock, and no later. He warned Boggs that if he uttered even one more word against him after that time, Sherburn would find him, no matter how far he traveled.
Sherburn then turned and went back into the store. The crowd became very subdued; no one moved, and the laughter ceased.

Boggs, however, rode off, continuing to revile Sherburn as loudly as he could yell, all the way down the street. Shortly after, he returned and stopped before the store, resuming his abusive shouting.
Some men gathered around Boggs, attempting to persuade him to be quiet, and told him it would be one o'clock in about fifteen minutes, urging him to go home immediately. Their efforts were futile.
Boggs persisted in his cursing with all his might, threw his hat into the mud, rode his horse over it, and then galloped off down the street again in a rage, his gray hair flying.
Everyone who could get near him tried to coax him off his horse so they could detain him and let him sober up, but to no avail—he would tear up the street again to hurl more curses at Sherburn.
Eventually, someone suggested fetching Boggs's daughter, reasoning that she sometimes had influence over him and might be able to persuade him if anyone could.
Following this suggestion, someone set off running to find her.

“Come out here, Sherburn! Come out and meet the man you’ve swindled. You’re the houn’ I’m after, and I’m a-gwyne to have you, too!”

He says to Boggs, mighty ca’m and slow—he says:
“I’m tired of this, but I’ll endure it till one o’clock. Till one o’clock, mind—no longer. If you open your mouth against me only once after that time you can’t travel so far but I will find you.”
Then he turns and goes in. The crowd looked mighty sober; nobody stirred, and there warn’t no more laughing. Boggs rode off blackguarding Sherburn as loud as he could yell, all down the street; and pretty soon back he comes and stops before the store, still keeping it up. Some men crowded around him and tried to get him to shut up, but he wouldn’t; they told him it would be one o’clock in about fifteen minutes, and so he must go home—he must go right away. But it didn’t do no good. He cussed away with all his might, and throwed his hat down in the mud and rode over it, and pretty soon away he went a-raging down the street again, with his gray hair a-flying. Everybody that could get a chance at him tried their best to coax him off of his horse so they could lock him up and get him sober; but it warn’t no use—up the street he would tear again, and give Sherburn another cussing. By-and-by somebody says:
“Go for his daughter!—quick, go for his daughter; sometimes he’ll listen to her. If anybody can persuade him, she can.”
So somebody started on a run.

events.title: Boggs's Death, the Town's Morbid Curiosity, and the Call for Lynching Sherburn
detailed_summary: Boggs was transported to a small drugstore, with the crowd maintaining its tight formation around him and the entire town trailing behind. Huck managed to secure a prime viewing spot at the window, close enough to see everything inside.

Inside the drugstore, Boggs was laid on the floor. A large Bible was placed under his head, and another was opened and spread across his chest, but only after his shirt was torn open, revealing to Huck the entry point of one of the bullets.
Boggs took about a dozen deep, gasping breaths, his chest rising and falling with the Bible, before he became still; he was dead.

His daughter, screaming and crying, was then pulled away from his body and taken off. She was described as about sixteen years old, with a sweet and gentle appearance, though terribly pale and frightened.

Soon, the entire town seemed to have gathered, squirming and pushing to get to the window for a look, while those already occupying the vantage points refused to yield them. People in the back complained about the unfairness of others monopolizing the view.
Amidst considerable bickering, Huck decided to leave, anticipating potential trouble.
The streets were packed with excited people. Everyone who had witnessed the shooting was recounting the details, surrounded by large, attentive crowds craning their necks to listen.

One particularly notable figure, a tall, lanky man with long hair, a large white fur stovepipe hat worn on the back of his head, and a crooked-handled cane, demonstrated the sequence of events. He marked the spots on the ground where Boggs and Sherburn had stood, and the crowd followed him from place to place, observing his every move, nodding to show their understanding, and stooping to watch him mark the locations with his cane.

This man then stood straight and stiff where Sherburn had been, frowning with his hat brim pulled low over his eyes, shouted "Boggs!", then slowly brought his cane down to a level as if aiming, said "Bang!", staggered backward, said "Bang!" again, and fell flat on his back.
Those who had seen the actual shooting declared his reenactment perfect, stating it was exactly how it had all occurred. Afterward, as many as a dozen people offered him drinks from their bottles.
After a while, someone suggested that Colonel Sherburn should be lynched.
Within about a minute, this sentiment was echoed by everyone, and the crowd, now enraged and shouting, set off, tearing down every clothesline they encountered to use for the hanging.

events.text_segment:
They took Boggs to a little drug store, the crowd pressing around just the same, and the whole town following, and I rushed and got a good place at the window, where I was close to him and could see in. They laid him on the floor and put one large Bible under his head, and opened another one and spread it on his breast; but they tore open his shirt first, and I seen where one of the bullets went in. He made about a dozen long gasps, his breast lifting the Bible up when he drawed in his breath, and letting it down again when he breathed it out—and after that he laid still; he was dead. Then they pulled his daughter away from him, screaming and crying, and took her off. She was about sixteen, and very sweet and gentle-looking, but awful pale and scared.
Well, pretty soon the whole town was there, squirming and scrouging and pushing and shoving to get at the window and have a look, but people that had the places wouldn’t give them up, and folks behind them was saying all the time, “Say, now, you’ve looked enough, you fellows; ’tain’t right and ’tain’t fair for you to stay thar all the time, and never give nobody a chance; other folks has their rights as well as you.”
There was considerable jawing back, so I slid out, thinking maybe there was going to be trouble. The streets was full, and everybody was excited. Everybody that seen the shooting was telling how it happened, and there was a big crowd packed around each one of these fellows, stretching their necks and listening. One long, lanky man, with long hair and a big white fur stovepipe hat on the back of his head, and a crooked-handled cane, marked out the places on the ground where Boggs stood and where Sherburn stood, and the people following him around from one place to t’other and watching everything he done, and bobbing their heads to show they understood, and stooping a little and resting their hands on their thighs to watch him mark the places on the ground with his cane; and then he stood up straight and stiff where Sherburn had stood, frowning and having his hat-brim down over his eyes, and sung out, “Boggs!” and then fetched his cane down slow to a level, and says “Bang!” staggered backwards, says “Bang!” again, and fell down flat on his back. The people that had seen the thing said he done it perfect; said it was just exactly the way it all happened. Then as much as a dozen people got out their bottles and treated him.
Well, by-and-by somebody said Sherburn ought to be lynched. In about a minute everybody was saying it; so away they went, mad and yelling, and snatching down every clothes-line they come to, to do the hanging with.

events.title: Sherburn's Scathing Rebuke of the Mob's Cowardice
detailed_summary: Sherburn remained silent, his steady gaze sweeping across the crowd, making individuals uncomfortable and avoid eye contact.

He mocked their presumption to lynch anyone, especially a man, contrasting it with their bravery in tarring and feathering vulnerable women.
Sherburn asserted that a true man would be safe from thousands of their kind in daylight, as long as he wasn't attacked from behind.
He claimed a thorough understanding of their character, based on his experiences in both the South and North, concluding that the average person is a coward.

He elaborated on regional cowardice: Northerners passively endure mistreatment, while Southerners commit acts like stagecoach robberies or form lynch mobs for jury-acquitted murderers due to fear of reprisal.
He chided the mob for not adhering to the 'proper' method of lynching—at night, masked, and led by a 'man'—identifying Buck Harkness as merely 'part of a man' who initiated their current folly.
He accused them of lacking genuine desire for confrontation, stating they joined out of fear of being exposed as cowards if they didn't follow an instigator like Harkness.
He described a mob as pitiful, its courage borrowed from the group and its leaders, and a mob without a true leader as even more contemptible.
He ordered them to leave with their 'half-a-man,' emphasizing that any genuine lynching would be done in the dark, Southern style, with masks and a proper leader, while cocking his gun.

Sherburn never said a word—just stood there, looking down. The crowd grew restless, shifting and murmuring like a pack of wolves waiting for their leader to strike. I could feel the tension in the air, thick as molasses on a hot summer day. My heart pounded so loud I reckoned folks could hear it clear across the square.  

Then, slow as molasses in January, Sherburn raised his head. His eyes were cold, like two chips of ice, and they swept over the mob like he was sizing up a herd of cattle. The silence stretched so long I thought my ears might burst from the weight of it.  

Finally, he spoke, his voice quiet but sharp as a razor.  

"You call yourselves men?" he said. "Look at you—a pack of cowards, hiding behind each other like sheep. You think you can scare me? You think I don’t know every last one of you? I do. And I know not a single one of you has the grit to stand up alone."  

The crowd shuffled, uneasy. Some of the men looked at their boots, others at the sky—anywhere but at Sherburn.  

"You talk big when you’re in a crowd," Sherburn went on, his voice dripping with contempt. "But if I stepped down there right now, not one of you would lift a finger. Because deep down, you’re all yellow. Every last one."  

A few muttered protests rose up, but they died quick as they came. Sherburn didn’t even blink.  

"You want to hang me?" he said, almost laughing. "Then do it. But you won’t. Because you’re afraid. Afraid of me, afraid of each other, afraid of what happens when the law comes knocking. So go on home. Play at being brave some other day."  

And just like that, the spell broke. The crowd started to melt away, men slinking off like dogs with their tails between their legs. I couldn’t believe it. A whole mob, cowed by one man’s words.  

Huck Finn, standing beside me, let out a low whistle. "Dang," he muttered. "Ain’t never seen nothin’ like that before."  

I shook my head. Neither had I.  

Sherburn watched them go, his face as still as stone. Then, without another word, he turned and walked back into his house, shutting the door behind him like it was just any other day.  

The square was empty now, save for a few stragglers and the dust settling back into the dirt. The whole thing had lasted maybe five minutes, but it felt like a lifetime.  

Huck nudged me. "Reckon we oughta skedaddle too?"  

I nodded. "Yeah. Ain’t nothin’ left to see here."  

As we walked away, I couldn’t help but think about what had just happened. Sherburn had faced down a lynch mob with nothing but words—and won. It made me wonder about courage, about what it really meant to be brave.

detailed_summary: Huck found the circus to be exceptionally entertaining and magnificent.

Eventually, all performers released their reins; the ladies placed their hands on their hips, and the gentlemen folded their arms, as the horses continued their spirited movements.

It was a real bully circus. It was the splendidest sight that ever was when they all come riding in, two and two, a gentleman and lady, side by side, the men just in their drawers and undershirts, and no shoes nor stirrups, and resting their hands on their thighs easy and comfortable—there must a been twenty of them—and every lady with a lovely complexion, and perfectly beautiful, and looking just like a gang of real sure-enough queens, and dressed in clothes that cost millions of dollars, and just littered with diamonds. It was a powerful fine sight; I never see anything so lovely. And then one by one they got up and stood, and went a-weaving around the ring so gentle and wavy and graceful, the men looking ever so tall and airy and straight, with their heads bobbing and skimming along, away up there under the tent-roof, and every lady’s rose-leafy dress flapping soft and silky around her hips, and she looking like the most loveliest parasol.
And then faster and faster they went, all of them dancing, first one foot out in the air and then the other, the horses leaning more and more, and the ring-master going round and round the center-pole, cracking his whip and shouting “Hi!—hi!” and the clown cracking jokes behind him; and by-and-by all hands dropped the reins, and every lady put her knuckles on her hips and every gentleman folded his arms, and then how the horses did lean over and hump themselves! And so one after the other they all skipped off into the ring, and made the sweetest bow I ever see, and then scampered out, and everybody clapped their hands and went just about wild.

Then, to everyone's surprise, the 'drunk' man skillfully regained his balance, stood up on the moving horse, and began removing layers of clothing.
He shed a total of seventeen outfits, revealing himself to be a slim, handsome performer in a dazzling costume.
He then expertly controlled the horse, performed impressively, made a bow, and danced off to the dressing room, leaving the audience howling with pleasure and astonishment.
The ring-master realized he had been tricked by one of his own performers who had orchestrated the entire prank, making him look foolish.

Well, all through the circus they done the most astonishing things; and all the time that clown carried on so it most killed the people. The ring-master couldn’t ever say a word to him but he was back at him quick as a wink with the funniest things a body ever said; and how he ever could think of so many of them, and so sudden and so pat, was what I couldn’t noway understand. Why, I couldn’t a thought of them in a year. And by-and-by a drunk man tried to get into the ring—said he wanted to ride; said he could ride as well as anybody that ever was. They argued and tried to keep him out, but he wouldn’t listen, and the whole show come to a standstill. Then the people begun to holler at him and make fun of him, and that made him mad, and he begun to rip and tear; so that stirred up the people, and a lot of men begun to pile down off of the benches and swarm towards the ring, saying, “Knock him down! throw him out!” and one or two women begun to scream. So, then, the ring-master he made a little speech, and said he hoped there wouldn’t be no disturbance, and if the man would promise he wouldn’t make no more trouble he would let him ride if he thought he could stay on the horse. So everybody laughed and said all right, and the man got on. The minute he was on, the horse begun to rip and tear and jump and cavort around, with two circus men hanging on to his bridle trying to hold him, and the drunk man hanging on to his neck, and his heels flying in the air every jump, and the whole crowd of people standing up shouting and laughing till tears rolled down. And at last, sure enough, all the circus men could do, the horse broke loose, and away he went like the very nation, round and round the ring, with that sot laying down on him and hanging to his neck, with first one leg hanging most to the ground on one side, and then t’other one on t’other side, and the people just crazy. It warn’t funny to me, though; I was all of a tremble to see his danger. But pretty soon he struggled up astraddle and grabbed the bridle, a-reeling this way and that; and the next minute he sprung up and dropped the bridle and stood! and the horse a-going like a house afire too. Well, all day him and the king was hard at it, rigging up a stage and a curtain and a row of candles for footlights; and that night the house was jam full of men in no time. When the place couldn’t hold no more, the duke he quit tending door and went around the back way and come on to the stage and stood up before the curtain and made a little speech, and praised up this tragedy, and said it was the most thrillingest one that ever was; and so he went on a-bragging about the tragedy, and about Edmund Kean the Elder, which was to play the main principal part in it; and at last when he’d got everybody’s expectations up high enough, he rolled up the curtain, and the next minute the king come a-prancing out on all fours, naked; and he was painted all over, ring-streaked-and-striped, all sorts of colors, as splendid as a rainbow. And—but never mind the rest of his outfit; it was just wild, but it was awful funny. The people most killed themselves laughing; and when the king got done capering and capered off behind the scenes, they roared and clapped and stormed and haw-hawed till he come back and done it over again, and after that they made him do it another time. Well, it would make a cow laugh to see the shines that old idiot cut.
Then the duke he lets the curtain down, and bows to the people, and says the great tragedy will be performed only two nights more, on accounts of pressing London engagements, where the seats is all sold already for it in Drury Lane; and then he makes them another bow, and says if he has succeeded in pleasing them and instructing them, he will be deeply obleeged if they will mention it to their friends and get them to come and see it.
Twenty people sings out:
“What, is it over? Is that all?”
The duke says yes. Then there was a fine time. Everybody sings out, “Sold!” and rose up mad, and was a-going for that stage and them tragedians. But a big, fine looking man jumps up on a bench and shouts:
“Hold on! Just a word, gentlemen.” They stopped to listen. “We are sold—mighty badly sold. But we don’t want to be the laughing stock of this whole town, I reckon, and never hear the last of this thing as long as we live. No. What we want is to go out of here quiet, and talk this show up, and sell the rest of the town! Then we’ll all be in the same boat. Ain’t that sensible?” (“You bet it is!—the jedge is right!” everybody sings out.) “All right, then—not a word about any sell. Go along home, and advise everybody to come and see the tragedy.”

The third night the house was crammed again—and they warn’t new-comers this time, but people that was at the show the other two nights. I stood by the duke at the door, and I see that every man that went in had his pockets bulging, or something muffled up under his coat—and I see it warn’t no perfumery, neither, not by a long sight. I smelt sickly eggs by the barrel, and rotten cabbages, and such things; and if I know the signs of a dead cat being around, and I bet I do, there was sixty-four of them went in. I shoved in there for a minute, but it was too various for me; I couldn’t stand it. Well, when the place couldn’t hold no more people the duke he give a fellow a quarter and told him to tend door for him a minute, and then he started around for the stage door, I after him; but the minute we turned the corner and was in the dark he says:
“Walk fast now till you get away from the houses, and then shin for the raft like the dickens was after you!”
I done it, and he done the same. We struck the raft at the same time, and in less than two seconds we was gliding down stream, all dark and still, and edging towards the middle of the river, nobody saying a word. I reckoned the poor king was in for a gaudy time of it with the audience, but nothing of the sort; pretty soon he crawls out from under the wigwam, and says:
“Well, how’d the old thing pan out this time, duke?”
He hadn’t been up town at all.

He humorously speculated on how the townspeople were now 'enjoying' their opportunity for payback with the rotten provisions they had brought.
The narrator reveals that the conmen had amassed a total of four hundred and sixty-five dollars from their three-night theatrical scam, a sum that astonished Huck.
Later, after the King and Duke had fallen asleep, Jim expressed his bewilderment to Huck regarding the uncouth behavior of these self-proclaimed 'kings'.
Huck responded that their actions were not surprising to him, as he believed such conduct was inherent to all royalty.
Jim contended that their companions were merely common swindlers, not actual kings.
Huck, however, maintained his cynical view, asserting that, based on his understanding, most kings were essentially rapscallions.

To illustrate his point, Huck launched into a comically inaccurate and anachronistic diatribe about various historical monarchs, portraying all of them, especially Henry VIII, as villains of the highest order, conflating figures, events, and timelines.
He concluded that their current 'king' was comparatively mild and that one simply had to make allowances for kings, whom he described as a 'mighty ornery lot' due to their upbringing.
Jim then remarked on the unpleasant body odor of their 'king'.
Huck philosophized that all kings likely smelled bad and that history offered no remedies for such a royal trait.
Jim acknowledged that the Duke was perhaps slightly more tolerable in some respects.
Huck concurred that a duke was different, but not significantly so, deeming their Duke a rather poor specimen, particularly when inebriated.
Jim declared he had had enough of both 'kings' and 'dukes'.
Huck shared Jim's exhaustion but pragmatically noted they were stuck with the conmen and needed to remember their true nature and tolerate them, wistfully wishing for a country devoid of kings.

Huck reflected internally on the futility of revealing to Jim that the King and Duke were frauds, believing it would serve no purpose and that their behavior was, in his eyes, indistinguishable from that of genuine royalty.

“But, Huck, dese kings o’ ourn is reglar rapscallions; dat’s jist what dey is; dey’s reglar rapscallions.”
“Well, that’s what I’m a-saying; all kings is mostly rapscallions, as fur as I can make out.”
“Is dat so?”
“You read about them once—you’ll see. Look at Henry the Eight; this’n ’s a Sunday-school Superintendent to him. And look at Charles Second, and Louis Fourteen, and Louis Fifteen, and James Second, and Edward Second, and Richard Third, and forty more; besides all them Saxon heptarchies that used to rip around so in old times and raise Cain. My, you ought to seen old Henry the Eight when he was in bloom. He was a blossom. He used to marry a new wife every day, and chop off her head next morning. And he would do it just as indifferent as if he was ordering up eggs. ‘Fetch up Nell Gwynn,’ he says. They fetch her up. Next morning, ‘Chop off her head!’ And they chop it off. ‘Fetch up Jane Shore,’ he says; and up she comes, Next morning, ‘Chop off her head’—and they chop it off. ‘Ring up Fair Rosamun.’ Fair Rosamun answers the bell. Next morning, ‘Chop off her head.’ And he made every one of them tell him a tale every night; and he kept that up till he had hogged a thousand and one tales that way, and then he put them all in a book, and called it Domesday Book—which was a good name and stated the case. You don’t know kings, Jim, but I know them; and this old rip of ourn is one of the cleanest I’ve struck in history. Well, Henry he takes a notion he wants to get up some trouble with this country. How does he go at it—give notice?—give the country a show? No. All of a sudden he heaves all the tea in Boston Harbor overboard, and whacks out a declaration of independence, and dares them to come on. That was his style—he never give anybody a chance. He had suspicions of his father, the Duke of Wellington. Well, what did he do? Ask him to show up? No—drownded him in a butt of mamsey, like a cat. S’pose people left money laying around where he was—what did he do? He collared it. S’pose he contracted to do a thing, and you paid him, and didn’t set down there and see that he done it—what did he do? He always done the other thing. S’pose he opened his mouth—what then? If he didn’t shut it up powerful quick he’d lose a lie every time. That’s the kind of a bug Henry was; and if we’d a had him along ’stead of our kings he’d a fooled that town a heap worse than ourn done. I don’t say that ourn is lambs, because they ain’t, when you come right down to the cold facts; but they ain’t nothing to that old ram, anyway. All I say is, kings is kings, and you got to make allowances. Take them all around, they’re a mighty ornery lot. It’s the way they’re raised.”
“But dis one do smell so like de nation, Huck.”
“Well, they all do, Jim. We can’t help the way a king smells; history don’t tell no way.”
“Now de duke, he’s a tolerble likely man in some ways.”
“Yes, a duke’s different. But not very different. This one’s a middling hard lot for a duke. When he’s drunk, there ain’t no near-sighted man could tell him from a king.”
“Well, anyways, I doan’ hanker for no mo’ un um, Huck. Dese is all I kin stan’.”

What was the use to tell Jim these warn’t real kings and dukes? It wouldn’t a done no good; and, besides, it was just as I said: you couldn’t tell them from the real kind.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
We never showed a light till we was about ten mile below the village. Then we lit a lantern and hung it up in the raft, just to let folks know we was there, in case any steamboat or trading scow come along. The river was mighty wide and dark, and the stars shone down like a million little candles. The air was cool and fresh, and the water lapped soft against the raft, like it was whispering secrets to us.

Huck and me sat quiet for a long time, just listening to the night sounds—the frogs croaking, the crickets chirping, and now and then the splash of a fish jumping out of the water. It was peaceful, but I couldn’t shake the feeling that trouble wasn’t far behind us. I kept thinking about Pap and how he’d come after me if he ever found out I’d run off. And then there was Jim—if anybody caught him, they’d drag him back to Miss Watson sure as shooting.

Jim must’ve been thinking the same thing, ‘cause after a while he says, “Huck, you reckon we safe now?”  

I scratched my head and looked back upriver, though there wasn’t nothing to see but blackness. “Reckon so,” I says. “Ain’t nobody likely to follow us this far, ‘less they got wings.”  

Jim nodded, but he didn’t look too convinced. “I hopes you right, Huck. I surely do.”  

We let the raft drift with the current, not bothering with the oars much. The river knew where it was going, and we was content to let it carry us. After a spell, Jim got out his pipe and lit it, the tobacco smell mixing with the damp night air. He offered me a puff, but I shook my head. I never did take to smoking much, though Pap was always at it, drunk or sober.  

“You ever think ‘bout what’s downriver, Huck?” Jim asked after a while.  

I shrugged. “Ain’t thought much on it. Reckon we’ll find out when we get there.”  

Jim chuckled low. “That’s the truth, sure enough. But I gots me a dream, Huck. I dreams ‘bout gettin’ to the free states, workin’ hard, savin’ up money, and buyin’ my wife and children out of slavery. That’s what keeps me goin’.”  

I never heard Jim talk like that before, and it struck me deep. Here I was, just running away from Pap and school and all them rules, but Jim—he was running toward something. Something real and good.  

“You’ll do it, Jim,” I says, though I didn’t know if it was true. But it felt right to say it.  

Jim smiled in the lantern light. “I ‘preciate that, Huck. I surely do.”  

We fell quiet again, listening to the river and the night. After a while, I stretched out on the raft, using my coat for a pillow. The planks was hard, but I was so tired I didn’t much care. Jim stayed sitting up, keeping watch, his pipe glowing now and then like a firefly.  

Just as I was drifting off, I heard a sound that made my skin prickle—a low, steady chugging noise, far off but getting closer. I sat up quick. “Jim, you hear that?”  

Jim’s eyes was wide. “Steamboat,” he whispered.  

We both scrambled to douse the lantern, plunging us into darkness again. The sound grew louder, and pretty soon we could see the steamboat’s lights coming around the bend, big and bright like a floating house. It was heading straight down the middle of the river, and we was right in its path.  

“Grab the oars!” I hissed.  

Jim didn’t need telling twice. We both seized the oars and started paddling like mad, trying to steer the raft toward the shore. The steamboat’s whistle blew, loud and sudden, making my heart jump clean into my throat. The water churned white as the big wheel churned past, missing us by no more than a few feet. The wake rocked the raft hard, nearly tossing us overboard.  

When the steamboat was gone and the river was quiet again, Jim and me just looked at each other, breathing heavy.  

“That was too close,” Jim said.  

I nodded. “We best keep the lantern out from now on, lessen we want to get run down.”  

Jim agreed, and we settled back down, though neither of us felt much like sleeping now. The near miss had put us both on edge, and every little noise made us jump.  

After a while, Jim said, “Huck, you ever think the world’s tryin’ to tell us somethin’?”  

I frowned. “Like what?”  

“Like maybe this ain’t the way we s’posed to go.”  

I thought about that. The river was taking us south, deeper into slave country, not north toward the free states like Jim wanted. Maybe the steamboat was a sign—or maybe it was just bad luck.  

“I dunno, Jim,” I says at last. “But we’ll figure it out. We always do.”  

Jim didn’t answer, but I could tell he was still worrying. I reckoned I’d be worrying too, if I was in his place.  

The night wore on, and finally, exhaustion got the better of us. We took turns sleeping, one of us always keeping watch. The river kept moving, carrying us further away from St. Petersburg, further into the unknown.  

And that’s just how we wanted it.

events.title: Jim's Profound Grief and the Heartbreaking Story of His Daughter 'Lizabeth's Deafness
detailed_summary: Huck went to sleep, and Jim, in a common act of kindness, allowed him to sleep through his scheduled watch.
Upon waking at daybreak, Huck discovered Jim sitting with his head bowed between his knees, audibly moaning and expressing deep sorrow.
Huck intuitively understood that Jim was overwhelmed with homesickness and grief for his wife and children, from whom he had never before been separated.

Huck reflected on Jim's profound affection for his family, believing it to be as strong as that of white individuals for their own kin—a realization he found somewhat unnatural by societal standards, yet accepted as true.

He noted that Jim often mourned this way during the night when he presumed Huck was asleep, lamenting for his 'Po’ little ’Lizabeth' and 'po’ little Johnny,' and voicing his fear of never seeing them again. Huck privately acknowledged Jim as a 'mighty good nigger'.
On this particular morning, Huck initiated a conversation with Jim about his family.

Jim explained that his acute sadness was triggered by a sound he had heard from the riverbank, which vividly reminded him of an incident where he had treated his young daughter, ’Lizabeth, with unintentional cruelty.
He recounted that ’Lizabeth, who was only about four years old at the time, had endured a severe illness, scarlet fever.
Sometime after her recovery, Jim had instructed her to close a door. When she didn’t comply, merely smiling up at him, he became irritated.
He repeated his command more forcefully, but she remained unresponsive, still smiling.
Consumed by anger, Jim struck her forcefully on the side of her head, causing her to fall.
He then left the room for approximately ten minutes. Upon his return, he found the door still ajar and ’Lizabeth standing near it, looking down and crying silently.
As he was about to confront her again, a sudden gust of wind slammed the inward-opening door shut with a loud 'ker-blam!' right behind the child.
To Jim's profound shock, ’Lizabeth did not react in any way to the loud noise.
This lack of response deeply unsettled Jim. Overcome with a strange feeling, he cautiously crept around, quietly opened the door, and positioned himself behind her.
He then suddenly shouted 'pow!' as loudly as he possibly could, directly behind her head.
When ’Lizabeth still showed no reaction, the devastating truth dawned on Jim. He burst into tears, embraced her, and cried out for the Lord's forgiveness, knowing he could never forgive himself.
He then revealed to Huck, with immense sorrow, that his little daughter was completely deaf and dumb, and he had tragically mistreated her without understanding her condition.

I went to sleep, and Jim didn’t call me when it was my turn. He often done that. When I waked up just at daybreak, he was sitting there with his head down betwixt his knees, moaning and mourning to himself. I didn’t take notice nor let on. I knowed what it was about. He was thinking about his wife and his children, away up yonder, and he was low and homesick; because he hadn’t ever been away from home before in his life; and I do believe he cared just as much for his people as white folks does for their’n. It don’t seem natural, but I reckon it’s so. He was often moaning and mourning that way nights, when he judged I was asleep, and saying, “Po’ little ’Lizabeth! po’ little Johnny! it’s mighty hard; I spec’ I ain’t ever gwyne to see you no mo’, no mo’!” He was a mighty good nigger, Jim was.
But this time I somehow got to talking to him about his wife and young ones; and by-and-by he says:
“What makes me feel so bad dis time ’uz bekase I hear sumpn over yonder on de bank like a whack, er a slam, while ago, en it mine me er de time I treat my little ’Lizabeth so ornery. She warn’t on’y ’bout fo’ year ole, en she tuck de sk’yarlet fever, en had a powful rough spell; but she got well, en one day she was a-stannin’ aroun’, en I says to her, I says:
“‘Shet de do’.’
“She never done it; jis’ stood dah, kiner smilin’ up at me. It make me mad; en I says agin, mighty loud, I says:
“‘Doan’ you hear me?—shet de do’!’
“She jis stood de same way, kiner smilin’ up. I was a-bilin’! I says:
“‘I lay I make you mine!’
“En wid dat I fetch’ her a slap side de head dat sont her a-sprawlin’. Den I went into de yuther room, en ’uz gone ’bout ten minutes; en when I come back dah was dat do’ a-stannin’ open yit, en dat chile stannin’ mos’ right in it, a-lookin’ down and mournin’, en de tears runnin’ down. My, but I wuz mad! I was a-gwyne for de chile, but jis’ den—it was a do’ dat open innerds—jis’ den, ’long come de wind en slam it to, behine de chile, ker-blam!—en my lan’, de chile never move’! My breff mos’ hop outer me; en I feel so—so—I doan’ know how I feel. I crope out, all a-tremblin’, en crope aroun’ en open de do’ easy en slow, en poke my head in behine de chile, sof’ en still, en all uv a sudden I says pow! jis’ as loud as I could yell. She never budge! Oh, Huck, I bust out a-cryin’ en grab her up in my arms, en say, ‘Oh, de po’ little thing! De Lord God Amighty fogive po’ ole Jim, kaze he never gwyne to fogive hisself as long’s he live!’ Oh, she was plumb deef en dumb, Huck, plumb deef en dumb—en I’d ben a-treat’n her so!”

I went to sleep, and Jim didn’t call me when it was my turn. When I woke up, the sun was already high in the sky, and the river was glistening like a sheet of gold. Jim was sitting by the fire, stirring a pot of coffee, his face tired but kind.

events.title: Jim's "Sick Arab" Disguise
detailed_summary: The duke and the king began strategizing to exploit the two nearby towns.
Jim voiced his discomfort about being tied up in the wigwam all day, a necessary precaution to maintain his facade as a runaway slave if discovered alone.
The duke, described as exceptionally intelligent, quickly conceived a plan to alleviate Jim's situation.
He dressed Jim in a King Lear costume, consisting of a long calico gown, a white horse-hair wig, and whiskers.
The duke then used theater paint to color Jim's face, hands, ears, and neck a deathly, solid blue, making him resemble a man who had been drowned for nine days.
Huck found Jim's transformed appearance to be the most horrifying sight he had ever witnessed.
To complete the ruse, the duke wrote a sign on a shingle stating, "Sick Arab—but harmless when not out of his head," and placed it in front of the wigwam.
Jim expressed satisfaction with this arrangement, finding it far preferable to being tied up daily and constantly on edge.
The duke instructed Jim to act freely but, if anyone approached, to jump out of the wigwam, behave erratically, and howl like a wild animal, expecting this to frighten people away.
Huck mused that Jim's ghastly appearance alone would likely be sufficient to deter anyone, even before any howling.

events.text_segment:
Next day, towards night, we laid up under a little willow tow-head out in the middle, where there was a village on each side of the river, and the duke and the king begun to lay out a plan for working them towns. Jim he spoke to the duke, and said he hoped it wouldn’t take but a few hours, because it got mighty heavy and tiresome to him when he had to lay all day in the wigwam tied with the rope. You see, when we left him all alone we had to tie him, because if anybody happened on to him all by himself and not tied it wouldn’t look much like he was a runaway nigger, you know. So the duke said it was kind of hard to have to lay roped all day, and he’d cipher out some way to get around it.
He was uncommon bright, the duke was, and he soon struck it. He dressed Jim up in King Lear’s outfit—it was a long curtain-calico gown, and a white horse-hair wig and whiskers; and then he took his theater paint and painted Jim’s face and hands and ears and neck all over a dead, dull, solid blue, like a man that’s been drownded nine days. Blamed if he warn’t the horriblest looking outrage I ever see. Then the duke took and wrote out a sign on a shingle so:
Sick Arab—but harmless when not out of his head.
And he nailed that shingle to a lath, and stood the lath up four or five foot in front of the wigwam. Jim was satisfied. He said it was a sight better than lying tied a couple of years every day, and trembling all over every time there was a sound. The duke told him to make himself free and easy, and if anybody ever come meddling around, he must hop out of the wigwam, and carry on a little, and fetch a howl or two like a wild beast, and he reckoned they would light out and leave him alone. Which was sound enough judgment; but you take the average man, and he wouldn’t wait for him to howl. Why, he didn’t only look like he was dead, he looked considerable more than that.

The duke, he scratched his head and said, “We got to be mighty careful here, your majesty. These folks ain’t seen us before, and we got to make a grand entrance.”  

The king, he puffed out his chest and smoothed down his greasy coat. “Why, of course, my noble companion. A royal performance demands royal preparation. I propose we present ourselves as the celebrated tragedians, direct from the London stage!”  

The duke frowned. “No, no, that won’t do. These folks ain’t likely to swallow that. Better we go as reformed pirates, turned missionaries, seeking to save souls and collect donations for our holy cause.”

By morning, they’d settled on their plan. The king would preach a revival, and the duke would pass the hat, claiming it was for the “conversion of the heathen.” Then, under cover of night, they’d slip away before anyone caught on.

events.title: New Scams Considered and a River Encounter
detailed_summary: The con men contemplated repeating their lucrative "Nonesuch" performance but decided against it, fearing word of their previous scam might have spread.
Failing to settle on a suitable new project, the duke resolved to spend some time devising a plan for the Arkansas village.
The king, conversely, decided to go to the other village without a specific plan, trusting in what Huck sardonically calls "Providence" (implying the devil) to lead him to profit.
Having recently purchased new outfits, the king donned his and instructed Huck to do the same.
The king's new black attire strikingly transformed his appearance from that of a disreputable vagrant to a man of apparent dignity and piety, leading Huck to marvel at the effect of clothing.

While Jim readied the canoe, the king, citing his respectable new look, proposed they arrive at the village via a steamboat, ostensibly coming from a larger city like St. Louis or Cincinnati, to create a more impressive entrance.
Huck, enthusiastic about a steamboat ride, paddled towards the vessel located about three miles upriver.
Along the way, they observed a young, seemingly naive country fellow sitting on a log, wiping sweat due to the intense heat, with two large carpet-bags next to him.

events.text_segment:
These rapscallions wanted to try the Nonesuch again, because there was so much money in it, but they judged it wouldn’t be safe, because maybe the news might a worked along down by this time. They couldn’t hit no project that suited exactly; so at last the duke said he reckoned he’d lay off and work his brains an hour or two and see if he couldn’t put up something on the Arkansaw village; and the king he allowed he would drop over to t’other village without any plan, but just trust in Providence to lead him the profitable way—meaning the devil, I reckon. We had all bought store clothes where we stopped last; and now the king put his’n on, and he told me to put mine on. I done it, of course. The king’s duds was all black, and he did look real swell and starchy. I never knowed how clothes could change a body before. Why, before, he looked like the orneriest old rip that ever was; but now, when he’d take off his new white beaver and make a bow and do a smile, he looked that grand and good and pious that you’d say he had walked right out of the ark, and maybe was old Leviticus himself. Jim cleaned up the canoe, and I got my paddle ready. There was a big steamboat laying at the shore away up under the point, about three mile above the town—been there a couple of hours, taking on freight. Says the king:
“Seein’ how I’m dressed, I reckon maybe I better arrive down from St. Louis or Cincinnati, or some other big place. Go for the steamboat, Huckleberry; we’ll come down to the village on her.”
I didn’t have to be ordered twice to go and take a steamboat ride. I fetched the shore a half a mile above the village, and then went scooting along the bluff bank in the easy water. Pretty soon we come to a nice innocent-looking young country jake setting on a log swabbing the sweat off of his face, for it was powerful warm weather; and he had a couple of big carpet-bags by him.

events.title: The King Gathers Intelligence on the Wilks Family
detailed_summary: The king directed Huck to bring the canoe to the shore where the young man was.
Upon asking the young man's destination, he learned the man was traveling to New Orleans via the steamboat.
The king invited the young man aboard their canoe, instructing Huck (whom he called "Adolphus") to assist with the luggage.
The young man expressed gratitude for the help, noting the difficulty of carrying his bags in the hot weather.
When asked about his own plans, the king falsely claimed to have recently arrived at the other village and was now heading a few miles upriver to visit an old friend on a farm.
The young man mentioned he had initially mistaken the king for a Mr. Wilks, who was expected, but then doubted it because the king was paddling upstream.
The king introduced himself as "Reverend Elexander Blodgett" and feigned sympathy for Mr. Wilks possibly having missed something significant.
The young man clarified that Peter Wilks had not missed out on any inheritance but had missed the opportunity to see his brother Peter before he died.

He elaborated that Peter Wilks had been desperate to see his brothers, Harvey (a preacher in England) and William (who was deaf and dumb), before his death. Peter had not seen Harvey since their boyhood and had never met William.
The young man explained Peter's loneliness following the deaths of his brother George and George's wife, which left George's young daughters (Mary Jane, Susan, and Joanna) somewhat orphaned.
Peter, who was elderly and ill, had avoided writing a formal will but left a letter for Harvey detailing the location of his money and instructions for dividing the property to care for his nieces.
The young man conveyed that Harvey Wilks lived in Sheffield, England, and might not have received the letter or had sufficient time to travel.

The king persistently questioned the young man, acquiring details about the Wilks nieces' ages (Mary Jane, nineteen; Susan, fifteen; Joanna, about fourteen and having a hare-lip) and the local friends, like Deacon Lot Hovey and Levi Bell, who would look after them.

The king continued his inquiries until he had extracted comprehensive information about everyone in the town, the Wilks family, Peter's tanning business, George's carpentry profession, and Harvey's role as a dissenting minister.
He learned that Peter Wilks was relatively wealthy, possessing houses, land, and an estimated three to four thousand dollars in hidden cash.
The young man revealed that Peter Wilks had died the previous night, and his funeral was scheduled for the middle of the next day.
The king responded with pious remarks about mortality and the importance of being prepared, to which the young man concurred, quoting his mother.

"Run her nose in shore," says the king.  

I steered the raft toward the bank, keeping a sharp eye out for any sign of trouble. The king and the duke had been acting stranger than usual lately, whispering to each other when they thought I wasn’t listening. I didn’t trust them as far as I could throw them, but I reckoned it was best to play along for now.  

The raft bumped against the muddy bank, and the duke hopped off, tying her up to a low-hanging willow branch. The king followed, smoothing out his fancy coat—stolen, no doubt—and adjusting his hat like he was some kind of royalty instead of the no-account fraud he was.  

“Now, Huck,” the king says, turning to me with that greasy smile of his, “you stay here and mind the raft while me and the duke attend to some business ashore.”  

I nodded, but I didn’t like the sound of that. Every time those two had “business,” it usually meant somebody was about to get swindled. Still, I wasn’t in no position to argue.  

“How long you reckon you’ll be?” I asked, trying to sound casual.  

The duke chuckled, slapping the king on the back. “Oh, not long, my boy. Just a quick errand—a matter of great delicacy.”  

That settled it. Whatever they were up to, it was bound to be trouble.  

As soon as they disappeared into the trees, I started thinking. Maybe this was my chance to slip away. Jim was hiding in the wigwam we’d built on the raft, keeping out of sight like always. If I could just figure out a way to shake those two frauds for good, we could head downriver and finally get Jim to freedom.  

I crept over to the wigwam and whispered, “Jim?”  

“Huck?” Jim’s voice was low and cautious. “Dem two rascals gone?”  

“Yeah, but they’ll be back. We gotta think fast.”  

Jim nodded, his face serious. “I’s ready to go whenever you is, Huck.”  

I chewed on my lip, thinking. If we cut the raft loose now, the king and the duke would be stranded, but they’d likely raise a fuss, and folks might come looking. On the other hand, if we waited, they’d just keep dragging us into their schemes.  

Then I heard it—voices coming from the woods. The king and the duke were returning, and they weren’t alone.  

“Quick, Jim, lay low!” I hissed, scrambling back to the steering oar just as the king came into view, leading two rough-looking men toward the raft.  

“Ah, Huck, my lad!” the king boomed, like he was delighted to see me. “These fine gentlemen have agreed to join us for a spell. Ain’t that grand?”  

I forced a smile, but my stomach twisted. The two strangers had the look of river rats—hard-eyed and mean. One of ’em spat tobacco juice into the water and grinned at me with yellow teeth.  

“This here’s Huck,” the duke said, slinging an arm around my shoulders like we were old pals. “A fine boy, if a bit simple.”  

The men chuckled, and I felt my face burn, but I kept quiet.  

“Now,” the king said, rubbing his hands together, “let’s all get comfortable. We’ve got a proposition for these gentlemen, Huck, and you’re gonna help us out.”  

I glanced at the wigwam, where Jim was hiding. Whatever they were planning, it wasn’t gonna be good. And if they found Jim…  

I swallowed hard. Looks like I was gonna have to think of something fast.  

(Continued...)

events.title: The King Devises the Wilks Impersonation Scheme
detailed_summary: Upon reaching the steamboat, they found it had nearly completed its loading and departed shortly thereafter, much to Huck's disappointment as he missed his ride.
The king then instructed Huck to paddle another mile to a more isolated location along the river.

Once ashore, the king ordered Huck to return immediately, locate the duke (even if it meant crossing to the other side of the river), and bring him along with the new carpet-bags, ensuring the duke was presentably dressed.
Huck, though silent, perceived the king's emerging plan.
When Huck returned with the duke, they concealed the canoe.
The king then sat down with the duke and recounted every detail about the Wilks family and their circumstances, just as the young man had told him.
During this explanation, the king practiced speaking with an English accent, which Huck observed he managed quite convincingly for someone of his background.
The king then queried the duke on his ability to portray a deaf and dumb individual.
The duke confidently asserted his capability, mentioning prior acting experience in such roles.
Having settled their roles, they began to wait for a steamboat that could take them to the village connected with the Wilks family.

events.title: Arrival at the Village and Start of the Wilks Deception
detailed_summary: Around mid-afternoon, after a few unsuitable small boats passed, a large steamboat appeared from further upriver, which they successfully hailed.
The steamboat dispatched its yawl, and they boarded; it was a vessel from Cincinnati.
The crew was initially furious upon learning the king and duke only wanted a short journey of four or five miles and threatened not to land them.
The king calmly negotiated, arguing that if they were willing to pay a dollar per mile each for yawl transport, the steamboat could surely accommodate them.
The crew eventually agreed and transported them ashore at the village in the yawl.
As they landed, a group of about two dozen men gathered to meet the arriving yawl.
The king inquired if any of the gentlemen could direct him to the residence of Mr. Peter Wilks.
The townsmen exchanged knowing looks, and one of them gently informed the king that they could only show him where Peter Wilks *had* lived as of the previous evening.

Reacting instantaneously, the king put on a dramatic display of grief, collapsing against the informant, placing his chin on the man's shoulder, and wailing about their "poor brother" whom they supposedly never got to see.
He then turned, still blubbering, and made a series of exaggerated hand gestures to the duke, feigning communication with a deaf person.
The duke played his part by dropping a carpet-bag and bursting into tears, contributing to the fraudulent spectacle of sorrow.
Huck internally condemned the duo as the most accomplished con artists he had ever encountered.
The townspeople, completely deceived by the performance, offered their sympathies and kind words.
They assisted the con men by carrying their carpet-bags up the hill, allowing the frauds to lean on them for support while they cried, and shared details about Peter Wilks's final hours.
The king, in turn, relayed this information to the supposedly deaf duke using more hand signs, and both men continued their ostentatious mourning as if deeply bereaved.
Huck concluded his observation of the scene with a profound sense of shame for humanity.

She sent out her yawl, and we went aboard, and she was from Cincinnati; and when they found we only wanted to go four or five mile they was booming mad, and gave us a cussing, and said they wouldn’t land us. The man frowned. “Whereabouts was it?”

The man shook his head. “Ain’t heard of no wreck. You boys the only ones got off?”  

Huck nodded solemnly. “Yes, sir. Just us. My family—well, I reckon they’re all drowned.” He sniffed for effect, and Jim, hidden below, nearly choked trying not to laugh.  

The man on the steamboat looked sympathetic. “That’s mighty hard luck. You best come aboard—we’ll take you to the next town.”

events.title: The Frauds' Arrival and Feigned Mourning
detailed_summary: News of the "uncles'" arrival spreads rapidly through the town, drawing a large and expectant crowd to the Wilks family home.

The three Wilks sisters, Mary Jane, Susan, and Joanna (referred to as "hare-lip"), are at the door, and Mary Jane, described as exceptionally beautiful and radiant with joy, eagerly embraces the King.
Joanna similarly embraces the Duke, and the emotional reunion moves many onlookers, especially women, to tears of happiness.
The King subtly signals the Duke, and together they approach Peter Wilks's coffin, which is placed on two chairs in a corner, adopting an exaggerated air of solemnity.
The crowd respectfully makes way for them, and a hush falls over the room, with men removing their hats in deference.
Upon looking into the coffin, the King and Duke erupt into an extremely loud and theatrical display of weeping, a performance the narrator finds overdone.
Their feigned sorrow is so potent that it causes widespread weeping among the assembled townspeople, making the atmosphere palpably damp.
The two conmen then kneel beside the coffin, pretending to pray silently, a gesture that further intensifies the crowd's emotional outburst, with everyone, including the Wilks sisters, sobbing aloud.
Many women in the crowd approach the grieving sisters, offering solemn kisses on their foreheads and tearful, skyward glances as gestures of profound sympathy before moving away, still sobbing.
The narrator expresses his deep disgust at the entire manipulative spectacle orchestrated by the King and Duke.
