events.text_segment:
We stopped talking, and got to thinking. By-and-by Tom says:
“Looky here, Huck, what fools we are to not think of it before! I bet I know where Jim is.”
“No! Where?”
“In that hut down by the ash-hopper. Why, looky here. When we was at dinner, didn’t you see a nigger man go in there with some vittles?”
“Yes.”
“What did you think the vittles was for?”
“For a dog.”
“So’d I. Well, it wasn’t for a dog.”
“Why?”
“Because part of it was watermelon.”
“So it was—I noticed it. Well, it does beat all that I never thought about a dog not eating watermelon. It shows how a body can see and don’t see at the same time.”
“Well, the nigger unlocked the padlock when he went in, and he locked it again when he came out. He fetched uncle a key about the time we got up from table—same key, I bet. Watermelon shows man, lock shows prisoner; and it ain’t likely there’s two prisoners on such a little plantation, and where the people’s all so kind and good. Jim’s the prisoner. All right—I’m glad we found it out detective fashion; I wouldn’t give shucks for any other way. Now you work your mind, and study out a plan to steal Jim, and I will study out one, too; and we’ll take the one we like the best.”
What a head for just a boy to have! If I had Tom Sawyer’s head I wouldn’t trade it off to be a duke, nor mate of a steamboat, nor clown in a circus, nor nothing I can think of. I went to thinking out a plan, but only just to be doing something; I knowed very well where the right plan was going to come from. Pretty soon Tom says:
“Ready?”
“Yes,” I says.
“All right—bring it out.”
“My plan is this,” I says. “We can easy find out if it’s Jim in there. Then get up my canoe to-morrow night, and fetch my raft over from the island. Then the first dark night that comes steal the key out of the old man’s britches after he goes to bed, and shove off down the river on the raft with Jim, hiding daytimes and running nights, the way me and Jim used to do before. Wouldn’t that plan work?”
“Work? Why, cert’nly it would work, like rats a-fighting. But it’s too blame’ simple; there ain’t nothing to it. What’s the good of a plan that ain’t no more trouble than that? It’s as mild as goose-milk. Why, Huck, it wouldn’t make no more talk than breaking into a soap factory.”
I never said nothing, because I warn’t expecting nothing different; but I knowed mighty well that whenever he got his plan ready it wouldn’t have none of them objections to it.
And it didn’t. He told me what it was, and I see in a minute it was worth fifteen of mine for style, and would make Jim just as free a man as mine would, and maybe get us all killed besides. So I was satisfied, and said we would waltz in on it. I needn’t tell what it was here, because I knowed it wouldn’t stay the way, it was. I knowed he would be changing it around every which way as we went along, and heaving in new bullinesses wherever he got a chance. And that is what he done.

We stopped talking, and got to thinking. The fire crackled low, and the shadows danced on the trees around us. Huck sat with his knees drawn up, chewing on a piece of grass, his eyes fixed on the river. I could tell his mind was working hard, turning over something heavy.  

"You reckon we done right, Tom?" he asked after a spell.  

I didn’t answer right off. Truth was, I wasn’t sure. We’d had ourselves an adventure, sure enough, but now that the excitement had worn off, I was starting to wonder if we hadn’t stirred up more trouble than we meant to.  

Huck sighed and tossed the grass into the fire. "Ain’t no use frettin’ over it now, I s’pose. What’s done is done."  

That was Huck’s way—take things as they come and don’t fuss too much about the past. But I couldn’t shake the feeling that we’d crossed a line somewhere, and there wasn’t no going back.  

The river rolled on, dark and quiet, like it knew all the secrets in the world and wasn’t telling. I thought about Jim, out there somewhere, maybe looking up at the same stars we were. I wondered if he was thinking about us too, or if he was just glad to be free of all our foolishness.  

Huck leaned back against a log, his hat pulled low over his eyes. "Reckon we oughta turn in," he said.  

I nodded, but I knew I wouldn’t sleep much. My head was too full of what-ifs and maybes. What if we’d taken a different path? What if we’d listened to the Widow Douglas and stayed put? But then, where’d the fun be in that?  

The fire burned down to embers, and the night settled in around us. Somewhere off in the woods, an owl called, soft and lonesome. Huck started snoring, easy as you please, like he didn’t have a care in the world.  

I lay there, staring up at the sky, counting the stars and wondering if anybody up there was counting me too. The world felt awful big just then, and me and Huck awful small in the middle of it.  

But that’s the way of things, I reckoned. You make your choices, and then you live with ’em. And if you’re lucky, you got a friend like Huck to see you through the rough patches.  

I closed my eyes and let the river’s whisper carry me off to sleep. Tomorrow was another day, and who knew what it’d bring? One thing was sure—it wouldn’t be dull. Not with Huck Finn around.

events.title: Huck's Astonishment at Tom's Commitment to Freeing Jim
detailed_summary: Huck is certain of Tom's genuine intention to help free Jim, a realization that deeply perplexes him.

He contemplates Tom's respectable upbringing, good character, intelligence, and kind nature, finding it incomprehensible that Tom would stoop to an act that would bring shame upon himself and his family.
Huck feels a moral obligation as Tom's friend to intervene and persuade him to abandon the risky endeavor to save Tom from the consequences.
However, when Huck attempts to express his concerns, Tom quickly dismisses him, asserting his own competence and awareness of his actions.
Tom firmly reminds Huck of his declared commitment to help steal Jim, effectively ending the discussion.
Huck, still baffled by Tom's willingness to engage in such a serious undertaking, decides to let the matter rest, acknowledging Tom's unshakeable resolve.

events.text_segment:
Well, one thing was dead sure, and that was that Tom Sawyer was in earnest, and was actuly going to help steal that nigger out of slavery. That was the thing that was too many for me. Here was a boy that was respectable and well brung up; and had a character to lose; and folks at home that had characters; and he was bright and not leather-headed; and knowing and not ignorant; and not mean, but kind; and yet here he was, without any more pride, or rightness, or feeling, than to stoop to this business, and make himself a shame, and his family a shame, before everybody. I couldn’t understand it no way at all. It was outrageous, and I knowed I ought to just up and tell him so; and so be his true friend, and let him quit the thing right where he was and save himself. And I did start to tell him; but he shut me up, and says:
“Don’t you reckon I know what I’m about? Don’t I generly know what I’m about?”
“Yes.”
“Didn’t I say I was going to help steal the nigger?”
“Yes.”
“Well, then.”
That’s all he said, and that’s all I said. It warn’t no use to say any more; because when he said he’d do a thing, he always done it. But I couldn’t make out how he was willing to go into this thing; so I just let it go, and never bothered no more about it. If he was bound to have it so, I couldn’t help it.

events.title: Nighttime Reconnaissance and Tom's Preference for Complication
detailed_summary: Later, with the house quiet and dark, Huck and Tom proceed to the hut by the ash-hopper for an inspection.
They navigate the yard, and the hounds, recognizing them, do not raise an alarm.
Upon examining the cabin, they find a square window hole on the north side, covered by a single stout board.
Huck immediately identifies this as a viable escape route if they remove the board.
Tom dismisses this idea as too simplistic, expressing a desire for a more complex solution.

Huck then suggests sawing Jim out, referencing a past elaborate deception of his own, which Tom finds more appealing for its 'mysterious and troublesome' qualities, yet he still hopes for an even more time-consuming method.
They discover a lean-to structure at the back of the hut, padlocked at its south-end door.
Tom uses an iron tool from the soap-kettle to pry out a staple, allowing them to enter the lean-to.
Inside, they find the shed is not connected to the main cabin, has no floor, and contains only old, discarded tools.

Despite the shed not offering direct access, Tom is pleased and declares their method will be to dig Jim out, a process he estimates will take about a week, satisfying his need for a grand, elaborate scheme.

Upon returning to the house, Tom eschews the simple back door Huck uses, insisting on a 'romantical' entrance by climbing the lightning rod, which he achieves only after several clumsy and painful failures.

When we got home the house was all dark and still; so we went on down to the hut by the ash-hopper for to examine it. We went through the yard so as to see what the hounds would do. They knowed us, and didn’t make no more noise than country dogs is always doing when anything comes by in the night. When we got to the cabin we took a look at the front and the two sides; and on the side I warn’t acquainted with—which was the north side—we found a square window-hole, up tolerable high, with just one stout board nailed across it. I says:
“Here’s the ticket. This hole’s big enough for Jim to get through if we wrench off the board.”
Tom says:
“It’s as simple as tit-tat-toe, three-in-a-row, and as easy as playing hooky. I should hope we can find a way that’s a little more complicated than that, Huck Finn.”
“Well, then,” I says, “how’ll it do to saw him out, the way I done before I was murdered that time?”
“That’s more like,” he says. “It’s real mysterious, and troublesome, and good,” he says; “but I bet we can find a way that’s twice as long. There ain’t no hurry; le’s keep on looking around.”
Betwixt the hut and the fence, on the back side, was a lean-to that joined the hut at the eaves, and was made out of plank. It was as long as the hut, but narrow—only about six foot wide. The door to it was at the south end, and was padlocked. Tom he went to the soap-kettle and searched around, and fetched back the iron thing they lift the lid with; so he took it and prized out one of the staples. The chain fell down, and we opened the door and went in, and shut it, and struck a match, and see the shed was only built against a cabin and hadn’t no connection with it; and there warn’t no floor to the shed, nor nothing in it but some old rusty played-out hoes and spades and picks and a crippled plow. The match went out, and so did we, and shoved in the staple again, and the door was locked as good as ever. Tom was joyful. He says;
“Now we’re all right. We’ll dig him out. It’ll take about a week!”
Then we started for the house, and I went in the back door—you only have to pull a buckskin latch-string, they don’t fasten the doors—but that warn’t romantical enough for Tom Sawyer; no way would do him but he must climb up the lightning-rod. But after he got up half way about three times, and missed fire and fell every time, and the last time most busted his brains out, he thought he’d got to give it up; but after he was rested he allowed he would give her one more turn for luck, and this time he made the trip.

When we got home the house was all dark and still; so we went on down to the hut by the ash-hopper for to examine it. The moon was high in the sky, casting long shadows across the yard, and the air was thick with the scent of damp earth and old wood. Jim went first, his big shoulders hunched like he was expecting trouble, and I followed close behind, my heart pounding like a drum in my chest.

The hut was just as we’d left it—small, rickety, and smelling of smoke and sweat. But something felt different. Maybe it was the quiet, or the way the door creaked louder than usual when Jim pushed it open. Inside, the fire had died down to glowing embers, and the only light came from the moon slipping in through the cracks in the walls.

“You reckon anybody’s been here?” I whispered, though I didn’t know why I was whispering. The place was empty, but it felt like the walls had ears.

Jim shook his head slow. “Don’t look like it,” he said, but he didn’t sound too sure. He knelt by the fireplace and poked at the ashes with a stick. “Fire’s been dead a while. Ain’t nobody been here since we left.”

I sat down on the old straw mattress, feeling the lumps poke through my pants. The whole place gave me the shivers, like something bad was about to happen. Maybe it was just the night playing tricks on me, but I couldn’t shake the feeling we weren’t alone.

Then I heard it—a soft rustling outside, like somebody stepping careful through the grass. Jim heard it too. His head snapped up, and his eyes met mine in the dim light. We didn’t move, didn’t breathe. The sound came again, closer this time.

“Somebody’s out there,” I mouthed.

Jim nodded and motioned for me to get behind him. He picked up a heavy piece of firewood, holding it like a club. My hands were shaking so bad I could barely make a fist, but I grabbed the old hunting knife we kept under the mattress and held it tight.

The rustling stopped right outside the door. Then—knock, knock, knock. Three soft taps, like whoever it was didn’t want to wake the dead.

Jim’s voice was steady when he called out, “Who’s there?”

For a long second, there was nothing. Then a voice, low and familiar, said, “It’s me—Tom Sawyer.”

I near about jumped out of my skin. Tom? Here? I scrambled to the door and yanked it open, and sure enough, there stood Tom in his fancy clothes, grinning like he’d just pulled the best joke in the world.

“Well, don’t just stand there gawping,” he said, brushing past me into the hut. “I got a plan that’ll make this adventure ten times better. But first, you got to tell me everything that’s happened since I been gone.”

And just like that, the night didn’t feel so scary anymore. With Tom around, trouble was sure to follow—but at least it’d be the fun kind.

events.title: Encounter at the Hut and Tom's Deceptive Maneuvers
detailed_summary: At dawn, Tom and Huck visit the slave cabins to interact with the dogs and befriend the Black man responsible for feeding Jim, assuming it is indeed Jim being fed.
The man, Nat, appears good-natured but is deeply superstitious, his hair tied in bunches to ward off witches, whom he claims are severely pestering him.
When Tom asks about the food Nat is carrying, Nat replies with a slow smile that it is for a 'curious dog' and invites the boys to see it.
Huck whispers his concern to Tom about deviating from their plan by entering the hut in daylight, but Tom declares this is the new plan.
Inside the dimly lit hut, Jim immediately recognizes the boys and exclaims their names.
Nat, startled, questions how the 'runaway nigger' knows them.
Tom quickly feigns ignorance and bewilderment, asking who called out and what was said, then calmly asks Huck if he heard anything.
Huck plays along, denying that he heard anyone speak.
Tom then questions Jim, who, grasping the situation, also denies having spoken or having seen the boys before.
Tom attributes Nat's perception of voices to 'witches,' further playing on Nat's superstitions and distress.
Tom gives Nat a dime, advising him to buy more thread for his hair to protect against witches, and assures him they won't mention his troubles.

While Nat is momentarily distracted by the dime, Tom quickly whispers to Jim, instructing him not to reveal their acquaintance and to listen for digging sounds at night, signifying their rescue efforts.
Jim manages a brief, grateful squeeze of their hands before Nat returns.
Nat expresses his willingness for the boys to visit again, especially after dark, as he believes company helps deter the witches that trouble him most at night.

In the morning we was up at break of day, and down to the nigger cabins to pet the dogs and make friends with the nigger that fed Jim—if it was Jim that was being fed. The niggers was just getting through breakfast and starting for the fields; and Jim’s nigger was piling up a tin pan with bread and meat and things; and whilst the others was leaving, the key come from the house.
This nigger had a good-natured, chuckle-headed face, and his wool was all tied up in little bunches with thread. That was to keep witches off. He said the witches was pestering him awful these nights, and making him see all kinds of strange things, and hear all kinds of strange words and noises, and he didn’t believe he was ever witched so long before in his life. He got so worked up, and got to running on so about his troubles, he forgot all about what he’d been a-going to do. So Tom says:
“What’s the vittles for? Going to feed the dogs?”
The nigger kind of smiled around gradually over his face, like when you heave a brickbat in a mud-puddle, and he says:
“Yes, Mars Sid, a dog. Cur’us dog, too. Does you want to go en look at ’im?”
“Yes.”
I hunched Tom, and whispers:
“You going, right here in the daybreak? That warn’t the plan.”
“No, it warn’t; but it’s the plan now.”
So, drat him, we went along, but I didn’t like it much. When we got in we couldn’t hardly see anything, it was so dark; but Jim was there, sure enough, and could see us; and he sings out:
“Why, Huck! En good lan’! ain’ dat Misto Tom?”
I just knowed how it would be; I just expected it. I didn’t know nothing to do; and if I had I couldn’t a done it, because that nigger busted in and says:
“Why, de gracious sakes! do he know you genlmen?”
We could see pretty well now. Tom he looked at the nigger, steady and kind of wondering, and says:
“Does who know us?”
“Why, dis-yer runaway nigger.”
“I don’t reckon he does; but what put that into your head?”
“What put it dar? Didn’ he jis’ dis minute sing out like he knowed you?”
Tom says, in a puzzled-up kind of way:
“Well, that’s mighty curious. Who sung out? When did he sing out? what did he sing out?” And turns to me, perfectly ca’m, and says, “Did you hear anybody sing out?”
Of course there warn’t nothing to be said but the one thing; so I says:
“No; I ain’t heard nobody say nothing.”
Then he turns to Jim, and looks him over like he never see him before, and says:
“Did you sing out?”
“No, sah,” says Jim; “I hain’t said nothing, sah.”
“Not a word?”
“No, sah, I hain’t said a word.”
“Did you ever see us before?”
“No, sah; not as I knows on.”
So Tom turns to the nigger, which was looking wild and distressed, and says, kind of severe:
“What do you reckon’s the matter with you, anyway? What made you think somebody sung out?”
“Oh, it’s de dad-blame’ witches, sah, en I wisht I was dead, I do. Dey’s awluz at it, sah, en dey do mos’ kill me, dey sk’yers me so. Please to don’t tell nobody ’bout it sah, er ole Mars Silas he’ll scole me; ’kase he say dey ain’t no witches. I jis’ wish to goodness he was heah now—den what would he say! I jis’ bet he couldn’ fine no way to git aroun’ it dis time. But it’s awluz jis’ so; people dat’s sot, stays sot; dey won’t look into noth’n’en fine it out f’r deyselves, en when you fine it out en tell um ’bout it, dey doan’ b’lieve you.”
Tom give him a dime, and said we wouldn’t tell nobody; and told him to buy some more thread to tie up his wool with; and then looks at Jim, and says:
“I wonder if Uncle Silas is going to hang this nigger. If I was to catch a nigger that was ungrateful enough to run away, I wouldn’t give him up, I’d hang him.” And whilst the nigger stepped to the door to look at the dime and bite it to see if it was good, he whispers to Jim and says:

The old nigger give him a slow look and says, “They comin’ along, young marster.”  

Tom grinned and says, “Say, uncle, you got a mighty interestin’ job here, feedin’ the prisoners and all. Must be a powerful responsibility.”  

The nigger didn’t answer right off, just kept stirring. Then he says, “I does what I’s told, young marster.”  

Tom leaned in close, like he was sharing a secret, and says, “You ever talk to that prisoner? The one they got locked up in the shed?”  

The nigger’s hands slowed on the spoon, and he give Tom another long look. “No, suh. Ain’t my place to talk to him. Just feeds him and leaves.”  

I could see Tom’s eyes light up at that, like he’d struck gold. “Well now, that’s a shame,” he says. “A man locked up like that must get mighty lonesome. Don’t you reckon he’d appreciate a little conversation now and then?”  

The nigger shook his head. “Ain’t my place,” he says again, firm-like.  

Tom sighed, like he was real disappointed, but I could tell he was just getting started. “Say, uncle, what’s your name?”  

“They calls me Silas, suh.”  

“Well, Silas, I reckon you’re a good man. A trustworthy man. The kind of man a feller could depend on.”  

Silas didn’t look like he much cared what Tom reckoned, but he nodded anyway. “Yes, suh.”  

Tom clapped him on the shoulder. “Tell you what, Silas. Me and my brother here”—he jerked a thumb at me—“we’re mighty interested in that prisoner. We’d like to help him out if we can. Now, I don’t suppose you’d mind if we was to bring him a little extra something now and then? A pie, maybe, or some tobacco?”  

Silas’s face went still, and for a minute I thought he was gonna say no. Then he looked around quick-like, like he was making sure nobody was listening, and says real low, “You boys best stay clear of that shed. Ain’t no good gonna come of messin’ with that prisoner.”  

Tom’s grin got wider. “Why, Silas, you sound almost like you’re worried about him.”  

Silas didn’t answer, just turned back to his pot. But I seen the way his hands shook a little, and I reckoned he knew more than he was letting on.  

Tom, he wasn’t about to let it go. “Silas,” he says, “you ever hear that prisoner say anything? Like maybe he’s got friends coming for him?”  

Silas’s spoon clattered against the pot, and he looked up sharp. “What you know ’bout that?”  

Tom shrugged, all innocent-like. “Nothin’ much. Just curious.”  

Silas studied him for a long minute, then says, “You boys best go on now. Breakfast be ready soon, and massa don’t like folks hangin’ round the kitchen.”

events.title: Gathering Fox-fire and Tom's Frustration with Simplicity
detailed_summary: With breakfast an hour away, Huck and Tom ventured into the woods to gather fox-fire for a subtle light source, as Tom deemed lanterns too risky.
After collecting an armful of the glowing wood and hiding it, Tom expressed his dissatisfaction with the straightforward nature of Jim's current confinement.
He lamented the lack of typical escape-story obstacles, such as a watchman to drug or a dog to give a sleeping potion to.
Tom pointed out the ease with which Jim's chain could be removed from the bedstead and criticized Uncle Silas's trusting nature for not posting a guard.
He noted that Jim's only real impediment was the ten-foot chain itself, making escape otherwise too simple.
Tom concluded that they would have to invent all the difficulties themselves to make the escape honorable and challenging.
He considered it more prestigious to overcome self-created obstacles when none were provided by Jim's captors.
As an example, he stated they must pretend a lantern is risky, even though they could probably use a torchlight procession without issue.
He then declared their immediate need to find material for a saw.

events.text_segment:
It would be most an hour yet till breakfast, so we left and struck down into the woods; because Tom said we got to have some light to see how to dig by, and a lantern makes too much, and might get us into trouble; what we must have was a lot of them rotten chunks that’s called fox-fire, and just makes a soft kind of a glow when you lay them in a dark place. We fetched an armful and hid it in the weeds, and set down to rest, and Tom says, kind of dissatisfied:
“Blame it, this whole thing is just as easy and awkward as it can be. And so it makes it so rotten difficult to get up a difficult plan. There ain’t no watchman to be drugged—now there ought to be a watchman. There ain’t even a dog to give a sleeping-mixture to. And there’s Jim chained by one leg, with a ten-foot chain, to the leg of his bed: why, all you got to do is to lift up the bedstead and slip off the chain. And Uncle Silas he trusts everybody; sends the key to the punkin-headed nigger, and don’t send nobody to watch the nigger. Jim could a got out of that window-hole before this, only there wouldn’t be no use trying to travel with a ten-foot chain on his leg. Why, drat it, Huck, it’s the stupidest arrangement I ever see. You got to invent all the difficulties. Well, we can’t help it; we got to do the best we can with the materials we’ve got. Anyhow, there’s one thing—there’s more honor in getting him out through a lot of difficulties and dangers, where there warn’t one of them furnished to you by the people who it was their duty to furnish them, and you had to contrive them all out of your own head. Now look at just that one thing of the lantern. When you come down to the cold facts, we simply got to let on that a lantern’s resky. Why, we could work with a torchlight procession if we wanted to, I believe. Now, whilst I think of it, we got to hunt up something to make a saw out of the first chance we get.”

events.title: Tom's Elaborate, Book-Inspired Escape Fantasies
detailed_summary: Huck questioned the necessity of a saw.
Tom, invoking adventure novels, explained they needed to saw the leg of Jim's bed to free the chain, rather than simply lifting the bedstead.
Huck pointed out Tom's earlier observation that the chain could be slipped off by lifting the bed.
Tom chided Huck for his simplistic, 'infant-school' approach, asking if he'd ever read adventure stories featuring heroes like Baron Trenck or Casanova.

He asserted that respected authorities in escape narratives always saw the bed-leg in two, conceal the act by swallowing sawdust and camouflaging the cut, then kick the leg to break it on the night of escape.

Tom enthusiastically described a dramatic escape sequence involving rope ladders, moats (lamenting the cabin's lack thereof), horses, and loyal vassals, culminating in a flight to a romanticized foreign land.
He declared such an escape 'gaudy' and expressed a wish for a moat, suggesting they might dig one if time permitted.

events.text_segment:
“What do we want of a saw?”
“What do we want of it? Hain’t we got to saw the leg of Jim’s bed off, so as to get the chain loose?”
“Why, you just said a body could lift up the bedstead and slip the chain off.”
“Well, if that ain’t just like you, Huck Finn. You can get up the infant-schooliest ways of going at a thing. Why, hain’t you ever read any books at all?—Baron Trenck, nor Casanova, nor Benvenuto Chelleeny, nor Henri IV., nor none of them heroes? Who ever heard of getting a prisoner loose in such an old-maidy way as that? No; the way all the best authorities does is to saw the bed-leg in two, and leave it just so, and swallow the sawdust, so it can’t be found, and put some dirt and grease around the sawed place so the very keenest seneskal can’t see no sign of it’s being sawed, and thinks the bed-leg is perfectly sound. Then, the night you’re ready, fetch the leg a kick, down she goes; slip off your chain, and there you are. Nothing to do but hitch your rope ladder to the battlements, shin down it, break your leg in the moat—because a rope ladder is nineteen foot too short, you know—and there’s your horses and your trusty vassles, and they scoop you up and fling you across a saddle, and away you go to your native Langudoc, or Navarre, or wherever it is. It’s gaudy, Huck. I wish there was a moat to this cabin. If we get time, the night of the escape, we’ll dig one.”

Tom Sawyer looked at me like I was the dullest tool in the shed. “Why, to saw Jim’s chain off, of course! You don’t reckon we can just bust it with our bare hands, do you?”  

I reckoned he had a point, but it still seemed like a mighty roundabout way of doing things. “Seems to me a file would do the job quicker,” I said. “Jim ain’t got but one little link to cut through.”  

Tom sighed like I was testing his patience something awful. “Huck Finn, where’s your imagination? This ain’t just about getting Jim free—it’s about doing it the *right* way, the way they do in the books. Prisoners always saw through their chains. It’s the romantic way!”  

I didn’t see much romance in making Jim sit there sawing for a week when a file would’ve had him loose in half an hour, but Tom had his heart set on it. So we snuck the saw into the cabin where Jim was kept, along with a rusty old case-knife and a spoon—Tom said a proper prisoner needed to dig his way out with a spoon, too, even if there wasn’t any dirt to dig through.  

Jim looked at the saw and then at me, and I could tell he was thinking the same thing I was. But he just said, “Thank’ee, Marse Tom,” real polite-like, and set to work.  

Sometimes I wondered if Tom cared more about the adventure than about setting Jim free. But I kept that thought to myself.

events.title: Debating Morbid Escape Tropes and the Necessity of a Rope Ladder
detailed_summary: Huck questioned the purpose of a moat since their plan was to extract Jim from beneath the cabin.
Tom, lost in thought, initially ignored Huck.
He then sighed, stating that a particular idea wouldn't work due to insufficient necessity.
When Huck inquired further, Tom revealed he was contemplating sawing off Jim's leg, citing precedents from 'best authorities' who amputated their own hands to escape chains.
Huck reacted with alarm, exclaiming there was no need for such a drastic measure.
Tom conceded that sawing off Jim's leg wasn't strictly necessary in this case and added that Jim, being a 'nigger,' wouldn't grasp the European customs behind such acts, so they would forgo it.
However, Tom insisted Jim must have a rope ladder, which they could make from torn sheets and deliver in a pie, as this was a common method in stories.
Huck argued that Jim had no use for a rope ladder.
Tom countered vehemently, stating Jim absolutely needed one because it was standard procedure for all prisoners in stories.
When Huck asked what Jim would do with it, Tom explained he could hide it in his bed, providing a clue for their pursuers after the escape, emphasizing the importance of leaving such clues.

“He has got use for it. How you talk, you better say; you don’t know nothing about it. He’s got to have a rope ladder; they all do.”
“What in the nation can he do with it?”
“Do with it? He can hide it in his bed, can’t he?” That’s what they all do; and he’s got to, too. Huck, you don’t ever seem to want to do anything that’s regular; you want to be starting something fresh all the time. S’pose he don’t do nothing with it? ain’t it there in his bed, for a clew, after he’s gone? and don’t you reckon they’ll want clews? Of course they will. And you wouldn’t leave them any? That would be a pretty howdy-do, wouldn’t it! I never heard of such a thing.”

“*Do* with it? He can hide it in his bed, can’t he? That’s what they all do; and *he’s* got to, too. Huck, you don’t ever seem to want to do anything that’s regular; you want to be starting something fresh all the time. S’pose he *don’t* do nothing with it? ain’t it there in his bed, for a sign, after he’s gone? and don’t you reckon they’ll want signs? Of course they will. And you wouldn’t leave them any? That would be a *pretty* howdy-do, *wouldn’t* it! I never heard of such a thing.”  

“Well,” I says, “if it’s in the regulations, and he’s got to have it, all right, let him have it; because I don’t wish to go back on no regulations; but there’s one thing, Tom Sawyer—if we go to tearing up our sheets to make Jim a rope ladder, we’re going to get into trouble with Aunt Sally, just as sure as you’re born. Now, the way I look at it, a hickry-bark ladder don’t cost nothing, and don’t waste nothing, and is just as good to load up a pie with, and hide in a straw tick, as any rag ladder you can start; and as for Jim, he ain’t had no experience, and so he don’t care what kind of a—”  

“Oh, shucks, Huck Finn, if I was as ignorant as you I’d keep still—that’s what *I’d* do. Who ever heard of a state prisoner escaping by a hickry-bark ladder? Why, it’s perfectly ridiculous.”  

“Well, all right, Tom, fix it your own way; but if you’ll take my advice, you’ll let me borrow a sheet off of the clothesline.”  

He said that would do. And that give him another idea, and he says:  

“Borrow a shirt, too.”  

“What do we want of a shirt, Tom?”  

“Want it for Jim to keep a journal on.”  

“Journal your granny—*Jim* can’t write.”  

“S’pose he *can’t* write—he can make marks on the shirt, can’t he, if we make him a pen out of an old pewter spoon or a piece of an old iron barrel-hoop?”  

“Why, Tom, we can pull a feather out of a goose and make him a better one; and quicker, too.”  

“*Prisoners* don’t have geese running around the donjon-keep to pull pens out of, you muggins. They *always* make their pens out of the hardest, toughest, troublesomest piece of old brass candlestick or something like that they can get their hands on; and it takes them weeks and weeks and months and months to file it out, too, because they’ve got to do it by rubbing it on the wall. *They* wouldn’t use a goose-quill if they had it. It ain’t regular.”  

“Well, then, what’ll we make him the ink out of?”  

“Many makes it out of iron-rust and tears; but that’s the common sort and women; the best authorities uses their own blood. Jim can do that; and when he wants to send any little common ordinary mysterious message to let the world know where he’s captivated, he can write it on the bottom of a tin plate with a fork and throw it out of the window. The Iron Mask always done that, and it’s a blame’ good way, too.”  

“Jim ain’t got no tin plates. They feed him in a pan.”  

“That ain’t anything; we can get him some.”  

“Can’t nobody *read* his plates.”  

“That ain’t got nothing to *do* with it, Huck Finn. All *he’s* got to do is to write on the plate and throw it out. You don’t *have* to be able to read it. Why, half the time you can’t read anything a prisoner writes on a tin plate, or anywhere else.”  

“Well, then, what’s the sense in wasting the plates?”  

“Why, blame it all, it ain’t the *prisoner’s* plates.”  

“But it’s *somebody’s* plates, ain’t it?”  

“Well, if that’s the way you look at it, what’s the sense in wasting the *prisoner*? But you always take the most reskless view of things a body ever see.”  

“All right, Tom, if you say so; but I’ll be bound if I don’t think we ought to have a rock for him to grind his pens and his saws and his things out of, and then there ain’t no occasion to be borrowing other people’s. There’s a big grindstone down at the mill, and we can smouch it.”  

“Now you’re *talking*, Huck. That shows sense. But we got to have a case for the grindstone, too, and a leather strap to turn it with, and we got to have a little mill, or something of that kind, to do the sharpening on. But that ain’t the main thing. The main thing is, how are we going to smuggle the things to Jim?”  

“We’ll manage that easy enough,” I says, “if we can get them into the cabin.”  

Tom turned on me looking pitying enough to make a body cry, and says:  

“Huck Finn, did you *ever* hear of a prisoner having picks and shovels, and all the modern conveniences in his pocket to dig himself out with? Now I want to ask you—if you got any reasonableness in you at all—what kind of a show would *that* give him to be a hero? Why, they might as well lend him the key and done with it. Picks and shovels—why, they wouldn’t furnish ’em to a king.”  

“Well, then,” I says, “if we don’t want the picks and shovels, what *do* we want?”  

“A couple of case-knives.”  

“To dig the foundations out from under that cabin with?”  

“Yes.”  

“Confound it, it’s foolish, Tom.”  

“It don’t make no difference how foolish it is, it’s the *right* way—and it’s the regular way. And there ain’t no *other* way, that ever *I* heard of, and I’ve read all the books that gives any information about these things. They always dig out with a case-knife—and not through dirt, mind you; generly it’s through solid rock. And it takes them weeks and weeks and weeks, and for ever and ever. Why, look at one of them prisoners in the bottom dungeon of the Castle Deef, in the harbor of Marseilles, that dug himself out that way; how long was *he* at it, you reckon?”  

“I don’t know.”  

“Well, guess.”  

“I don’t know. A month and a half?”  

“*Thirty-seven year*—and he come out in China. *That’s* the kind. I wish the bottom of *this* fortress was solid rock.”  

“*Jim* don’t know nobody in China.”  

“What’s *that* got to do with it? Neither did that other fellow. But you’re always a-wandering off on a side issue. Why can’t you stick to the main point?”  

“All right—*I* don’t care where he comes out, so he *comes* out; and Jim don’t, either, I reckon. But there’s one thing, anyway—Jim’s too old to be dug out with a case-knife. He won’t last.”  

“Yes he will, too. You don’t reckon it’s going to take thirty-seven years to dig out through a *dirt* foundation, do you?”  

“How long will it take, Tom?”  

“Well, we can’t resk being as long as we ought to, because it mayn’t take very long for Uncle Silas to hear from down there by New Orleans. He’ll hear Jim ain’t from there. Then his next move will be to advertise Jim, or something like that. So we can’t resk being as long digging him out as we ought to. By rights I reckon we ought to be a couple of years; but we can’t. Things being so uncertain, what I recommend is this: that we really dig right in, as quick as we can; and after that, we can *let on*, to ourselves, that we was at it thirty-seven years. Then we can snatch him out and rush him away the first time there’s an alarm. Yes, I reckon that’ll be the best way.”  

“Now, there’s *sense* in that,” I says. “Letting on don’t cost nothing; letting on ain’t no trouble; and if it’s any object, I don’t mind letting on we was at it a hundred and fifty year. It wouldn’t strain me none, after I got my hand in. So I’ll mosey along now, and smouch a couple of case-knives.”  

“Smouch three,” he says; “we want one to make a saw out of.”  

“Tom, if it ain’t unregular and irreligious to sejest it,” I says, “there’s an old rusty saw-blade around yonder sticking under the weather-boarding behind the smoke-house.”  

He looked kind of weary and discouraged-like, and says:  

“It ain’t no use to try to learn you nothing, Huck. Run along and smouch the knives—three of them.” So I done it.

But Tom he just shook his head, looking solemn as an owl.  

“Huck,” he says, “you don’t understand the principles of a proper rescue. Every prisoner of consequence has got to have a moat. It’s in the books—all the best ones. Why, if we left that out, it wouldn’t be half as noble, and Jim wouldn’t feel near as important.”  

I reckoned he had a point, though it seemed like a powerful lot of trouble just to make Jim feel like a real prisoner. But Tom had his mind set, so we set to digging that moat all around the cabin, just deep enough to trip a fellow if he wasn’t looking.  

“Now,” says Tom, wiping his brow, “that’s more like it. A prisoner’s got to have style, Huck. You can’t just yank him out like a turnip—there’s got to be ceremony to it.”  

I didn’t argue, seeing as how Tom had read a heap more books than me, and likely knew the proper way of things. But I couldn’t help thinking that Jim might not care much about style if it meant waiting another week to get free.  

“What’s next?” I asked, figuring we’d done enough digging to satisfy even Tom’s notions.  

“Next,” says Tom, eyes shining like he’d just struck gold, “we got to smuggle in a rope ladder baked into a pie.”  

I opened my mouth to say something, then shut it again. There wasn’t any use arguing once Tom got one of his ideas. So I just nodded and said, “Reckon we better get to baking, then.”  

And that’s how we spent the next hour mixing flour and water, though neither of us knew the first thing about pies. But Tom said it didn’t matter so long as it looked close enough, seeing as Jim wouldn’t likely eat it anyway.  

Sometimes I wondered if Jim knew what he was in for, letting Tom Sawyer plan his escape.

“Many makes it out of iron-rust and tears; but that’s the common sort and women; the best authorities uses their own blood. Jim can do that; and when he wants to send any little common ordinary mysterious message to let the world know where he’s captivated, he can write it on the bottom of a tin plate with a fork and throw it out of the window. The Iron Mask always done that, and it’s a blame’ good way, too.”
“Jim ain’t got no tin plates. They feed him in a pan.”
“That ain’t nothing; we can get him some.”
“Can’t nobody read his plates.”
“That ain’t got anything to do with it, Huck Finn. All he’s got to do is to write on the plate and throw it out. You don’t have to be able to read it. Why, half the time you can’t read anything a prisoner writes on a tin plate, or anywhere else.”
“Well, then, what’s the sense in wasting the plates?”
“Why, blame it all, it ain’t the prisoner’s plates.”
“But it’s somebody’s plates, ain’t it?”
“Well, spos’n it is? What does the prisoner care whose—”
He broke off there, because we heard the breakfast-horn blowing. So we cleared out for the house.

I called it borrowing, because that was what pap always called it; but Tom said it warn’t borrowing, it was stealing. He said we was representing prisoners; and prisoners don’t care how they get a thing so they get it, and nobody don’t blame them for it, either. It ain’t no crime in a prisoner to steal the thing he needs to get away with, Tom said; it’s his right; and so, as long as we was representing a prisoner, we had a perfect right to steal anything on this place we had the least use for to get ourselves out of prison with. He said if we warn’t prisoners it would be a very different thing, and nobody but a mean, ornery person would steal when he warn’t a prisoner. So we allowed we would steal everything there was that come handy. And yet he made a mighty fuss, one day, after that, when I stole a watermelon out of the nigger-patch and eat it; and he made me go and give the niggers a dime without telling them what it was for. Tom said that what he meant was, we could steal anything we needed. Well, I says, I needed the watermelon. But he said I didn’t need it to get out of prison with; there’s where the difference was. He said if I’d a wanted it to hide a knife in, and smuggle it to Jim to kill the seneskal with, it would a been all right. So I let it go at that, though I couldn’t see no advantage in my representing a prisoner if I got to set down and chaw over a lot of gold-leaf distinctions like that every time I see a chance to hog a watermelon.

“Well, then, what’ll we make him the ink out of?” I says, scratching my head.  

Tom Sawyer, he just leaned back against the fence and looked up at the sky like he was studying on it real hard. Then he snapped his fingers and grinned. “We’ll make it out of rusty nails and vinegar,” he says.  

“Rusty nails and vinegar?” I says. “That ain’t ink, Tom. That’s just a mess.”  

“Course it is,” says Tom, like he was explaining something to a baby. “You take a handful of old nails, drop ’em in a bottle of vinegar, and let ’em sit till they’re good and rusty. Then you pour off the liquid, and there’s your ink—black as sin and perfect for writing.”  

I reckoned he’d read about it in one of them books of his, the kind full of pirates and hidden treasure and such. Tom was always coming up with the most outlandish schemes, and half the time they worked, too.  

“All right,” I says, “but where we gonna get the vinegar?”  

Tom frowned a minute, then brightened up. “Aunt Polly’s got a whole jug of it in the pantry. I’ll just borrow a little—she won’t even notice.”  

I didn’t much like the idea of stealing from his aunt, but Tom was already set on it, and once his mind was made up, there wasn’t no changing it. So we snuck into the kitchen while Aunt Polly was out feeding the chickens, and Tom poured some vinegar into an old medicine bottle he’d fished out of the trash.  

Next, we needed the nails. Tom said they had to be real rusty, so we dug around in the shed till we found a handful of old ones covered in red-brown crust. We dropped ’em in the vinegar, gave the bottle a shake, and set it on the windowsill to stew.  

“Now we just gotta wait,” Tom says, rubbing his hands together. “By tomorrow, we’ll have the finest ink this side of the Mississippi.”  

I wasn’t so sure, but I kept my mouth shut. Tom’s plans had a way of working out, even when they didn’t make a lick of sense.  

Sure enough, next morning, the vinegar had turned a nasty brown-black, and the nails were even rustier than before. Tom fished ’em out with a stick and held the bottle up to the light. “There,” he says, proud as could be. “Genuine outlaw ink, just like they used in the old days.”  

I dipped a quill in it and tried writing my name on a scrap of paper. It came out all splotchy and faded, but Tom said that just made it look more authentic. “Real pirates didn’t have store-bought ink neither,” he says. “They had to make do with what they could find.”  

I reckon he was right about that. And if Tom Sawyer said rusty nails and vinegar made proper ink, then I suppose it did—leastways for the kind of adventures we was fixing to have.

Well, as I was saying, we waited that morning till everybody was settled down to business, and nobody in sight around the yard; then Tom he carried the sack into the lean-to whilst I stood off a piece to keep watch. By-and-by he come out, and we went and set down on the woodpile to talk. He says:
“Everything’s all right now except tools; and that’s easy fixed.”
“Tools?” I says.
“Yes.”
“Tools for what?”
“Why, to dig with. We ain’t a-going to gnaw him out, are we?”
“Ain’t them old crippled picks and things in there good enough to dig a nigger out with?” I says.
He turns on me, looking pitying enough to make a body cry, and says:
“Huck Finn, did you ever hear of a prisoner having picks and shovels, and all the modern conveniences in his wardrobe to dig himself out with? Now I want to ask you—if you got any reasonableness in you at all—what kind of a show would that give him to be a hero? Why, they might as well lend him the key and done with it. Picks and shovels—why, they wouldn’t furnish ’em to a king.”
“Well, then,” I says, “if we don’t want the picks and shovels, what do we want?”
“A couple of case-knives.”
“To dig the foundations out from under that cabin with?”
“Yes.”
“Confound it, it’s foolish, Tom.”
“It don’t make no difference how foolish it is, it’s the right way—and it’s the regular way. And there ain’t no other way, that ever I heard of, and I’ve read all the books that gives any information about these things. They always dig out with a case-knife—and not through dirt, mind you; generly it’s through solid rock. And it takes them weeks and weeks and weeks, and for ever and ever. Why, look at one of them prisoners in the bottom dungeon of the Castle Deef, in the harbor of Marseilles, that dug himself out that way; how long was he at it, you reckon?”
“I don’t know.”
“Well, guess.”
“I don’t know. A month and a half.”
“Thirty-seven year—and he come out in China. That’s the kind. I wish the bottom of this fortress was solid rock.”

events.title: A Compromise on Time, Theatrics, and Acquiring the 'Proper' Tools
detailed_summary: Huck pointed out the irrelevance of China to Jim and then raised a practical concern: Jim was too old to endure an escape dug out with case-knives over a long period.
Tom reassured Huck that Jim would last, as digging through dirt wouldn't take thirty-seven years.
When Huck asked for an estimated time, Tom admitted they couldn't take as long as they 'ought to' (implying years) because Uncle Silas might soon learn Jim wasn't from New Orleans and advertise him.
Tom proposed a compromise: they would dig quickly but then 'let on' to themselves that they had been at it for thirty-seven years, allowing them to snatch Jim away at the first alarm.
Huck found sense in this plan, agreeing that 'letting on' was easy and he wouldn't mind pretending it took even a hundred and fifty years.
He then offered to go 'smouch' a couple of case-knives.
Tom instructed him to get three, needing one to fashion into a saw.
Huck hesitantly suggested using an old rusty saw-blade he knew of, located behind the smoke-house.
Tom, looking weary and discouraged by Huck's persistent practicality, dismissed the idea, telling Huck it was no use trying to teach him anything and to just get the three knives.
Huck complied and procured the knives.

Reckon it’s a powerful far-off place, full o’ folks that talks mighty strange and eats all sorts o’ queer things. But I don’t see what that’s got to do with us floatin’ down this river.”

Here we are, driftin’ along, free as birds, and there’s folks over yonder in China doin’ the same, only they got their own rivers and their own troubles.”

Jim nodded slow-like, his eyes fixed on the water. “Dat’s de truth, Huck. Ever’body got dey own river to float, dey own troubles to bear. Don’t matter if dey’s black or white or yeller—ain’t none of us free from worry.”

That got me thinkin’ deeper. Jim had a way of sayin’ things that stuck with you. Here he was, a runaway slave, and yet he understood more about folks than most anybody I’d ever met. He knew that no matter where you was from, life had a way of weighin’ on you same as anybody else.

“You reckon them Chinese folks got slaves too?” I asked, though I wasn’t sure why it mattered.

Jim sighed heavy. “I ’spect dey does, Huck. Seems like wherever dere’s people, dere’s somebody tryin’ to put chains on somebody else. But maybe not all places is like dat. Maybe somewheres out dere, folks live free and don’t bother nobody ’bout what dey look like or where dey come from.”

I hoped he was right. The river stretched out ahead of us, wide and endless, and for the first time, I felt like it wasn’t just carryin’ us away from trouble, but maybe toward somethin’ better. A place where a fella like Jim wouldn’t have to hide, and where a boy like me could just be, without the world tellin’ him how.

“Well,” I said, leanin’ back against the raft, “long as we got this river and each other, I reckon we’re doin’ all right.”

Jim smiled, slow and easy. “Dat’s right, Huck. Dat’s right.”

events.title: The Futility of Case-Knives and Tom's "Moral" Shift to Picks
detailed_summary: Huck and Tom sneak out and begin their attempt to dig Jim out using case-knives, working near Jim's bed inside a lean-to.
They toil for hours until almost midnight, but their efforts yield minimal results, leaving them exhausted and with blistered hands.
Huck expresses his frustration, remarking that the task seems like it will take an impossibly long time.
Tom becomes contemplative and eventually concedes that digging with case-knives is impractical given their limited time, contrasting it with how prisoners with ample time would operate.
He suggests they must resort to using picks for speed but insists they must 'let on' or pretend they are using case-knives to maintain the 'propriety' of the escape.
Huck readily agrees to using picks, stating he doesn't care about the morality of the method as long as the goal is achieved, be it freeing Jim, stealing a watermelon, or a Sunday-school book.

Tom rationalizes this deception, claiming that while Huck might use picks openly due to his perceived lack of understanding, he, Tom, knows better and must adhere to the 'rules,' thus requiring the pretense.
Tom then theatrically asks for a case-knife, only to discard it, and wordlessly accepts the pickaxe Huck offers him.

As soon as we reckoned everybody was asleep that night we went down the lightning-rod, and shut ourselves up in the lean-to, and got out our pile of fox-fire, and went to work. We cleared everything out of the way, about four or five foot along the middle of the bottom log. Tom said he was right behind Jim’s bed now, and we’d dig in under it, and when we got through there couldn’t nobody in the cabin ever know there was any hole there, because Jim’s counter-pin hung down most to the ground, and you’d have to raise it up and look under to see the hole. So we dug and dug with the case-knives till most midnight; and then we was dog-tired, and our hands was blistered, and yet you couldn’t see we’d done anything hardly. At last I says:
“This ain’t no thirty-seven year job; this is a thirty-eight year job, Tom Sawyer.”
He never said nothing. But he sighed, and pretty soon he stopped digging, and then for a good little while I knowed that he was thinking. Then he says:
“It ain’t no use, Huck, it ain’t a-going to work. If we was prisoners it would, because then we’d have as many years as we wanted, and no hurry; and we wouldn’t get but a few minutes to dig, every day, while they was changing watches, and so our hands wouldn’t get blistered, and we could keep it up right along, year in and year out, and do it right, and the way it ought to be done. But we can’t fool along; we got to rush; we ain’t got no time to spare. If we was to put in another night this way we’d have to knock off for a week to let our hands get well—couldn’t touch a case-knife with them sooner.”
“Well, then, what we going to do, Tom?”
“I’ll tell you. It ain’t right, and it ain’t moral, and I wouldn’t like it to get out; but there ain’t only just the one way: we got to dig him out with the picks, and let on it’s case-knives.”
“Now you’re talking!” I says; “your head gets leveler and leveler all the time, Tom Sawyer,” I says. “Picks is the thing, moral or no moral; and as for me, I don’t care shucks for the morality of it, nohow. When I start in to steal a nigger, or a watermelon, or a Sunday-school book, I ain’t no ways particular how it’s done so it’s done. What I want is my nigger; or what I want is my watermelon; or what I want is my Sunday-school book; and if a pick’s the handiest thing, that’s the thing I’m a-going to dig that nigger or that watermelon or that Sunday-school book out with; and I don’t give a dead rat what the authorities thinks about it nuther.”
“Well,” he says, “there’s excuse for picks and letting-on in a case like this; if it warn’t so, I wouldn’t approve of it, nor I wouldn’t stand by and see the rules broke—because right is right, and wrong is wrong, and a body ain’t got no business doing wrong when he ain’t ignorant and knows better. It might answer for you to dig Jim out with a pick, without any letting on, because you don’t know no better; but it wouldn’t for me, because I do know better. Gimme a case-knife.”
He had his own by him, but I handed him mine. He flung it down, and says:
“Gimme a case-knife.”
I didn’t know just what to do—but then I thought. I scratched around amongst the old tools, and got a pickaxe and give it to him, and he took it and went to work, and never said a word.
He was always just that particular. Full of principle.

We cleared everything away from the corner of the lean-to, about four or five foot square. Tom said he was going to dig a tunnel right under Jim’s bed, so he could crawl out when the time came. I didn’t see no sense in it, seeing as we could just unlock the chain and walk him out the door, but Tom said that wasn’t the way it was done in books. There had to a tunnel, and it had to be dug with case-knives, and it had to take weeks, else it wouldn’t be a proper escape.

So we set to work, scratching away at the dirt with our knives. It was slow going, and before long my hands were sore and blistered. Tom kept whispering about how grand it was and how Jim would appreciate all the trouble we was taking. I reckoned Jim would’ve been just as happy with a quicker plan, but I didn’t say nothing. Tom had his heart set on doing it the “right” way, and there wasn’t no arguing with him once his mind was made up.

After a couple hours, we hadn’t made much progress. The ground was hard-packed, and the knives kept slipping. Tom sat back, wiping his forehead, and said we needed to think smarter. He pulled out a nail from his pocket and started scratching marks on the blade of his knife.

“What’re you doing?” I asked.

“Making a saw,” he said. “We’ll cut through the dirt like it’s wood. That’ll go faster.”

I didn’t see how that would help much, but I let him have his way. Sure enough, after another hour, we’d only dug down about six inches. Tom was getting frustrated, but he wouldn’t give up. He said we had to keep at it, no matter how long it took.

Then I had an idea. “Why don’t we just use a shovel?” I whispered. “There’s one leaning against the shed outside.”

Tom looked at me like I’d gone crazy. “A shovel? Huck, that ain’t the way it’s done! Prisoners don’t get shovels—they have to make do with what they can find. It’s got to be hard, or it ain’t an adventure.”

I sighed and went back to scraping with my knife. My fingers were raw, and I was starting to think this whole plan was foolish. But Tom was dead set on it, so I kept quiet and kept working.

By the time the sky started turning gray in the east, we’d only managed to dig a shallow hole. Tom said we’d have to cover it up before daylight so nobody would notice. We piled some old boards and straw over it, then sneaked back up the lightning-rod to our beds.

As I lay there, my hands aching, I couldn’t help but wonder if there wasn’t an easier way to help Jim. But Tom Sawyer had read a heap of books, and he was bound to do things according to the rules of adventure. I just hoped Jim wouldn’t have to wait too long before we got him out.

events.title: Progress with Picks, Ingenious Entry, and First Reunion with Jim
detailed_summary: Huck and Tom switch to using a pick and shovel, making significantly more progress in about half an hour of strenuous work.
After digging, Tom finds he cannot climb back up the lightning rod because his hands are too sore.
Huck proposes that Tom simply use the stairs and pretend it was the lightning rod, a suggestion Tom accepts.
The following day, Tom procures a pewter spoon, a brass candlestick, and six tallow candles for Jim's escape, while Huck manages to steal three tin plates.
Tom initially deems Huck's contribution insufficient but is satisfied when Huck explains the plates can be reused.
Tom dismisses Huck's straightforward idea of passing items to Jim through the hole they dug as too simplistic.
That night, they resume their efforts and successfully dig their way into Jim's cabin within about two and a half hours.
They enter, find Jim looking well, and gently awaken him.
Jim is overcome with emotion upon seeing them and expresses an urgent desire to have his leg chain cut and escape immediately.
Tom, however, dissuades him, explaining his more elaborate, 'regular' plans for the escape and reassuring Jim of their success.
Jim informs them that Uncle Silas visits to pray with him and Aunt Sally checks on his comfort and food, both treating him kindly.
This information gives Tom a new idea for smuggling items to Jim, planning to use Silas and Sally as unwitting couriers.

So then I got a shovel, and then we picked and shoveled, turn about, and made the fur fly. We stuck to it about a half an hour, which was as long as we could stand up; but we had a good deal of a hole to show for it. When I got up stairs I looked out at the window and see Tom doing his level best with the lightning-rod, but he couldn’t come it, his hands was so sore. At last he says:
“It ain’t no use, it can’t be done. What you reckon I better do? Can’t you think of no way?”
“Yes,” I says, “but I reckon it ain’t regular. Come up the stairs, and let on it’s a lightning-rod.”
So he done it.
Next day Tom stole a pewter spoon and a brass candlestick in the house, for to make some pens for Jim out of, and six tallow candles; and I hung around the nigger cabins and laid for a chance, and stole three tin plates. Tom says it wasn’t enough; but I said nobody wouldn’t ever see the plates that Jim throwed out, because they’d fall in the dog-fennel and jimpson weeds under the window-hole—then we could tote them back and he could use them over again. So Tom was satisfied. Then he says:
“Now, the thing to study out is, how to get the things to Jim.”
“Take them in through the hole,” I says, “when we get it done.”
He only just looked scornful, and said something about nobody ever heard of such an idiotic idea, and then he went to studying. By-and-by he said he had ciphered out two or three ways, but there warn’t no need to decide on any of them yet. Said we’d got to post Jim first.
That night we went down the lightning-rod a little after ten, and took one of the candles along, and listened under the window-hole, and heard Jim snoring; so we pitched it in, and it didn’t wake him. Then we whirled in with the pick and shovel, and in about two hours and a half the job was done. We crept in under Jim’s bed and into the cabin, and pawed around and found the candle and lit it, and stood over Jim awhile, and found him looking hearty and healthy, and then we woke him up gentle and gradual. He was so glad to see us he most cried; and called us honey, and all the pet names he could think of; and was for having us hunt up a cold-chisel to cut the chain off of his leg with right away, and clearing out without losing any time. But Tom he showed him how unregular it would be, and set down and told him all about our plans, and how we could alter them in a minute any time there was an alarm; and not to be the least afraid, because we would see he got away, sure. So Jim he said it was all right, and we set there and talked over old times awhile, and then Tom asked a lot of questions, and when Jim told him Uncle Silas come in every day or two to pray with him, and Aunt Sally come in to see if he was comfortable and had plenty to eat, and both of them was kind as they could be, Tom says:
“Now I know how to fix it. We’ll send you some things by them.”

So then I got a shovel, and then we picked and shoveled, turn about, and made the fur fly. We worked like beavers, digging and scraping, till the hole was deep enough to bury a man—or at least a small one. Tom said it had to be just right, not too deep and not too shallow, else the whole plan would be spoiled.  

“Now,” says Tom, “we got to fetch some vittles and a knife, and a couple of blankets, and a coil of rope, and a few other things. It’s got to look like a real robber’s den, Huck, else what’s the use?”  

I reckoned he was right, though it seemed like a powerful lot of trouble just to play at being robbers. But Tom Sawyer had a way of making even the silliest notions seem grand and important. So off we went, sneaking back to the widow’s house to pilfer what we needed.  

The widow kept a sharp eye on her pantry, but I knew all the tricks for slipping in and out without being seen. We stuffed a sack full of cornbread, bacon, and a jug of molasses, then tiptoed out like shadows. Tom swiped a butcher knife from the kitchen drawer, and I snagged an old quilt from the linen closet.  

“This here’s prime,” Tom whispered, grinning like a possum in a persimmon tree. “Now we just need the rope.”  

That was trickier. The only rope we could find was hanging in the barn, and Jim, the widow’s slave, was sleeping right under it. Jim was a kindly sort, but he had a way of waking up sudden-like if he heard so much as a mouse squeak.  

“You distract him,” Tom said, “and I’ll cut the rope down.”  

I didn’t much like the idea of waking Jim, but Tom had that look in his eye—the one that meant arguing was useless. So I crept up close and gave a low whistle. Jim stirred but didn’t wake. I whistled again, louder this time, and Jim sat up, rubbing his eyes.  

“Who dar?” he mumbled, peering into the dark.  

I ducked behind a barrel, heart pounding like a drum. Meanwhile, Tom was sawing away at the rope with the butcher knife. Just as Jim was about to get up and investigate, the rope came loose with a *snap!* and Tom caught it before it hit the ground.  

Jim scratched his head, muttered something about “hants,” and lay back down. We didn’t wait to see if he’d settle—we lit out of there like our tails was on fire.  

Back at the hideout, we laid out our loot and admired our handiwork. Tom said it was the finest robber’s den he’d ever seen, and I reckoned he was probably right, seeing as how neither of us had ever seen a real one.  

“Now all we need is a secret oath,” Tom declared, “and blood.”  

“Blood?” I said, feeling a mite queasy.  

“Sure,” says Tom. “All the best gangs sign their oaths in blood. It’s in all the books.”  

I didn’t much care for the notion, but Tom was already pricking his finger with the knife. He squeezed out a drop onto a piece of paper and handed the knife to me.  

“Your turn,” he said.  

I gritted my teeth and poked my thumb. The blood welled up, bright red, and I smeared it next to Tom’s mark.  

“There,” Tom said, satisfied. “Now we’re bound for life—or death.”  

I wasn’t so sure about the “death” part, but I kept quiet. After all, it was just a game.  

Or so I thought.

events.title: Tom Details His Elaborate Escape Scheme to a Puzzled Jim
detailed_summary: Huck vehemently objects to Tom's new plan of involving Uncle Silas and Aunt Sally, deeming it idiotic, but Tom disregards his concerns, characteristic of his determination once a plan is set.
Tom then elaborates his complex scheme to Jim: smuggling a rope-ladder pie and other large items via Nat, the slave who feeds Jim, and instructing Jim on how to receive them covertly.

events.title: The Painful Candlestick Prank and an Unexpected Canine Intrusion
detailed_summary: The next morning, Tom and Huck go to the woodpile and chop the stolen brass candlestick into manageable pieces.
Tom pockets these pieces along with the pewter spoon.
They proceed to the slave cabins where, while Huck distracts Nat, Jim's caretaker, Tom embeds a piece of the candlestick into a corn-pone meant for Jim's meal.
They accompany Nat to witness the outcome of their prank.
The prank succeeds dramatically when Jim bites into the corn-pone, almost breaking all his teeth on the hidden metal piece.
Jim, however, does not betray any awareness of the prank, merely acting as if he encountered a common stone in his bread.
This incident leads Jim to meticulously inspect all his food with a fork before taking a bite thereafter.
As they stand in the dim cabin, a sudden commotion occurs as eleven hounds burst in from under Jim's bed, having entered through the lean-to door which the boys had forgotten to secure.
Nat, utterly terrified by the sudden appearance of the dogs, screams "Witches" once before collapsing onto the floor amidst them, groaning as if he were dying.

events.text_segment:
In the morning we went out to the woodpile and chopped up the brass candlestick into handy sizes, and Tom put them and the pewter spoon in his pocket. Then we went to the nigger cabins, and while I got Nat’s notice off, Tom shoved a piece of candlestick into the middle of a corn-pone that was in Jim’s pan, and we went along with Nat to see how it would work, and it just worked noble; when Jim bit into it it most mashed all his teeth out; and there warn’t ever anything could a worked better. Tom said so himself. Jim he never let on but what it was only just a piece of rock or something like that that’s always getting into bread, you know; but after that he never bit into nothing but what he jabbed his fork into it in three or four places first.
And whilst we was a-standing there in the dimmish light, here comes a couple of the hounds bulging in from under Jim’s bed; and they kept on piling in till there was eleven of them, and there warn’t hardly room in there to get your breath. By jings, we forgot to fasten that lean-to door! The nigger Nat he only just hollered “Witches” once, and keeled over on to the floor amongst the dogs, and begun to groan like he was dying.

events.title: Tom Exploits Nat's Superstition with the "Witch Pie" Ruse
detailed_summary: Tom reacts quickly to the hound invasion, throwing a piece of Jim's meat to distract the dogs, then slips out to secure the lean-to door and returns.
He attempts to soothe the terrified Nat, suggesting that Nat might have merely imagined the swarm of dogs.

Nat, however, remains adamant, vividly describing his conviction that he saw nearly a million dogs or devils and felt their presence all over him, expressing both a desire for revenge on the 'witches' and a stronger wish to be left alone by them.
Tom seizes upon Nat's superstitious fear, theorizing that the 'witches' (the dogs) appeared at the runaway slave's breakfast time because they were hungry.
He then proposes that Nat should make a 'witch pie' to appease these supernatural visitors.
When Nat confesses his ignorance on how to prepare such a pie, Tom offers to make it himself, an offer Nat gratefully accepts.

Tom then issues a series of mysterious instructions to Nat: he must turn his back while the pie is being prepared, not acknowledge anything put into the pan, avoid looking when Jim unloads the pan, and, most importantly, never touch any of the 'witch-things'.
Nat, thoroughly convinced of the supernatural danger, vehemently promises to follow Tom's instructions, asserting he wouldn't touch the enchanted items for an astronomical sum of money.

Then he went to work on the nigger, coaxing him and petting him, and asking him if he’d been imagining he saw something again. He raised up, and blinked his eyes around, and says:
“Mars Sid, you’ll say I’s a fool, but if I didn’t b’lieve I see most a million dogs, er devils, er some’n, I wisht I may die right heah in dese tracks. I did, mos’ sholy. Mars Sid, I felt um—I felt um, sah; dey was all over me. Dad fetch it, I jis’ wisht I could git my han’s on one er dem witches jis’ wunst—on’y jis’ wunst—it’s all I’d ast. But mos’ly I wisht dey’d lemme ’lone, I does.”
Tom says:
“Well, I tell you what I think. What makes them come here just at this runaway nigger’s breakfast-time? It’s because they’re hungry; that’s the reason. You make them a witch pie; that’s the thing for you to do.”
“But my lan’, Mars Sid, how’s I gwyne to make ’m a witch pie? I doan’ know how to make it. I hain’t ever hearn er sich a thing b’fo’.”
“Well, then, I’ll have to make it myself.”
“Will you do it, honey?—will you? I’ll wusshup de groun’ und’ yo’ foot, I will!”
“All right, I’ll do it, seeing it’s you, and you’ve been good to us and showed us the runaway nigger. But you got to be mighty careful. When we come around, you turn your back; and then whatever we’ve put in the pan, don’t you let on you see it at all. And don’t you look when Jim unloads the pan—something might happen, I don’t know what. And above all, don’t you handle the witch-things.”
“Hannel ’m, Mars Sid? What is you a-talkin’ ’bout? I wouldn’ lay de weight er my finger on um, not f’r ten hund’d thous’n billion dollars, I wouldn’t.”

events.title: Preparations and Planting Evidence for Jim's Escape
detailed_summary: Huck and Tom searched a rubbish pile for necessary items.
They found an old tin washpan to bake a pie in, stopping its holes.
They took the washpan to the cellar and filled it with stolen flour.
They found two shingle-nails, which Tom suggested a prisoner could use to write on dungeon walls.
One nail was placed in Aunt Sally's apron pocket, which was on a chair.
The other nail was stuck in the band of Uncle Silas's hat on the bureau.
They did this knowing the Phelpses planned to visit Jim (the runaway nigger) that morning.
At breakfast, before Aunt Sally arrived, Tom put a pewter spoon into Uncle Silas's coat pocket.
They had to wait for Aunt Sally to join them for breakfast.

events.title: Breakfast Turmoil: The Mystery of the Missing Items
detailed_summary: Aunt Sally arrived for breakfast visibly hot, flushed, and annoyed, immediately disciplining a child.
She exclaimed her frustration over Uncle Silas's other shirt being missing despite extensive searching.
Huck was startled, and a piece of corn-crust he was eating shot out of his mouth, hitting a child.
Tom also appeared visibly uneasy due to this unexpected complication.
Uncle Silas expressed his confusion, stating he knew he had taken the shirt off.
Aunt Sally countered that she saw it on the clothesline the previous day and that it was now gone, forcing Uncle Silas to wear a red flannel one.
She lamented having to make him a third shirt in two years, puzzled by how he managed to lose them.
Uncle Silas defended himself, saying he only wears the shirts and doesn't believe he loses them while wearing them.
Aunt Sally retorted that other items were also missing: a spoon (from a set of ten, now nine) and six candles.
She speculated that rats might have taken the candles, criticizing Uncle Silas for not stopping their holes, but insisted rats wouldn't take a spoon.
Uncle Silas admitted his fault regarding the rat holes and promised to fix them the next day.
Aunt Sally sarcastically told him not to rush, then disciplined another child for reaching for the sugar bowl.
A servant woman, Lize, then reported that a sheet was missing from the clothesline.
Uncle Silas, looking sorrowful, reiterated his promise to stop up the rat holes that very day.
Aunt Sally angrily dismissed the idea of rats taking a sheet and questioned Lize about its whereabouts.
Lize confirmed the sheet was on the line yesterday but was gone now.
Aunt Sally despaired at the series of disappearances, listing the shirt, sheet, spoon, and starting to mention the candles when interrupted.
A young female servant then announced that a brass candlestick was also missing.
Aunt Sally, now utterly incensed, threatened the servant with a skillet.

And when she come she was hot and red and cross, and couldn’t hardly wait for the blessing; and then she went to sluicing out coffee with one hand and cracking the handiest child’s head with her thimble with the other, and says:
“I’ve hunted high and I’ve hunted low, and it does beat all what has become of your other shirt.”
My heart fell down amongst my lungs and livers and things, and a hard piece of corn-crust started down my throat after it and got met on the road with a cough, and was shot across the table, and took one of the children in the eye and curled him up like a fishing-worm, and let a cry out of him the size of a warwhoop, and Tom he turned kinder blue around the gills, and it all amounted to a considerable state of things for about a quarter of a minute or as much as that, and I would a sold out for half price if there was a bidder. But after that we was all right again—it was the sudden surprise of it that knocked us so kind of cold. Uncle Silas he says:
“It’s most uncommon curious, I can’t understand it. I know perfectly well I took it off, because—”
“Because you hain’t got but one on. Just listen at the man! I know you took it off, and know it by a better way than your wool-gethering memory, too, because it was on the clo’s-line yesterday—I see it there myself. But it’s gone, that’s the long and the short of it, and you’ll just have to change to a red flann’l one till I can get time to make a new one. And it’ll be the third I’ve made in two years. It just keeps a body on the jump to keep you in shirts; and whatever you do manage to do with ’m all is more’n I can make out. A body ’d think you would learn to take some sort of care of ’em at your time of life.”
“I know it, Sally, and I do try all I can. But it oughtn’t to be altogether my fault, because, you know, I don’t see them nor have nothing to do with them except when they’re on me; and I don’t believe I’ve ever lost one of them off of me.”
“Well, it ain’t your fault if you haven’t, Silas; you’d a done it if you could, I reckon. And the shirt ain’t all that’s gone, nuther. Ther’s a spoon gone; and that ain’t all. There was ten, and now ther’s only nine. The calf got the shirt, I reckon, but the calf never took the spoon, that’s certain.”
“Why, what else is gone, Sally?”
“Ther’s six candles gone—that’s what. The rats could a got the candles, and I reckon they did; I wonder they don’t walk off with the whole place, the way you’re always going to stop their holes and don’t do it; and if they warn’t fools they’d sleep in your hair, Silas—you’d never find it out; but you can’t lay the spoon on the rats, and that I know.”
“Well, Sally, I’m in fault, and I acknowledge it; I’ve been remiss; but I won’t let to-morrow go by without stopping up them holes.”
“Oh, I wouldn’t hurry; next year’ll do. Matilda Angelina Araminta Phelps!”
Whack comes the thimble, and the child snatches her claws out of the sugar-bowl without fooling around any. Just then the nigger woman steps on to the passage, and says:
“Missus, dey’s a sheet gone.”
“A sheet gone! Well, for the land’s sake!”
“I’ll stop up them holes to-day,” says Uncle Silas, looking sorrowful.
“Oh, do shet up!—s’pose the rats took the sheet? Where’s it gone, Lize?”
“Clah to goodness I hain’t no notion, Miss’ Sally. She wuz on de clo’sline yistiddy, but she done gone: she ain’ dah no mo’ now.”
“I reckon the world is coming to an end. I never see the beat of it in all my born days. A shirt, and a sheet, and a spoon, and six can—”
“Missus,” comes a young yaller wench, “dey’s a brass cannelstick miss’n.”
“Cler out from here, you hussy, er I’ll take a skillet to ye!”
